questions.text: A woman during her routine examination presents with the following X-ray finding. What is her most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Multiple Enchondromas

Explanation:

  • Enchondromas are benign hyaline cartilage tumors of unknown etiology occurring in bones of endochondral origin.
  • Although they can develop in other bones as well, these tumors are most frequently found in the tiny bones of the hands and feet.
  • When multiple enchondromas manifest in a unilateral pattern, the ailment is known as Ollier's disease.
  • In the given X-ray growth of some benign tumors made of cartilage tissue near the tiny bones of the hand is observed.

Multiple Enchondromatosis

  • Definition: Condition characterized by numerous benign cartilaginous tumors (chondromas).
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Ollier's disease- only enchondromas
    • Maffucci syndrome- enchondromas + hemangiomas

Ollier's Disease

Feature

Details

Clinical Presentation

Usually diagnosed in childhood

Most chondromas found in phalangeal bones

Common findings:

  • Asymmetric limb shortening
  • Swelling of fingers/toes
  • Impaired movement of interphalangeal joints

Distribution

Can be unilateral or bilateral

Progression

New chondromas typically stop after puberty

Tumor growth in adulthood may indicate malignancy

Risk of pathological fractures

Malignant Transformation

20-30% risk of secondary chondrosarcoma

Transformation usually occurs in the 30s or 40s

Warning signs:

  • Increase in size of existing chondroma
  • New symptoms

Multiple Brown Tumor (Option A), also known as osteoclastic giant cell tumors, are a rare complication of hyperparathyroidism, a disease in which the parathyroid gland overproduces the hormone parathyroid. These tumors are composed of fibrous tissue and areas of hemorrhage and cystic degeneration, and they can appear as osteolytic (bone-destructive) lesions on X-ray.

Fibrous Dysplasia (Option B) can appear as a "ground-glass" or "smudged" appearance with areas of increased and decreased density.

Multiple Exostoses (Option D) The development of numerous noncancerous bone growths, known as osteochondromas, on the outer surface of bones characterizes multiple exostoses, also known as hereditary multiple osteochondromas. On X-ray, exostoses can appear as bony projections arising from the surface of bones

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the type of fixation shown in the image?

choices.text: Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

questions.solution:
Spanning Fixator:

Definition

A type of external fixation device used to stabilize fractures or deformities, spanning over a joint.

Indications
  • Complex fractures
  • Joint instability
  • Bone deformities
  • Temporary stabilization during healing

Types
  • Unilateral fixator
  • Bilateral fixator
  • Circular fixator

Mechanism of Action

The fixator applies external support to immobilize the fractured area and maintain proper alignment while healing.

Advantages
  • Minimizes surgical exposure
  • Adjustable design
  • Can be used in complex fractures
  • Can be applied to both long bones and joints

Disadvantages
  • Pin-site infections
  • Risk of soft tissue damage
  • Aesthetic concerns due to external frame

Duration of Use

Typically used temporarily, but can be extended depending on the severity of the fracture or injury.

 

Fracture tibia, ilizarov fixator (Option A) An Ilizarov fixator, a special device that is surgically implanted into the afflicted bone to give stability and speed the healing process, can be used to treat a tibia fracture, which is a crack or break in the shin bone.

Fracture tibia, spanning fixator (Option B) A spanning fixator may be used as an external fixation device in the case of a tibia fracture to support and stabilize the bone as it heals. In order to keep the bone immobilized, the spanning fixator requires inserting metal pins or wires above and below the fracture. These are then joined by an external frame or bar.

Fracture femur, spanning fixator (Option C) Implementing a spanning fixator could be a potential recovery option in the event that the long bone in the area of the thigh, the femur, fractures.

questions.text: A male patient presented with the fracture of Tibia following a road traffic accident. He was managed appropriately, but after 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Fat Embolism

Explanation:

  • Dyspnea, and the presence of petechiae all over the body in a male patient who has broken a long bone in a car accident could be signs of the hazardous medical disorder known as fat embolism syndrome (FES)
  • Fat embolism syndrome (FES) is a serious medical condition that can occur after a bone fracture or other traumatic injury.
  • Symptoms of FES include dyspnea, decreased oxygen saturation, and petechiae all over the body.

 

Gurd and Wilson's Diagnostic Criteria:

One major criterion, four minor criteria, and the presence of macroglobulinemia are required for the diagnosis.

Major criteria

Minor criteria
  • Respiratory insufficiency (symptoms and radiologic evidence)
  • Cerebral dysfunction not caused by head injury or other conditions
  • Petechial rash
  • Tachycardia (>110 beats/min)
  • Pyrexia (temperature >38.5°C)
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal dysfunction
  • Jaundice
  • Acute drop in haemoglobin
  • Sudden thrombocytopenia
  • Elevated ESR
  • Fat macroglobulinemia.

Air embolism (Option B) occurs when air bubbles obstruct blood flow, risking organ damage or death.

Venous thromboembolism (VTE) (Option C) forms blood clots in veins, often traveling to the lungs, leading to pulmonary embolism and potential fatality.

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) (Option D) causes high blood pressure in lung arteries, straining the heart and leading to eventual failure

questions.text: An intrauterine scan at the 13th week of pregnancy showed a fetus with multiple long bone fractures. What is commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Osteogenesis Imperfecta

Explanation:

  • Multiple long bone fractures seen on an ultrasound during the 13th week of pregnancy are typically indicative of osteogenesis imperfecta, a genetic disorder.

Osteogenesis Imperfecta:

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic condition that affects bone strength and causes brittle bones.Hearing issues, dental deformities, and discolored sclera (the whites of the eyes) are further signs of osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • Ultrasound imaging can detect multiple long bone fractures in a fetus with osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • Defective Type 1 collagen.
  • Genetic Disorders and Prenatal Screening:
  • Prenatal screening tests can detect genetic disorders such as osteogenesis imperfecta during pregnancy.
  • Most commonly COL1A1 and COL1A2.

Radiological features:

  • Wormian bones: Supernumerary bones of the skull that form as a result of extra-ossification centres during development in utero. These are classic osteogenesis imperfecta and are usually within and surrounded by the suture lines.
  • Frontal and mastoid sinus enlargement: Observed in some patients.
  • Thin cortices of long bones: General demineralization and thinning of bone cortices.
  • Frontal and mastoid sinus enlargement: Observed in some patients
  • Reduction in bone density: Notable in severe forms of osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • Codfish vertebra: Biconcave appearance of vertebrae (esp. Lumbar vertebrae) noted in imaging studies.
  • Fracture deformities: Mid-diaphyseal deformities (e.g., apex anterior) due to fragility fractures.
  • Protrusio acetabuli: Common hip finding.
  • Shepherd’s crook deformity: Common in femurs and is classically associated with fibrous dysplasia
  • Radiolucent scalloping with radio-dense rims: "Popcorn" appearance in metaphyses.
  • Trumpet-like metaphysis: Characteristic deformity seen in radiology.

Diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta:

  • Serum calcium and phosphorus levels: Typically normal.
  • Alkaline phosphatase: Elevated.

Management of Osteogenesis Imperfecta

  • Physiotherapy & Mobility Aids:
    • Walking aids and orthotics to maximize mobility and reduce fracture risk.
  • Pharmaceutical Agents:
    • Bisphosphonates:
      • IV Zoledronate: Commonly used in children to enhance bone strength by inhibiting osteoclastic bone resorption.
      • Increases cortical thickness.
      • Cycles of intravenous bisphosphonates reduce bone pain and fracture incidence.
  • Surgical Intervention:
    • Sheffield Procedure:
      • Used in children with bowed long bones.
      • Involves the insertion of expanding intramedullary rods or telescopic rods to improve weight-bearing and correct deformities.
    • Sofield-Miller or Kebab Osteotomy:
      • Involves multiple osteotomies of bowed long bones in children to correct severe deformities and enhance bone stability.
    • Intramedullary fixation systems are often utilized to stabilize load-bearing bones.

Achondroplasia (Option A) Dwarfism is a side effect of the genetic condition achondroplasia, which inhibits bone growth. It is brought on by a mutation in the FGFR3 gene, which has an impact on how cartilage grows in bone growth plates.

Cretinism (Option C) Congenital hypothyroidism is a disorder that develops in cretinism, which affects growth and development, intellectual disability, and other aspects of health.

Marfan Syndrome (Option D), a hereditary condition which produce defective fibrillin protein. In addition to other difficulties, it may affect the heart, eyes, and skeletal system. Marfan syndrome patients typically have lengthy fingers and limbs and are tall and slender.

questions.text: What is the most common Late complication of this condition, if left untreated ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C)Cubitus Varus

 

Explanation:

Cubitus varus or bow elbow or gunstock deformity is the result of malunion occurring as a complication of supracondylar fracture of the humerus. It occurs in only the extension type of supracondylar fracture of the humerus, causing a reduction or loss of the carrying angle

 

Supracondylar Fractures

Mechanism of injury

Fall on outstretched hand (FOOSH)

Location

Humerus fractures just above the condyles.

Displacements

The distal fragment of the humerus is usually displaced by

  • Posterior shift (Due to Impaction)
  • Posterior Tilt
  • Proximal shift
  • Medial shift/ Tilt
  • Internal rotation

Types
  • Type 1: Undisplaced fracture
  • Type 2: Partially displaced fracture with displacement of only anterior cortex
  • Type 3: Completely displaced anterior and posterior cortex.

Clinical Presentation
  • Severe elbow pain, swelling, deformity, and loss of function may occur, and neurological symptoms like weakness in wrist flexion or the "hand of benediction" sign may also occur if the median nerve is affected.
  • Unusual posterior prominence of the olecranon in the backward tilt (S-shaped deformity)
  • The skin around the fracture has a dimpled appearance (Dimple sign)

X-ray Findings
  • Three bony parts relationship is maintained.
  • Fat Pad or Sail sign: A translucent shadow-like appearance representing anterior and posterior fat pads.
  • Disturbed tear drop sign: An abnormal appearance of the fat pad, suggesting the presence of an injury, such as a fracture or joint effusion.

 

  • Fishtail sign: The ends of the proximal fragment are slightly widened and serrated, resembling a fishtail.

 

  • Crescent sign: The normal radiolucent gap of the elbow joint is replaced by a crescent-shaped shadow from the capitulum overlapping the olecranon, indicating varus or valgus tilt of the distal fragment.

Management

Based on the type of fracture

  • Undisplaced fracture: Immobilisation in above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90-degree flexion.
  • Displaced fractures
    • Closed reduction with percutaneous K-wire fixation. (for Type 2 fracture)
    • Open reduction internal fixation with K-wire. (for Type 3 fracture)
  • In Late presentation with swelling
    • Dunlop traction (skin)
    • Smith traction (skeletal)

Complications
  • Early complications
    • Vascular injury (commonly Brachial artery)
    • Nerve injury (commonly Anterior Interosseous nerve)
  • Delayed complications
    • Cubitus varus or Gunstock deformity (Malunion) (Option C)
    • Volkmann's Ischemia and compartment syndrome.
    • Elbow stiffness
    • Myositis ossificans.

Pulled Elbow (Option A) The condition indicates a pulled elbow (nursemaid’s elbow) caused by a sudden pull on the arm, leading to radial head subluxation. The classic arm position is slightly flexed and pronated.

Dinner Fork Deformity (Option B) occurs due to a Colles' fracture. In this condition, the radial styloid process is positioned at or slightly above the level of the ulnar styloid process, creating the characteristic appearance of a dinner fork.

Osteoarthritis (Option D) Commonly found in older patients, It mainly affects the hips, knees, spine, hands and feet.

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee along with high fever. X – ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. The organism most likely involved is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Salmonella

Explanation:

The peripheral blood smear image suggests sickle cell anemia and Salmonella is most likely the culprit causing the joint infection,as salmonella is the most common causative agent for Osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia. Salmonella affects the Diaphysis (MC)

Osteomyelitis:

  • The most common organism causing Acute and chronic osteomyelitis in Adults & Children- Staphylococcus aureus.(Option A)
  • The most common organism in HIV patients- MRSA
  • The most common organism in patients using intravenous drugs- Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • The most common organism in sickle-cell disease- Salmonella typhi. (Option C)
  • The most common organism in a child between 1 to 4 years- Haemophilus influenza.
  • The most common organism in a child following upper respiratory infection- Kingella kingae

E. coli (Option B) causes illnesses such as urinary tract infections and diarrhea.

Streptococcus (Option D) Numerous infections, including strep throat, pneumonia, and skin infections, are brought on by streptococcus.

questions.text: A boy falls on the left shoulder joint and presents to the emergency department with shoulder pain. His left elbow is flexed and is supported by the right hand. Which bone might be most likely fractured?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Clavicle

Explanation:

The clavicle is most likely to be shattered in the current circumstance. The boy's gesture of using his right hand to support his left elbow with the left suggests a common sign of a clavicle fracture.

Mechanism of Injury:

  • Fall on the shoulder: The most common mechanism is a fall directly onto the point of the shoulder, accounting for 91% of cases.
  • Direct trauma : A direct blow to the clavicle can cause a fracture, especially in high-impact situations (e.g., sports injuries, falls from a height , and road traffic accidents), which contribute to about 8% of clavicle fractures.
  • Fall on an outstretched hand : Rare & responsible for only 1% of cases (but is more commonly associated with fractures of the wrist (Colles fracture), elbow, or shoulder dislocations).

Site of clavicle fracture:

  • Clavicular fracture most commonly occurs at the junction of the middle two-third and outer (lateral) thirds of the clavicle. This area is most vulnerable to injury due to the natural curvature of the bone and the forces exerted during trauma.
  • It is the most common bone to be fractured in children.
  • Displacement:
    • The outer fragment tends to displace medially and downward due to gravity and the pull of the pectoralis major muscle.
    • The inner fragment displaces upward because of the sternocleidomastoid muscle's pull.

 

 

Radiographs: The following views are recommended for evaluating clavicle fractures:

  • Routine Anteroposterior (AP) View of the clavicle.
  • Lordotic View if the fracture is uncertain.
  • Special Radiographic Techniques like CT Scans are required for assessing the distal clavicle.
  • Findings:
    • Fracture Line: A clear line usually located in the middle third of the clavicle.
    • Displacement of Fragments
    • Overlapping Fragments: D/t muscle pull
    • No Medullary Cavity

Scapula (Option B) A fall onto the shoulder joint is unlikely to fracture the scapula, as it is a flat bone that is well-protected by muscles.

Humerus (Option C) is less prone to fractures from falls onto the shoulder joint. Furthermore, the symptom of shoulder pain is not unique to a fractured humerus and could be brought on by a number of other causes.

Rib Cage (Option D) protects the internal organs and the chest sustains little damage. Shoulder discomfort is not a specific sign of rib fracture.

questions.text: DNA packing is done by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Histone

Explanation:

DNA packing is done by histone

Histones:

  • Histones are a small family of closely related basic proteins
  • Essential for the organization and function of chromatin.
  • They play a critical role in DNA packaging within the nucleus, forming the structural unit of chromatin known as the nucleosome.
  • Histones are also involved in regulating gene expression through various posttranslational modifications (PTMs) eg. Acetylation, Methylation, Phosphorylation, ADP-Ribosylation, Monoubiquitylation, and Sumoylation.
  • Rich in lysine and arginine.

Types

Histones can be categorized into core histones and linker histones:

Core Histones: H2A, H2B, H3, and H4

Linker Histone: H1
  • These histones are highly conserved across species, indicating their essential role in cellular processes.
  • The core histones form the nucleosome by creating a histone octamer around which DNA is wrapped.
  • The carboxyl-terminal two-thirds of the histone molecules are hydrophobic, while the amino-terminal thirds are rich in basic amino acids.

 
  • H1 is the least tightly bound to chromatin and can be easily removed with a salt solution, making chromatin more soluble.
  • H1 interacts with DNA as it enters and exits the nucleosome, playing a role in the higher-order structure of chromatin.

 

Histone Octamer

The histone octamer is the fundamental unit of the nucleosome and consists of eight histone molecules:

  • Two molecules each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.
  • These histones interact specifically to form a structure with the composition (H3–H4)₂–(H2A–H2B)₂.
  • H3 and H4 form a tetramer (H3–H4)₂, and H2A and H2B form dimers (H2A–H2B).
  • This octamer binds approximately 145-150 base pairs of DNA, creating 1.75 superhelical turns around it.

questions.text: A patient who hails from Mediterranean country and travels to Africa, they contact malaria. After receiving treatment with primaquine, the patient subsequently develops haemolytic anaemia. Which pathway deficiency in the enzyme could potentially be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Hexose monophosphate (HMP) pathway

Explanation:

The pathway deficiency responsible is the Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP pathway) and enzyme deficiency is G6PD.

Hexose Monophosphate Pathway (HMP):

  • The HMP pathway is essential for generating NADPH, which maintains reduced glutathione (GSH) in red blood cells (RBCs).
  • Reduced glutathione protects RBCs from oxidative damage caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS).
  • The enzyme Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) is the first and rate-limiting enzyme in the HMP pathway.
  • Primaquine, generates oxidative stress by increasing ROS in RBCs.
  • In G6PD-deficient individuals, the HMP pathway fails to produce adequate NADPH, resulting in depletion of reduced glutathione (GSH).
  • Oxidative damage to hemoglobin (Heinz bodies) and the RBC membrane and subsequent haemolysis.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent disorders, exhibit only autosomal recessive inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cystic fibrosis

Explanation:

Cystic fibrosis is autosomal recessive mode of inheritance.

  • Mutation in CFTR gene that causes formation of thick mucus that blocks airway.
  • CFTR gene encodes protein that regulates transfer of salt and water into and out of cells.

Autosomal Dominant

Autosomal Recessive
  • Huntington’s disease (Option A)
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Achondroplasia (Option D)
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1
  • Polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
  • Cystic fibrosis (Option C)
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Tay-Sachs disease
  • Phenylketonuria (PKU)
  • Thalassemia
  • Albinism,Wilson’s disease
  • Treacher collins syndrome: Have autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive or sporadic inheritance patterns due to mutation in various genes affecting facial bone and tissue development.

questions.text: Which of the options aids in the transportation of fatty acids through the inner mitochondria membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Carnitine

Explanation:

Carnitine shuttle system transports long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondrial matrix for β-oxidation.

It involves:

  • Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT-I): Converts fatty acyl-CoA to fatty acyl-carnitine.
  • Translocase: Moves fatty acyl-carnitine across the inner mitochondrial membrane.
  • Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II (CPT-II): Converts fatty acyl-carnitine back to fatty acyl-CoA inside the matrix.
  • Movement of fatty acids across inner mitochondrial membrane where they are oxidised to produce energy depends on carnitine.

Acyl carrier protein (Option A): Involved in movement of fatty acids within the cytosol, but not in the movement of fatty acids across mitochondrial membrane.

Lecithin-Cholesterol acyltransferase (Option C):

Involved in metabolism of phospholipids and cholesterol.

Albumin (Option D): Functions as carrier and aids in the transportation of numerous chemicals in the blood, including fatty acids, but not directly.

questions.text: What is the term for a single mutation in a nucleotide base pair that leads to formation of termination codon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nonsense mutation

Explanation:

Nonsense mutation leading to premature termination of the protein, and destroying the functional activity.

 

Based on the Effects on Amino acid sequence

Silent Mutation (Option D)

Missense Mutation (Option A)

Nonsense Mutation (Option B)
  • Mutation may change the codon for one amino acid to a synonym for the same amino acid.
  • It has no effect on the phenotype.
  • Degeneracy of the code.
  • Different amino acid is incorporated due to change in the nucleotide sequence.
  • It can be acceptable, partially acceptable, and unacceptable.
  • Codon for an amino acid is mutated to a termination codon (UAA or UGA or UAG) causing premature termination of translation.

Stop mutation (Option C): Refers to premature termination of protein synthesis, but rarely used in genetics.

questions.text: Which enzyme deficiency could potentially be the cause of exercise intolerance and cramps in adolescent male patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myophosphorylase

Explanation:

McArdle disease, or myophosphorylase deficiency, affects glycogen utilization for energy.

  • Type 5 Glycogen storage disorder.
  • Myophosphorylase converts glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in muscle tissue.
  • Insufficient enzyme activity leads to exercise intolerance due impaired glycogen breakdown.
  • Symptoms include muscle cramps, stiffness, and weakness during exertion, alleviated

Hexokinase (Option B): Catalyzes glucose to glucose-6-phosphate conversion in glycolysis.Insufficiency affects glucose uptake, leading to exhaustion and weakness, not exercise intolerance or cramps.

Glucose-6-phosphatase (Option C): Converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose in gluconeogenesis.Deficiency causes hypoglycemia, not exercise intolerance.

Hepatic glycogen phosphorylase (Option D): Breaks down liver glycogen. Deficiency affects liver, not causing exercise intolerance or cramps.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activities can be estimated in red blood cells to diagnose vitamin B2 deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Glutathione reductase

Explanation:

In order to measure vitamin B2 levels, glutathione reductase activity in red blood cells can be monitored.

  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), a coenzyme generated from vitamin B2, is needed as a cofactor for the enzyme glutathione reductase inorder for it to work properly.
  • Low FAD levels are caused by a vitamin B2 deficiency, and this lowers glutathione reductase activity.

Vitamin deficiencies estimation by enzymes in RBC:

  • Transketolase - Vit B1
  • Kynureninase - Vit B6
  • Pyurvate dehydrogenase - Vit C

questions.text: Identify the mask in the image used for patients with COVID-19 infection.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Non-rebreathing mask

Explanation:

  • The Non-rebreathing mask (NRBM) is preferred for oxygen delivery in patients with COVID-19 infection requiring high concentrations of oxygen without risking aerosol generation.
  • This mask delivers a high concentration of oxygen (60–90%) by using a one-way valve and a reservoir bag.
  • It minimizes the rebreathing of exhaled air and limits aerosol dispersion, making it suitable for respiratory infections like COVID-19.

Venturi mask (Option A): Delivers precise oxygen concentrations (24–50%) and is commonly used for COPD patients. However, it is not suitable for high oxygen demands in severe COVID-19 cases.

Hudson mask (Option B): Delivers 40–60% oxygen but lacks a reservoir bag for higher concentrations and does not effectively prevent aerosol generation.

Nebuliser (Option C): Used to administer aerosolized medications, but it can increase the risk of aerosol generation, making it less suitable for infectious respiratory conditions.

The Non-rebreathing mask is the most appropriate for patients with severe COVID-19 requiring high-flow oxygen.

questions.text: What is the cause of following condition due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin A

Explanation:

This disorder is known as Conjunctival xerosis caused by vitamin A deficiency where the conjunctiva becomes dry, rough and irritating

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.

Skin manifestations of vit A deficiency:

  • Phrynoderma: Follicular hyperkeratosis

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ulnar nerve

Explanation:

  • Neuromuscular monitoring during anesthesia involves assessing the function of peripheral nerves to evaluate the degree of neuromuscular blockade.
  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for neuromuscular monitoring due to its accessibility and reliability.
  • The adductor pollicis muscle, innervated by the ulnar nerve, is typically monitored.
  • It provides a clear and reliable response to nerve stimulation, making it ideal for assessing neuromuscular function.

Median nerve (Option B): Stimulating the median nerve usually elicits thumb flexion, but it is less commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring as it’s not as reliable for blockade assessment.

Radial nerve (Option C): While the radial nerve controls wrist and finger extension, it is less commonly monitored because it’s harder to standardize the response.

Metacarpal nerve (Option D): This is not typically used for neuromuscular monitoring as it does not provide consistent or reliable muscle response for assessing blockade.

questions.text: What is the enzyme defect if a child with anemia, thrombocytopenia, bony pain and hepatosplenomegaly shows a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance on light microscopy of bone marrow aspirate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Beta- glucosidase

Explanation:

Gaucher disease, caused by a defect in beta- glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase), leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide (glucocerebroside) within macrophages.

  • Lysosomal storage disorder of autosomal recessive inheritance.
  • These macrophages, engorged with glucosylceramide, are known as Gaucher cells.
  • The accumulation affects the bone marrow and spleen, leading to anaemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Gaucher cells have characteristic appearance of crumbled tissue paper look due to accumulation of glucosylceramide in the cytoplasm of macrophages, forming fibril like structures.

Sphingomyelinase (Option B): Niemann-Pick disease results from a deficiency in sphingomyelinase.Its bone marrow findings involve foamy histiocytes with lipid-filled cytoplasm.

Hexosaminidase (Option C): Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by hexosaminidase deficiency, doesn't typically cause anemia, thrombocytopenia, or bone pain.Its bone marrow findings may show an onion-skin appearance.

Glucose 6-phosphatase (Option D): Von Gierke disease, due to glucose-phosphatase deficiency, may lead to hepatosplenomegaly and bone pain but not anemia or thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: According to triage, which of the following categories of patients comes under green?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ambulatory patients

Explanation:

  • In triage, patients are categorised based on the urgency of their medical needs, and the green category is for ambulatory patients, meaning those who are able to walk and have non-life-threatening injuries.
     

Colour

Priority

Medical Need

Clinical Status

Examples

Red

 

First

Immediate

Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
  • Severe facial trauma
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Profuse external bleeding
  • Haemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed
  • Extradural haematomas

Yellow

 

Second

Urgent

Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Ruptured abdominal viscus
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries

Green

 

Third

Non-Urgent

Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
  • Simple fractures
  • Sprains
  • Minor lacerations

Black

Last

Unsalvageable

Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help.
  • Severe brain damage
  • Very extensive burns
  • Major disruption/ loss of chest or abdominal wall structures


Moderate priority (Option B) can be classified as yellow in triage. These patients have conditions that are serious but not immediately life-threatening. They may require medical attention, but they can still wait for a period without their condition deteriorating rapidly.

High priority (Option C) is generally categorised as red in triage, indicating immediate care is required. These patients have life-threatening injuries or conditions and need immediate medical intervention.

Dead patients (Option D) are not part of the triage process, as they are not classified for further care. Triage prioritises patients based on the severity of their condition to allocate resources effectively, focusing on those who can be saved or treated.

questions.text: Which of the following substances inhibits cytochrome complex IV, a component of the electron transport chain responsible for ATP synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cyanide

Explanation:

Cyanide:

  • Powerful inhibitor of cytochrome complex IV is cyanide.
  • It attaches to the enzyme's active site and stops the enzyme from transferring electrons to oxygen.
  • Due to the blockage of the electron transport chain, reducing agents like NADH and FADH2 begin to accumulate.
  • The last enzyme complex in the electron transport chain is cytochrome complex IV, also known as cytochrome c oxidase.
  • When oxygen and protons are combined to form water, it receives electrons from cytochrome c.
  • The ATP synthase uses the proton gradient created by this mechanism to manufacture ATP.

inhibitor of Complex IV" data-author="" data-hash="11566" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/gRl6KbrfKeBvfYctyVtv1746256201.png" />

Carbon dioxide (Option B): Does not inhibit cytochrome complex IV.Bicarbonate ions, which are the predominant type of carbon dioxide carried in the blood, do not directly interact with the electron transport chain.

Oligomycin (Option C): Cytochrome complex IV is not inhibited by oligomycin.It is an ATP synthase inhibitor that attaches to the Fo subunit of ATP synthase and stops protons from passing through the enzyme, hence preventing the production of ATP.

Ouabain (Option D): Na/K ATPase pump, which keeps the electrochemical gradient across the plasma membrane of cell is inhibited by cardiac glycoside.

questions.text: Microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brugia malayi

Explanation:

Wuchereria bancrofti is the organism responsible for causing lymphatic filariasis. The characteristic finding on microscopy for Wuchereria bancrofti is a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail.

Species

Wuchereria bancrofti (Option A)

Nuclei form continuous rows in the tip of the tail

Nuclei extend to the tip of the tail

Nuclei do not extend to the tip of the tail

Nuclei do not extend to the tip of the tail

Sheath

Sheathed

Unsheathed

Periodicity

Nocturnal

Nocturnal

Nonperiodic

Culex, Anopheles, Aedes

Chrysops spp.

Culicoides

Brugia timori:

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines with which strain could have prevented it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 17D

Explanation:

Yellow fever

Agent and Vector
  • Flavivirus transmitted primarily by mosquitoes
    • Aedes Mosquito (in urban settings)
    • Haemagogus (in jungle or forested areas)

Hosts
  • Primarily monkeys (Reservoir hosts)
  • Humans are (Incidental hosts) and can develop severe disease.

Environmental Features
  • Found in tropical and subtropical areas of Africa and South America, where mosquito vectors are prevalent.
  • Transmission occurs primarily in forested or jungle areas.
  • Typical Conditions:
  • Temperature: 24-36’C
  • Humidity: >60%

Clinical Presentation
  • Initial symptoms (acute phase, 3-6 days post-infection): fever, chills, headache, backache, muscle aches, loss of appetite.
  • Severe cases (toxic phase): jaundice, bleeding, organ dysfunction (liver, kidney).

Diagnosis
  • Based on clinical signs
  • Travel history to endemic areas
  • Confirmed by detection of YFV RNA or specific antibodies (IgM and IgG) in blood samples.

Types
  • Live-attenuated vaccine (17D strain)
  • Diluent: lyophilized (freeze-dried) powder with saline solution.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Nakayama Strain (Option B) is used for the preparation of the formalin-inactivated mouse brain vaccine against Japanese encephalitis.

Weigl’s Strain (Option C)is a type of typhus vaccine against R. prowazekii.

Jeryl Lynn Strain (Option D) is used for the preparation of the live virus vaccine against mumps.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Serous otitis media

  • Based on the otoscopy finding of a retracted and opaque tympanic membrane with fluid visible behind it, the foremost likely diagnosis is serous otitis media.

 

Serous Otitis Media (SOM):

 

Category

Details

Symptoms

 
  • Hearing Loss: Conductive, mild to moderate (20-40 dB), gradual onset, may fluctuate; children may not complain, but parents may notice difficulties in hearing.
  • Delayed/Defective Speech
  • Mild Earaches
  • Fullness in Ear.

Signs

 
  • Tympanic Membrane Appearance: Dull, opaque, possibly yellow, grey, or bluish; absence of the usual light reflex.
  • Visible Fluid/Bubbles: Air-fluid levels or bubbles visible behind the eardrum.
  • Retracted Tympanic Membrane: Negative middle ear pressure causing eardrum retraction, with the malleus handle appearing shortened or horizontal.
  • Reduced Tympanic Membrane Mobility.

 

Diagnostic Tests for SOM:

Test

Description

Rinne Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), bone conduction is better than air conduction (negative Rinne test).

Weber Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), the sound is louder in the affected ear when the tuning fork is placed on the forehead.

Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test
  • Both patient and examiner hear the tuning fork for a similar duration when placed on the mastoid bone (ear canals plugged) in conductive hearing loss (SOM). (Bone conduction not impaired)

Schwabach's Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), the patient hears the tuning fork for a longer duration than the examiner when placed on the mastoid bone (ear canals not plugged).

Pneumatic Otoscopy
  • Visualizes eardrum movement with air pressure changes; reduced/absent movement indicates fluid presence.

Impedance audiometry
  • Measures eardrum movement; typically shows a flat/dome-shaped curve with negative pressure, indicating reduced compliance.

Audiometry
  • Conductive hearing loss (20-40 dB).
  • Sometimes, associated sensorineural hearing loss (d/t fluid on the round window membrane.

X-ray/CT Scan of Temporal Bone
  • May show mastoid air cell clouding due to fluid

Incorrect Options:

Myringitis bullosa (Option A):

  • This is often an uncommon condition where fluid-filled blisters develop on the tympanic membrane causing pain and hearing loss.
  • In any case, the otoscopy finding within the given scenario does not describe to have any blisters or erythema.

 

Acute otitis media (Option C):

  • Typically a bacterial infection of the middle ear causing pain, fever, and bulging of the tympanic membrane.
  • The otoscopy finding within the given scenario does not describe any bulging or signs of infection.

 

Pneumo tympanum (Option D):

  • Typically the presence of air in the middle ear causes a bulging and retracted tympanic membrane.
  • It is more often than not seen after a sudden change in pressure such as diving or a blast injury.
  • The otoscopy finding within the given scenario does not describe any bulging or increased air space within the middle ear.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a known case of hypertension presented with multiple episodes of hematuria and loin pain. His elder brother passed away due to a stroke at the age of 40. The CT abdomen is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of hematuria, loin pain, and a family history of early stroke is highly suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).
  • The presence of cysts in the CT scan would be consistent with this diagnosis.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Definition

Characterised by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys.

Inheritance
  • Autosomal Dominant
  • Involvement of chromosome 16 (PKD1) and 4 (PKD2)
  • Abnormal protein-Polycystin
  • Both kidneys are replaced by multiple cysts

Clinical Features (Intrarenal)
  • Most common manifestation is hypertension
  • Polyuria, Nocturia, Hematuria
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Chronic renal failure (Usually in the 5th to 6th decade)
  • Any compression in the pelvicalyceal system will lead to HIS (Hydronephrosis; Infection; Stone) → Hematuria

Clinical Features (Extrarenal)
  • Polycystic Liver Disease (Most common)
  • Cyst in Ovary, Pancreas, Spleen Berry Aneurysm
  • Mitral Valve prolapse
  • The most common cause of death is cardiovascular Disorders

Investigations
  • Investigation of choice: CECT
  • Ultrasound: Confirms the presence of cysts
  • IVP (Intravenous Pyelogram):
    • Spider leg/Bell-shaped appearance
    • Bubble appearance
    • Swiss-cheese appearance
  • Blood urea and serum creatinine: Elevated
  • Urine: Shows low specific gravity

Management
  • Wait and watch initially. Surgical intervention is required only after cysts get overdistended, causing pain, hemorrhage, and infection.
  • Gold Standard: Renal Transplantation
  • Rovsing's Operation: Deroofing of Cyst in ADPKD. The kidney is exposed. The cyst is opened. The fluid is evacuated.
  • US-guided aspiration & Laparoscopic aspiration is commonly done as a simpler approach.
  • Once renal failure sets in, initial hemodialysis followed by bilateral nephrectomy is done, and later renal transplantation can be planned


Renal cell carcinoma (Option A) can present with hematuria as a common feature; it typically presents with a mass or a solitary tumour, not multiple cysts on CT.

Tuberculosis of the kidney (Option C) usually presents with symptoms like hematuria, dysuria, fever, and flank pain and would not show cystic lesions on CT. Putty kidney refers to the appearance of the kidney in advanced renal tuberculosis, characterised by a pale, nodular surface due to caseous necrosis.

Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (Option D) typically presents in childhood with liver involvement and more severe kidney dysfunction, whereas the patient's age and presentation point more toward ADPKD.

questions.text: A militant presents with fever and a rash that started on the trunk first and spread to the extremities, sparing palms and soles. On examination, a louse is noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rickettsia prowazekii

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a febrile patient with rash sparing palms and soles and lice infestation is suggestive of epidemic typhus, which is caused by the bacterium Rickettsia prowazekii.

Epidemic typhus

Causative agent

Rickettsia prowazekii (It is the only rickettsial disease that can occur as an epidemic)

Vector

Louse

Pathophysiology
  • It occurs during conditions favourable to human body lice infestation such as in refugee and famine camps.(crowding, infrequent bathing)
  • The cycle starts with R.prowazekii circulating in a patient’s blood during an acute febrile infection.
  • After 5 to 10 days of incubation, large numbers of rickettsiae appear in its infective faeces.
  • Since the louse defecates when it feeds, the organisms can be rubbed into the louse bite wounds when the host scratches the site.
  • Dried louse faeces are also infectious through the mucous membranes of the eye or respiratory tract. The louse dies of its infection in 1 to 3 weeks.
  • Most of Rickettsiae, including Rickettsia prowazekii, shows tropism for vascular endothelium.
  • They multiply in the endothelial cells, leading to increased vascular permeability, hypovolemia, and hypotension.
  • Focal areas of endothelial proliferation cause the rash and petechial lesions, perivascular infiltration that leads to thrombosis, and leakage of red blood cells into the surrounding tissues.

Clinical features

  • Fever, headache, and rash begin 1 to 2 weeks after the bite.
  • In the majority of cases, a maculopapular rash appears first on the trunk and then spreads centrifugally to the extremities, sparing the palms and soles.
  • Eschar is absent at the site of entry.
  • Headache, malaise, and myalgia are prominent components of the illness.
  • Complications include myocarditis and central nervous system dysfunction.
  • In untreated disease, the fatality rate increases with age as much as 60%.

Investigations

  • The diagnostic test of choice is serology i.e. rise in antibody titre.
  • Weil-Felix test showing both OX 19+ and OX 2+.

Treatment

  • Treatment with doxycycline is effective.
  • Louse control is the best means of prevention and is particularly important in controlling epidemics.
  • No effective vaccine is available.

Endemic typhus and Rickettsia typhi (Option A): Although the clinical features and Weil Felix test are similar to those of epidemic typhus, it does not occur as an epidemic. The vector involved is rat flea.

Rickettsial pox and Rickettsia akari (Option C): is a benign rickettsial illness caused by Rickettsia akari and transmitted by a rodent mite. Distinguishing feature of the disease is an eschar at the site of the bite, later followed by fever and a vesicular rash distributed randomly sparing the palms and soles.

Rickettsia conorii (Option D) causes Indian tick typus, which is typically transmitted to humans through the bites of infected ticks. The clinical presentation includes fever, headache, myalgias, and a maculopapular rash that typically starts on the extremities and spreads to the trunk. The palms and soles may be involved in some cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man complained of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fistula in ano

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years suggests fistula in ano.
  • A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Fistula in ano

Causes
  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).


Pilonidal sinus (Option A) is found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair; it is not located typically around the anus.

 

Carbuncle (Option B) is a skin infection consisting of several boils that form a connected area of infection. It typically presents as a painful, swollen area of the skin, not as chronic drainage around the anus.

 

Boil (Option C) or furuncle is a perifollicular abscess that typically has an erythematous, indurated, tender nodule with a pus point. While it can present near the anus, the chronic nature and recurrent discharge suggest a fistula, not a boil.

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is observed. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Trichophyton rubrum

Explanation:

Dermatophyte

Macroscopic Appearance

Microscopic Appearance

T. rubrum

Velvety, red pigment on reverse

Microconidia—tear drop shaped, plenty

Macroconidia—few, long, pencil-shaped

T. mentagrophytes (Option A)

White to tan, powdery, pigment variable

Microconidia—numerous, round to pyriform

Macroconidia—cigar-shaped

Spiral hyphae seen

T. schoenleinii (Option C)

Smooth, waxy

Microconidia and macroconidia—rare or absent

Chlamydospores seen

Hyphae—hyphal swelling and favic chandelier seen

T. violaceum (Option D)

Slow growing, waxy, violet pigment on reverse

Microconidia and macroconidia—rare or absent

Distorted hyphae seen

Chlamydospores seen

M. canis

Cottony, orange pigment on reverse

Macroconidia—abundant, thick-walled, spiny, spindle-shaped, up to 15 septa, pointed ends

Microconidia—rare

E. floccosum

Powdery, folded, yellowish-green

Macroconidia—club or clavate-shaped in clusters, 4–6 septa

Microconidia—absent

questions.text: Identify the structure given in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Incus

  • The structure given within the picture is the Incus, also known as the anvil. It is one of the three ossicles of the center ear, alongside the malleus and stapes.
  • The incus is found between the malleus and stapes and is associated to them by synovial joints.

Incorrect Options :

Malleus (Option A): The malleus, too known as the hammer, is the primary of the three ossicles and is attached to the eardrum.

Stapes (Option C): The stapes, moreover known as the stirrup, is the last of the three ossicles and is attached to the oval window of the inner ear.

Vomer (Option D): The vomer may be a bone within the cranium that forms part of the nasal septum.

questions.text: What is the most frequently occurring location for an intraperitoneal abscess to develop?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subhepatic

Explanation:

  • The most common site for an intraperitoneal abscess to develop is the subhepatic area, typically located beneath the liver.
  • This location is prone to abscess formation due to its proximity to the biliary system and gastrointestinal tract, where infections can easily spread.

Most common site of intraperitoneal abscess:

  • In recumbent or lying down position: Morrison pouch/subhepatic space
  • In upright posture: Pelvis (Pouch of Douglas)
  • MC site (Overall): Pelvis (Pouch of Douglas)


Suprahepatic (Option A) refers to the area above the liver. While abscesses like subphrenic abscesses can occasionally form in this region, it is not the most common site for intraperitoneal abscesses.

Left lobe of the liver (Option C) is not the most common location for general intraperitoneal abscess formation.

Left side below the diaphragm (Option D) is not as commonly associated with intraperitoneal abscesses as the subhepatic space. The left side of the diaphragm area can have abscesses like subphrenic abscesses.

questions.text: A female patient presents with thick, curdy white vaginal secretions. Microscopic examination of a vaginal scraping shows budding yeast and pseudohyphae. Which of the following media can be utilized to determine the probable species of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CHROM agar

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of thick white vaginal secretions and microscopic examination showing pseudohyphae and yeast-like organisms are suggestive candidiasis.

Laboratory diagnosis of candida

Germ tube test
  • The germ tube test is a specific diagnostic test for Candida albicans.
  • Germ tube also seen in candida dubliniensis
  • Candida tropicalis- pseudo germ tube formation

 

Also known as Reynolds Braude Phenomenon

Candida + Human serum → Incubation → Big tube-like structure (Pseudohyphae).

 

Gram stain

Yeast-like organism - Has both buds and pseudohyphae.

 

SDA Culture media test (Option D)

Colonies are creamy white, smooth and with a yeasty odor

Corn meal agar test

 

Forms chlamydospores on corn meal agar cultures at 20°C -identified by double wall configuration.

 

Chrom agar test (Option C)

Colour differentiation test

Each type of organism is seen differently

Bird seed Agar (Option A) It is a selective medium used to grow Cryptococcus neoformans, a fungus that causes cryptococcosis, a potentially fatal infection of the central nervous system.

Brain Heart Infusion Agar (Option B) is a nutrient-rich medium used to grow fastidious microorganisms like Bacteroides and actinomyces israelii.

Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (Option D) is a general-purpose medium used to grow a variety of fungi. While it is commonly used to isolate Candida species, it is not differential and cannot differentiate between different species of Candida.

questions.text: A 60-year-old post-COVID male patient came with complaints of one-sided facial swelling, headache, and nasal sinus congestion. He is diabetic and it is uncontrolled. On examination black lesions on the nasal bridge and upper inside of the mouth were observed. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Biopsy with histopathologic examination

  • The patient presents with one-sided facial pain with nasal and oral black mass, which can be a sign of Mucormycosis.
  • Biopsy with histopathologic examination is gold standard for diagnosis.

Mucormycosis

Description

A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction.

Characteristic Findings

Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI.

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment)
  • Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues.

Diagnosis
  • Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing.
  • Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features.

Imaging
  • CT: Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement.
  • CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction.
  • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain.

Treatment

Antifungal Therapy:

  • Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day.
  • Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues.
  • Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required.

Incorrect Options:

X-ray (Option A):

  • X-rays are not the preferred imaging modality for visualizing fungal invasion of the sinuses. Imaging modalities like CT or MRI is preferred.

Serum ferritin (Option C):

  • Though patients with an iron overload are found to be more susceptible to post-COVID mucormycosis, serum ferritin is not an indicative test for Mucormycosis.

HbA1c (Option D):

  • HbA1c is a medical test used to measure long-term blood glucose control, and it is commonly used to screen for diabetes. Although poorly managed diabetes can increase the chances of developing Mucormycosis, HbA1c is not a specific test for Mucormycosis, and it is unlikely to be helpful in confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely to be affected in a patient who complains of an inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) Facial nerve:

  • The presentation of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth is indicative of facial nerve palsy or Bell's palsy, which is caused by the dysfunction of the facial nerve.
  • The facial nerve innervates the muscles of facial expression, including those involved in closing the eye, controlling the point of the mouth, and creating saliva.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Trigeminal nerve (Option B):

  • The trigeminal nerve innervates the muscles of mastication and is responsible for sensation of the face.
  • Dysfunction of this nerve can cause facial numbness, trouble chewing, and jaw weakness, but it would not cause the particular indications specified within the question.

Oculomotor nerve (Option C):

  • The oculomotor nerve is dependable for innervating the muscles of the eye, including those involved in controlling the size of the pupil and the position of the eyelid.
  • Dysfunction of this nerve can cause drooping of the eyelid and double vision, but it would not cause the other side effects specified within the question.

Glossopharyngeal nerve (Option D):

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve is dependable for innervating the tongue and pharynx and is involved in the taste sensation of the posterior one third.
  • Dysfunction of this nerve can cause trouble swallowing and loss of taste sensation, but it would not cause the specific side effects said within the question.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus, and fever. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Leptospirosis

Explanation:

Leptospirosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with high fever, severe headache, calf muscle pain, conjunctival suffusion,icterus and abdominal pain.

Leptospirosis

Agent
  • Leptospira interrogans (zoonotic bacteria)

Reservoir
  • Rodents (Ratus norvegicus, Mus musculus) and domestic animals

Source
  • Direct contact or contamination with excreta, urine of infected animals.

At risk individuals
  • Males 20-45 years (most common)
  • Urine-contaminated mud(Soil) or water
    • Sports: rafting, fishing and swimming
    • Rice field workers, sewer workers, animal handlers

Mode of transmission
  • Direct contact: Urine through skin abrasion
  • Indirect contact: Contact of broken skin with soil, water, vegetation
  • Droplet infection: Inhalation while milking cows.

Incubation
  • 4-20 days

Clinical features:
  • Fever with chills
  • Headache & retro-orbital pain
  • Conjunctival suffusion
  • Myalgia
  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
  • Non-specific rash

 

  • Anicteric leptospirosis:
  • Milder form
  • Pulmonary manifestations are primary concern
  • Icteric leptospirosis:
  • More severe form
  • Jaundice, fever, myalgia hypotension,
  • Circulatory failure

Diagnosis
  • Dark Field examination: Thin and motile spirochete.
  • IgM ELISA: High sensitivity
  • Labs: Elevated liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, thrombocytopenia

Chikungunya (Option B) presents with fever, joint pain, headache, muscle pain, joint swelling, and rash. While fever is a common symptom in both leptospirosis and chikungunya.

Dengue hemorrhagic fever (Option C) presents with fever, headache, joint and muscle pain, and rash. Dengue hemorrhagic fever is a severe form of the disease that can lead to bleeding, shock, and death.

Encephalopathy caused by hepatitis A (Option D) presents with fever, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, dark urine, and jaundice.

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice-water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) GM1 ganglioside receptor

Explanation:

Cholera toxin binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells. Once internalized, the A subunit of the toxin activates adenylate cyclase, leading to an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. Elevated cAMP disrupts ion transport, causing a significant efflux of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in profuse watery diarrhea.

Pathogenesis

  • Natural Host: Only humans.
  • Transmission: Orally through contaminated water or food.
  • Incubation Period: 1-5 days.

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection.

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea. (Option B)
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. (Option C)

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

Complications

  • Muscular Cramps
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Cardiac Arrhythmias
  • Paralytic Ileus

Increases cyclic GMP levels in intestinal cells Heat-stable toxin (ST) of E.coli increases intracellular cGMP levels causing watery diarrhea.

Cerebroganglioside (Option A) Not involved in cholera pathogenesis; these gangliosides are primarily associated with neural tissues and lysosomal storage diseases.

GM2 ganglioside receptor (Option B) this receptor is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, not cholera toxin activity.

Sphingomyelin (Option D)is a structural component of cell membranes and not a receptor for cholera toxin. It plays a role in lipid metabolism and is implicated in Niemann-Pick disease.

questions.text: A patient with cisplatin-induced nausea and vomiting was managed with an antiemetic, after which he developed symptoms like acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following drugs would have caused these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metoclopramide

Explanation:

  • Metoclopramide is an antiemetic often used to treat nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy, and it is to have caused the described symptoms in the given scenario.
  • It can induce extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) due to its central blockade of dopamine receptors, particularly D2 receptors in the basal ganglia.
  • This disruption in dopamine signalling can lead to dystonia, tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia, with characteristic features including grimacing and abnormal posturing.
  • EPS risk increases with higher doses or in susceptible individuals, necessitating close monitoring and consideration of alternative therapies in affected patients, with symptomatic management involving discontinuation of metoclopramide and, if necessary, the use of anticholinergic agents or benzodiazepines.

Incorrect Options:

Odansetron (Option A) does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms. It primarily works on serotonin receptors and is not associated with the movement side effects of dopamine antagonists.

Meclizine (Option C) is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties. It is commonly used for nausea and dizziness, especially in vertigo, and it is not associated with extrapyramidal side effects.

Scopolamine (Option D) is an anticholinergic drug used for motion sickness and nausea, and it is not associated with extrapyramidal side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Toxin assay

Explanation:

Clostridium difficile diagnosis:

Diagnosis

Colonoscopy
  • Examination of the colon whitish-yellow plaques on the colonic mucosa known as microabscesses.
  • Although it is highly specific, it is not as sensitive as ELISA, hence it is not considered the Gold standard for diagnosis. (Option D ruled out)

 

Culture
  • Stool samples cultured on selective media to identify C. difficile; less sensitive than toxin detection. (Option A ruled out)

Toxin Detection
  • ELISA: Detects toxins A and/or B in stool samples, the gold standard (Option B).
  • Cell Culture: Toxins produce characteristic effects on Hep-2 or human diploid cell cultures, neutralized by C. sordellii antitoxin.

Molecular Methods
  • PCR: Detects genes coding for toxins A and B in stool samples.

Histopathology
  • This can be performed with hematoxylin and eosin stains
  • Highly specific but low sensitivity

Treatment

Antibiotic Discontinuation
  • Stop the antibiotic suspected of contributing to the infection.

Antibiotic Therapy
  • Oral vancomycin or metronidazole.
  • Severe cases: Combination of oral vancomycin, intravenous metronidazole, and rectal vancomycin enemas.

Prevention

Antibiotic Stewardship
  • Limit the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin, ampicillin, and fluoroquinolones; prevent disruption of normal gut flora.

Infection Control Measures
  • Meticulous hand hygiene and contact precautions in healthcare settings.

Recent Treatment Option

Fecal Transplants
  • Replenishing gut flora with donated faeces from screened healthy donor

 

GDH assay (Option C) It is present in both toxigenic and non-toxigenic strains, therefore called as C. difficile common antigen.

questions.text: A truck driver with diabetes visits you complaining of cough and difficulty breathing. Pneumonia has been diagnosed, and histopathological examination indicates the presence of nonseptate hyphae branching at wide angles. What is the probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mucor

Explanation:

The presence of nonseptate hyphae that branch at wide angles on histopathological examination is characteristic of a Mucor fungal infection, most commonly caused by Mucor or Rhizopus species.

Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus

Absidia Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained)

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

 

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

​​​​​​a. ​

b.

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option A) is a capsulated yeast that causes cryptococcal meningitis in immunocompromised individuals.

Candida (Option C) is a genus of yeasts that can cause a range of infections involving skin, mucosa, and organs.

Aspergillus (Option D) Aspergillosis is caused by aspergillus, a septate fungi branching at less than 45°, commonly seen in patients on prolonged steroid use.

questions.text: A woman who was prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic presents with recurrent diarrhea. Regarding Clostridium difficile infection, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
Pseudomembrane is a layer of inflammatory cells and debris

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) No risk of fulminant infection

Explanation:

Clostridium difficile can lead to fulminant colitis characterized by hypotension or shock, ileus, and megacolon.

Pseudomembranous Colitis:

 

Definition
  • Inflammatory condition of the colon caused by Clostridium difficile toxin production, leading to pseudomembrane formation on the colonic mucosa.

Etiology
  • Primarily caused by C. difficile infection, usually after broad-spectrum antibiotic use (e.g., clindamycin, fluoroquinolones, cephalosporins).

Risk Factors
  • Recent antibiotic use
  • Hospitalization
  • Elderly patients
  • Immunosuppression (e.g., chemotherapy, organ transplant)
  • Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs)

Pathogenesis
  • C. difficile produces Toxin A (enterotoxin) and Toxin B (cytotoxin), leading to mucosal damage, inflammation, and pseudomembrane formation.

Clinical Features
  • Watery diarrhea (non-bloody)
  • Abdominal pain and cramping
  • Fever
  • Leukocytosis
  • Severe cases: Toxic megacolon, perforation, septic shock

Endoscopic Findings
  • Yellow-white plaques on the colonic mucosa (pseudomembranes)
  • Patchy or confluent distribution

Diagnosis
  • Stool toxin assay (Toxin A & B ELISA or PCR) - Gold standard.
  • Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) assay
  • Colonoscopy/Sigmoidoscopy

Treatment
  • First-line: Oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin
  • Alternative: Oral metronidazole
  • Severe/Recurrent cases: Fecal microbiota transplantation

Complications
  • Fulminant colitis
  • Toxic megacolon
  • Intestinal perforation
  • Sepsis & Multi-organ failure

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Heimlich's maneuver.

  • It is a first-aid procedure utilized to dislodge an object from a person's windpipe when they are choking.
  • It includes standing behind the choking individual and applying powerful upward pressure on the abdomen, below the ribcage and above the umbilicus, to make sufficient pressure to dislodge the object.

 

Incorrect Options:

Back slap (Option B):

  • Back slapping is a first-aid strategy utilized for infants who are choking.
  • It includes the rescuer placing the newborn child face down on their forearm and delivering firm slaps to the infant's back between the shoulder blades.
  • Typically done to unstick the object from the infant's airway. However, this procedure isn't recommended for adults because it can cause harm.

 

Chest thrust (Option C):

  • Chest thrusts are a strategy utilized in CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation) to clear an obstructed airway when the casualty isn't breathing.
  • This strategy includes setting the casualty on their back and delivering forceful thrusts to the lower half of their breastbone, between the nipples. This will help dislodge the object from the airway and reestablish breathing, but it isn't fitting for a conscious choking casualty who is still able to breathe.

 

Blind insertion of finger (Option D):

  • Blind insertion of finger isn't suggested as a first-aid method for choking casualties because it can thrust the object forward into the windpipe, making the circumstance worse.
  • It can also cause harm to the victim's throat and airway. It is important to utilize appropriate first-aid methods such as the Heimlich maneuver or chest thrusts to dislodge the object from the airway.

questions.text: A young patient started to take a weight loss medication that acts by inhibiting fat absorption from food. After a few weeks, she developed increased menstrual bleeding and stool that sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamins is responsible for her deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin K

Explanation:

  • Vitamin K is essential for the activation of several vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors, such as clotting factors II, VII, IX and X. Hence, its deficiency can lead to bleeding disorders and easy bruising.
  • The weight loss medication described is most likely orlistat, which inhibits pancreatic lipase and prevents the absorption of dietary fat.
  • This reduction in fat absorption also impairs the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K), which can lead to deficiencies.
  • Stool that sticks to the pan suggests fat malabsorption, which is the most common side effect of orlistat.
  • Other side effects of Orlistat:
    • Hepatotoxicity
    • Increased risk of renal stones and oxalate nephropathy
    • High risk of Osteoporosis due to impaired absorption of calcium and vitamin D

Incorrect Options:

Vitamin E (Option A) is an antioxidant that helps protect cells from free radicals; it is not involved directly in blood clotting. Hence, it's unlikely to cause the symptoms mentioned above.

Vitamin B6 (Option C) is involved in a variety of metabolic processes in the body, including the production of red blood cells. However, it is not directly associated with bleeding, as described in this case.

Vitamin D (Option D) is not involved in bleeding, as mentioned in the scenario; it is responsible for bone health and immune function.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and facial swelling. An intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with branching at the right angle. Evidence of vascular invasion was present. What will be the drug of choice
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Amphotericin B

Explanation:

  • The presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching and evidence of vascular invasion suggests an infection caused by Rhizopus arrhizus, a group of fungi commonly responsible for mucormycosis.
  • The first-line treatment for mucormycosis is Amphotericin B (broad-spectrum antifungal).

Aspect

Amphotericin B

Mechanism of Action

Binds to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes, forming pores that disrupt membrane integrity, leading to leakage of cellular contents and fungal cell death.

Preparation
  • Conventional Amphotericin B (c-AMB)
  • Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC)
  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (L-AMB)

Use

Cryptococcal meningitis, mucormycosis, coccidioidal meningitis.

Adverse Effects
  • Nephrotoxicity: Most notable with conventional Amphotericin B (c-AMB); less with liposomal formulations
  • Fever, chills, and hypotension can be managed with pre-treatment (NSAIDs, antihistamines)
  • Anaemia (requires erythropoietin treatment)
  • Renal tubular acidosis leads to electrolyte imbalances (hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia)
  • Arachnoiditis, when used intrathecally

Incorrect Options:

Fluconazole (Option A) is a triazole antifungal that inhibits fungal ergosterol synthesis, but it is not effective against mucormycosis. It is effective against other fungal species like Candida, Cryptococcus, and Histoplasma.

Ketoconazole (Option C) is a broad-spectrum antifungal that is effective against many types of fungi like Candida species but not effective in treating mucormycosis.

Griseofulvin (Option D) is used to treat superficial fungal infections of skin, hair and nails, but it does not work against systemic or invasive fungal infections like mucormycosis.

questions.text: A male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) was prescribed theophylline. He noticed that his urine output had increased the following day. Which of the following receptors is this action of the drug-mediated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Adenosine A1

Explanation:

  • The increased urine output in this patient taking theophylline is mediated through the adenosine A1 receptors.
  • Theophylline is a nonselective adenosine receptor antagonist, which means it blocks the action of adenosine at all types of adenosine receptors, including A1, A2A, A2B and A3 receptors.
  • Theophylline's antagonism of the A1 adenosine receptor present in the kidney leads to increased glomerular filtration and diuresis.

Mechanism of action of Theophylline: (Mnemonic: PANCHI)

  • P- Phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitor
    • Inhibition of PDEs,➞ increased cellular cAMP and cyclic GMP levels ➞ Bronchodilation
    • Important PDE isoenzymes in smooth muscle relaxation include PDE3(primary action), PDE4, and PDE5.
  • A- Blocks Adenosine (A1) receptor
    • Adenosine induces bronchoconstriction in asthmatic patients by releasing histamine and leukotrienes.
    • Theophylline acts as an antagonist to adenosine receptors ➞ bronchodilation.
    • Blocking adenosine A1 receptors might lead to serious side effects, such as cardiac arrhythmias and seizures.
  • N- Inhibit NF kappa B
    • Theophylline inhibits the movement of the proinflammatory transcription factor NF-κB into the nucleus ➞ reducing the expression of inflammatory genes in asthma and COPD.
  • C- Calcium channel blockade
  • H- Causes Histone acetylation ➞ Decreases the inflammatory activity of IL-5 and IL-4.
  • I- Reduces the Inflammation.

Incorrect Options:

Interleukin - 10 (Option A) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that regulates immune responses, particularly by limiting inflammatory damage in the body. It is not directly involved in the mechanism of diuresis or in the action of theophylline.

Histone deacetylase (Option B) are enzymes that regulate gene expression by removing acetyl groups from histone proteins. It is not involved in the mechanism behind the diuretic effect of theophylline.

Beta 2 adrenergic receptors (Option D) are a type of adrenergic receptors found primarily in the lungs, where their activation causes bronchodilation; they are not present in the kidney.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause Pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Metformin

Explanation:

  • Metformin is a widely used antidiabetic medication (Biguanides) that works by decreasing hepatic glucose production and improving insulin sensitivity.
  • It is not associated with pulmonary fibrosis.

Side effects and complications of Metformin


 

Side effects
  • Nausea/Vomiting/Diarrhoea
  • Megaloblastic anaemia: reduces vitamin B12 absorption from GIT
  • Lactic acidosis
    • Avoid metformin in COPD, CHF, dehydration, and sepsis (hypoxia increases lactic acid production).









 

Complications
  • Renal failure is common with metformin use.
  • Plasma metformin levels are inversely related to GFR due to reduced drug clearance.
  • Current guidelines suggest the safe use of metformin when GFR is more than 30 mL/min/1.73 m2.
  • Management:
    • Assess renal function before starting metformin and monitor it annually.
    • Discontinue if serum creatinine >1.5 mg/dL or eGFR < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2.
    • Discontinue pre-emptively before radiographic procedures using contrast dyes (till 48 hours after the procedure until renal function normalises) and hospitalization for severe illness (sepsis).
    • Dose adjustment is needed for cationic drugs excreted by renal tubular secretion, such as cimetidine, furosemide, nifedipine, etc.
