    • If symptoms persist after 60 minutes, consider increasing the initial dose or switching drug classes.
    • Individualize treatment based on attack severity and patient response.
  • Indications for Preventive Treatment:
    • Consider patients with four or more migraine attacks per month or those unresponsive to abortive treatments.
  • Pharmacologic Options:
    • Beta Blockers: Propranolol (Option D ruled out), metoprolol.
    • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, venlafaxine.
    • Anticonvulsants: Topiramate (Option A ruled out), valproate.
    • CGRP Antagonists: Eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab.
    • Other Medications: Flunarizine (Option B ruled out), candesartan, melatonin.
  • Considerations:
    • Preventive treatments often take 2–12 weeks to show effect.
    • Side effects vary; some medications require careful monitoring (e.g., weight gain with certain antidepressants).
    • Neuromodulation (sTMS) is also FDA-approved for prevention.
  • Patient Management:
    • Start with low doses and gradually increase.
    • Monitor effectiveness and side effects.
    • After stabilization, taper off medication after approximately six months to assess ongoing need.

Severity Classification of Migraine:

  • Migraine severity can be assessed using tools like the Migraine Disability Assessment Scale (MIDAS), which categorizes migraines as follows:
    • Grade 1: Little or no disability
    • Grade 2: Mild disability
    • Grade 3: Moderate disability
    • Grade 4: Serious disability

Acute Treatment (Abortive Therapy)

  1. Mild to Moderate Migraine (Grades 1-2)
    • Over-the-Counter Pain Relievers: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen or naproxen.
    • Triptans: Medications like sumatriptan or rizatriptan are effective for moderate migraines and should be taken at the onset of symptoms.
  2. Moderate to Severe Migraine (Grade 3-4)
    • Triptans: Higher doses or different formulations (e.g., nasal sprays, injections) may be necessary.
    • Dihydroergotamine: Effective for longer-lasting migraines; available as a nasal spray or injection.
    • Gepants: Ubrogepant and Rimegepant are newer oral medications that can relieve pain and associated symptoms like nausea.
    • Lasmiditan: An oral medication that can help with pain relief but may cause sedation.
  3. Status Migrainosus (Severe, prolonged attacks lasting over 72 hours)
    • Requires immediate medical attention.
    • Treatment may include intravenous fluids, anti-nausea medications, and possibly corticosteroids or stronger analgesics in a hospital setting.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be seen due to the rupture of a saccular aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subarachnoid hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • The most common consequence of the rupture of a saccular aneurysm is subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), which is a life-threatening emergency.
  • A saccular aneurysm, also known as a berry aneurysm, is a small, bulging outpouching of a blood vessel at branching points of cerebral arteries.
  • These aneurysms are prone to rupture, and when they do, the blood leaks into the subarachnoid space which lies between the arachnoid and pia mater

 

Subdural haemorrhage (Option A) occurs due to the rupture of veins that bridge the subdural space, often from trauma. It is not associated with the rupture of an aneurysm.

Intracerebral hemorrhage (Option C) refers to bleeding within the brain tissue itself. It happens due to the rupture of arteries within brain parenchyma, mostly due to hypertension or trauma, not directly from a saccular aneurysm rupture.

Hydrocephalus (Option D) is an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the brain, leading to increased intracranial pressure. It can happen due to various factors, but it is not the immediate consequence of an aneurysm rupture itself.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby presented with hypsarrhythmia with salaam spells. The drug of choice is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ACTH

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario describes a 10-month-old baby with hypsarrhythmia and salaam seizures, which are characteristic of infantile spasms.
  • The first-line treatment for infantile spasms, in the case of non-tuberous sclerosis, is ACTH.
  • It is a potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive agent and works by reducing the excessive brain activity that leads to spasms.

Epileptic spasm

(also called Infantile spasm, West syndrome or Hypsarrhythmia)

Definition

They typically occur in infants and are marked by sudden, forceful contractions of the muscles, particularly those of the trunk. The spasms often occur in clusters(5-50), especially upon waking, and are associated with widespread brain abnormalities.

Age Group

Predominantly occurs in infants, likely due to differences in neuronal function and connectivity in the immature CNS.

EEG Features

It shows hypsarrhythmia, which is marked by diffuse giant slow waves with a chaotic background of irregular, multifocal spikes and sharp waves.

Clinical Spasm EEG

During a spasm, the EEG shows significant background suppression, known as the "electrodecremental response."

EMG Characteristics

Reveals a rhomboid pattern, distinguishing it from brief tonic and myoclonic seizures.

Treatment

Occasional episodes:

  • Drug of choice: ACTH hormone +/- glucocorticoids

Associated with tuberous sclerosis (lifelong seizures):

  • Drug of choice: Vigabatrin

Incorrect Options:

Valproate (Option A) is an anticonvulsant that is commonly used in the treatment of various types of seizures, including generalized seizures and absence seizures. However, it is not effective in the treatment of infantile spasms.

Topiramate (Option B) is also an anticonvulsant that is used for a variety of seizure disorders, including atypical absence, myoclonic, and atonic seizures. However, it is not typically used in the management of infantile spasms.

Phenobarbital (Option D) is a barbiturate that is used as an anticonvulsant; it is also used in neonates for the treatment of febrile seizures or in cases of status epilepticus. However, it is not the drug of choice for infantile spasms.

questions.text: A patient with an incident of being stabbed in the front part of the abdomen is brought to the emergency. The patient’s vital signs are stable. What will be the next step in managing this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Further investigation

Explanation:

  • The next step in this case is to investigate further to evaluate the extent of the injury and make a decision regarding whether surgical intervention is necessary.
  • The patient is hemodynamically stable, which means they are not in shock or showing signs of severe internal injury at this point.
  • In such cases, the management should focus on evaluating the injury more thoroughly, as penetrating abdominal trauma may sometimes cause delayed complications or injuries that aren't immediately apparent.
  • Emergency laparotomy is generally indicated only if the child shows signs of peritonitis, active bleeding, or deterioration in their clinical status. (Option A ruled out)
  • For stable patients, imaging first allows them to make a more informed decision about whether surgery is immediately necessary or if observation and further management are sufficient. (Option B ruled out)

Intravenous hydration (Option C) can be important to maintain circulation, especially in trauma cases. However, it is not the primary next step in managing abdominal stab wounds. The focus in this case is on determining the extent of injury using imaging before considering any surgical intervention or supportive measures.

questions.text: A female developed hyperprolactinemia and galactorrhea with recurrent episodes of nausea and vomiting. MRI shows pituitary adenoma. Her pregnancy test was negative. She did not give consent for surgery. Which drug should be used in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bromocriptine

Explanation:

  • The findings with hyperprolactinemia, galactorrhea, and recurrent nausea and vomiting, along with an MRI showing a pituitary adenoma, are consistent with a prolactinoma.
  • It is a benign tumor of the pituitary gland that secretes prolactin, leading to elevated prolactin levels.
  • Bromocriptine, a dopamine agonist, is the most appropriate treatment for managing prolactinomas in this case, as it directly addresses the underlying cause (elevated prolactin) and can reduce the size of the tumor while alleviating symptoms like galactorrhea and nausea.

Prolactinomas

Explanation

  • Prolactinomas are typically microadenomas in pre-menopausal women, as the symptoms of elevated prolactin levels often lead to early diagnosis.
  • Prolactin levels correlate with the size of the tumour
  • Dopamine inhibits the production of prolactin.

Clinical Presentation
  • Prolactin has inhibitory effects on FSH & LH.
  • Women: Commonly present with amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhea. If the tumour extends beyond the sella, visual field defects & mass effects occur.
  • Men: Typically present with impotence, loss of libido, infertility, or signs of central nervous system (CNS) compression, such as headaches and visual disturbances.

Diagnosis
  • PRL levels > 200 μg/L most likely indicates prolactinoma
  • PRL levels below 100 μg/L may indicate microadenomas
  • MRI Head is recommended for all patients with hyperprolactinemia and it shows as a suprasellar mass.

Management

Dopamine Agonists

First-line treatment option

  • Cabergoline - long action and better tolerance
    • Galactorrhea improves in 90% of patients
    • PRL levels are normal in 80% of patients with microadenomas and 70% with macroprolactinomas.
  • Bromocriptine
    • Shorter action - preferable in women wishing to conceive

Side effects may include nausea, mental fogging, nightmares, insomnia, vertigo and postural hypotension

Surgery

Indication

  • Tumor causing pituitary apoplexy.
  • Cases resistant to medical therapy.
  • Invasive macroadenomas affecting vision.
  • Pregnant woman with clinical features of tumor.
  • Mass effect of tumor persisting > 1 month with medical therapy.

Radiotherapy

Reserved for aggressive tumors that do not respond to dopamine agonists or surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Octreotide (Option A) is a somatostatin analogue that is used primarily for acromegaly and neuroendocrine tumors that secrete growth hormones or other hormones. It is not effective for prolactinomas, as it does not directly inhibit prolactin secretion.

Goserelin (Option C) is a GnRH analogue that suppresses gonadotropin release. It does not affect prolactin secretion and is not appropriate for managing prolactinomas.

Dagarelix (Option D) is also a GnRH antagonist, which is used primarily in the treatment of prostate cancer. Like goserelin, it suppresses gonadotropin release but does not affect prolactin levels or manage prolactinomas.

questions.text: A 59-year-old lady presents with a progressive, painless lump in the breast. What is the cause for the following skin change?

choices.text: Spread of the tumour to the anterior chest wall

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Infiltration of subdermal lymphatics

Explanation:

  • In a patient with progressive, painless breast lump and skin changes, the most likely cause of the skin changes is infiltration of subdermal lymphatics.
  • In breast cancer, the tumour cells can spread to the lymphatic system, which can lead to obstruction of the lymphatic drainage of the skin.
  • This obstruction can cause skin changes such as peau d’orange (skin that appears dimpled or like orange peel) due to fluid accumulation and swelling in the dermis.

 

Infiltration of the lactiferous duct (Option B) could cause a nipple discharge, but it is not the primary cause of skin changes like peau d’orange.

Involvement of Cooper’s ligament (Option C) can cause retraction or deformity of the breast, leading to a pulled-in appearance of the skin; it does not directly lead to the skin changes.

Spread of the tumour to the anterior chest wall (Option D) involves the deeper tissues of the muscle and rib cage and may cause fixation of the breast or a palpable mass that is immobile. This is less likely to cause the specific skin changes associated with lymphatic obstruction.

questions.text: Identify the gun and the corresponding range of the shot that caused the wound
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pistol, near shot

Explanation

  • The characteristics of gunshot wounds vary with the type of firearm and the range at which it is fired. For a pistol fired at a near range, the wound demonstrates specific features:

Near Shot (Pistol):

  • The muzzle is very close to the skin but not in direct contact.
  • Soot deposition (due to gunpowder combustion) and tattooing (due to unburnt or partially burnt gunpowder particles embedding in the skin) are present around the entry wound.
  • The wound edges may appear abraded due to the energy of the projectile.

 

Type of shotgun wounds

Type of wound

Contact

Close

(Option B) ruled out

Short/ Intermediate-range (Option A ruled out)

Distant

Entry wound

Cruciate/Stellate (Skull) or

Circular

Circular

Rat-hole like

Multiple small pellet wounds with the mostly dispersed entry wound

Border of wound

Contused, Irregular and muzzled appearance

Clean-cut, irregular or lacerated

Abraded and scalloped borders

Irregular

Blackening

 

Present around the margins and even inside the wound.

 

 

 

Present

Absent

 

 

Absent

Burning

Absent

Tattooing

Present

Images

 

 

 

 

 

 

Shotgun, intermediate range: Shows a central wound with pellet dispersion and reduced soot/tattooing, which is not consistent with the described wound.

Shotgun, close range: Typically produces extensive central tissue destruction, scorching, and concentrated pellet effects, inconsistent with a pistol wound.

Pistol, close shot: A "close shot" (slightly farther than a near shot) would lack soot deposition and show only mild tattooing with a clean entry wound.

 

Gunshot wound characteristics based on Range of shooting:

 

Shooting Range

Range

Wound Description

Contact shot

Muzzle in direct contact

Circular entry wound with muzzle imprint, severe tissue damage, blackening, and burning of the wound edges. Cherry-red tissue due to carbon monoxide absorption.

Close-shot

< 1 meter

Circular or elliptical entry wound with blackening, burning, tattooing,, and cherry-red tissue discolouration due to carbon monoxide absorption.

Short-range

1-2 meters

Circular 4-5 cm wound (Rat hole) with irregular borders, no blackening, burning, or tattooing.

Intermediate shot

2-4 meters

Large, irregular wound surrounded by multiple satellite wounds.

Distant shot

> 4 meters

The entry wound fades, leaving multiple small pellet wounds.

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant TB refers to mycobacterial resistance to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Isoniazid and Rifampicin

Explanation:

  • Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) refers to tuberculosis (TB) caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains that are resistant to at least two of the most powerful first-line anti-TB drugs:
    • Isoniazid (INH)
    • Rifampicin (RIF)

First-line anti-tubercular drugs:

  • H- Isoniazid
  • R- Rifampicin
  • Z- Pyrazinamide
  • E- Ethambutol
  • S- Streptomycin


Ethionamide and Ciprofloxacin (Fluoroquinolones) are second-line anti-tubercular drugs. These are used for the treatment of MDR-TB and often require close monitoring for side effects and interactions. (Other options ruled out)

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Defense wounds

Explanation

  • The wound in the image points to an active defense wound where the victim has tried to grasp the weapon to prevent the attack and sustained injuries to the palm and on the fingers which would have been the case with a double-edged weapon.
  • Defence wounds are caused by the immediate and instinctive reaction of the victim to save himself from an attack and are usually seen on the extremities.
  • They are divided into two types:

 

 

Active defense wounds

Passive defense wounds

Mechanism of injury

The victim tries to grasp the weapon.

The victim raises the arms, legs, or hands.

Site

  • Depends on the type of weapon.
  • A single-edged weapon causes a single cut on the palm or the bends of fingers or thumb.
  • A double-edged weapon produces cuts on both the palm and fingers.
  • A typical knife defense wound is seen between the base of the thumb and the index finger.
  • Extensor or ulnar surfaces of the forearms, wrists, back of the hands, knuckle.
  • Rarely on the shin and feet.
  • Arms and posterior aspect of lower limbs and back.

Type of Injuries

Irregular and ragged cuts due to loosening of skin tension while gripping the knife.

Fractures of the carpal bones, metacarpals, and digits (mostly blunt trauma).

Medicolegal importance

  • Defense wounds indicate homicide.
  • They are absent if the victim is:
    • Unconscious
    • Taken by surprise
    • Attacked from the back
    • Under the influence of drugs or alcohol

 

Antemortem wound (Option B): They are characterized by signs of vital reactions such as bleeding, tissue bridging, clot formation, and signs of inflammation or healing. These features indicate that the injury occurred while the person was alive.

Postmortem wound (Option C): They lack vital reactions such as active bleeding or inflammation. They typically have clean, dry edges and no tissue bridging, as blood circulation ceases after death.

Hesitation cuts (Option D):

  • Hesitation cuts (also known as tentative cuts or trial wounds) are multiple, small, superficial cuts that typically involve only the skin.
  • These cuts are often found at the beginning of a deeper incised wound.

questions.text: What type of consent is obtained when a patient agrees to a procedure after being informed about its benefits and complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Informed consent

Explanation

Informed consent involves providing the patient with all necessary information about a procedure, including its purpose, benefits, risks, and potential complications. The patient voluntarily agrees to the procedure after understanding this information. This is a key principle of medical ethics and legal practice.

  • Informed consent is provided when a patient understands the nature of their condition, the proposed treatment, the outcomes of the suggested treatment, alternative treatment options, and the associated risks and benefits. The patient has the right to either accept or decline the procedure.
  • Consent refers to a voluntary agreement, permission, or compliance, which may be either expressed or implied.
  • It is exempt in certain circumstances.
  • While patients with notifiable diseases (e.g., tuberculosis) may be treated to protect public health, using a placebo without the patient's knowledge violates ethical guidelines. Even in cases of public health concerns, deceptive treatment is not an acceptable practice and does not fall under exceptions to informed consent.

Exceptions to Informed Consent:

  • Emergencies Medical examination ordered by a police officer for an arrested individual [Sec 51 & 52 BNSS] Therapeutic privilege
  • Therapeutic waiver
  • Medico-legal postmortems
  • Psychiatric examination or treatment mandated by a court order Use of placebos
  • Prisoners
  • A person suffering from disease under the ‘notified’ category (to notify the authorities only)
  • Treatment of notifiable diseases for greater community interest.

Implied consent (Option B):

  • Occurs when consent is not explicitly stated or written but is inferred through actions.
  • For example, when a patient visits a hospital for an illness, it is understood that they are consenting to a physical examination to determine the cause of their illness.
  • This form of consent is legally valid.

Presumed consent/opt-out (Option C): Refers to the patient's refusal of the procedure, test, or treatment.

Passive Consent (Option D): Passive consent is not a standard or widely recognized type of consent in medical ethics. It implies consent by lack of objection, which is insufficient for significant medical interventions.

Substituted consent:

  • When a person is unable to provide informed consent for medical treatment, proxy consent must be obtained from a close relative.
  • The typical order of priority is the spouse, followed by an adult child, then a parent, and finally a sibling.

questions.text: A patient presented with blunt trauma to the abdomen. On evaluation, liver injury was noted, for which primary repair was done. Coagulation function was monitored intraoperatively using the method shown below. What is the method used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thromboelastography

Explanation:

  • The method used for monitoring coagulation function in this patient undergoing primary repair for liver injury is thromboelastography (TEG).
  • TEG is a test that studies the ability of blood to form a clot by studying its viscoelastic properties.

Stages of Thromboelastogram

 

Definition

Normal value

Problem it indicates

Treatment

Reaction time
 

Time taken for the clot to start forming

7.5-15 mins

 

Increased: Deficiency in clotting factors

Decreased: Hypercoagulable states

Fresh frozen plasma

Time for the clot to reach fixed strength

3-6 mins

Fibrinogen dysfunction

Cryoprecipitate

Alpha angle

 

Fibrin linking speed

45° and 55°

Fibrinogen dysfunction

Cryoprecipitate

Maximum amplitude

The highest vertical amplitude of TEG

50-60 mm

Platelets (most often)

Clotting factors

Platelets

Lysis in 30 mins

Percentage of amplitude reduction
30 minutes after maximum amplitude

0-8%

A high value indicates excess lysis of the clot

Tranexamic acid

 

Plethysmography (Option B) is a test used to measure changes in the volume of an organ or body part, often used for assessing lung function. It does not assess coagulation or blood clotting function.

Sonography (Option C) or ultrasound is an imaging technique that uses sound waves to visualise internal structures. It can be used for assessing injuries (such as liver damage) but is not a tool for coagulation monitoring.

Elastography (Option D) is an imaging technique that evaluates the elasticity or stiffness of tissues. It is used mainly to assess liver fibrosis but is not involved in coagulation monitoring.

questions.text: A person after sleeping overnight with the arm under his head now experiences paresis but no numbness in the morning. Which of the following is the best explanation for it?

choices.text: C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to hypoxia than B fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers
A fibers are more susceptible to hypoxia than C fibers

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) A fibers are more susceptible to pressure changes than C fibers

Explanation:

  • The person experiences muscle weakness (paresis) without numbness, suggesting motor function impairment with preserved sensory function.
  • Pressure on larger, myelinated motor neurons (A fibers) during sleep likely causes temporary weakness, as A fibers are more pressure-sensitive than smaller, unmyelinated sensory neurons (C fibers).

A, B, and C Nerve Fibers

  • Nerve fibers are categorized by their diameter, conduction velocity, and myelination. A, B, and C fibers have distinct structures and functions.

Key Characteristics:

  • A Fibers: Large, myelinated, fast conduction; transmit sharp pain, proprioception, touch, and pressure.
  • B Fibers: Smaller, myelinated, slower conduction; regulate autonomic functions (e.g., heart rate, digestion).
  • C Fibers: Smallest, unmyelinated, slowest conduction; transmit dull pain, temperature, itch, and respond to multiple stimuli.

Subtypes of A Fibers

  • Aα: Motor function and proprioception.
  • Aβ: Sensory transmission for touch and pressure.
  • Aδ: Sharp pain and temperature sensations.

Sensitivity to Stimuli

  • A Fibers: Rapidly respond to light touch, pressure, and sharp pain due to myelination.
  • B Fibers: Involved in autonomic pathways; less sensitive to external stimuli.
  • C Fibers: React to noxious stimuli, inflammation, and physiological changes (e.g., hypoxia).

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Intravenous fluids with regular insulin

Explanation:

  • The patient with diabetes mellitus presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, dehydration, Kussmaul breathing, hyperglycemia, and metabolic acidosis, indicative of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA); the next best step in management is intravenous fluids with regular insulin.

Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)

  • It is a life-threatening complication of diabetes, primarily type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM), though it can occur in type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) under stress.

Precipitating Factors

  • Inadequate Insulin Administration
  • Infections
  • Infarctions
  • Pancreatitis
  • Pregnancy
  • Drugs: Cocaine and other substances that impair glucose metabolism.

Pathophysiology

  • Insulin Deficiency: Leads to reduced glucose uptake and unopposed glucagon secretion, causing hyperglycemia and lipolysis.
  • Ketogenesis: Increased fatty acid oxidation produces ketone bodies (ß-hydroxybutyrate, acetoacetate), resulting in ketosis.
  • Acidosis: Accumulation of ketone bodies leads to high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Dehydration: Osmotic diuresis from hyperglycemia causes volume depletion, electrolyte imbalances, and renal impairment.

 

Clinical Features

Symptoms

Signs
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Thirst, polyuria, and polydipsia
  • Weight loss
  • Weakness and fatigue
  • Shortness of breath
  • Dehydration (dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor)
  • Hypotension (postural or supine)
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypothermia
  • Tachypnea
  • Kussmaul respiration (deep, labored breathing)
  • Fruity odor of acetone on the breath
  • Abdominal tenderness resembling acute abdomen
  • Lethargy, obtundation, possible cerebral edema, or coma

Investigations

Blood Glucose: Typically 250–600 mg/dL.

Serum Ketones: ß-hydroxybutyrate preferred for accurate detection; urine ketostix detect acetoacetate and acetate.

Arterial Blood Gas (ABG):

  • pH: 6.8–7.3 (acidosis).
  • pCO₂: 20–30 mmHg.
  • HCO₃: <18 mEq/L.

Electrolytes:

  • Potassium: Total body deficiency (3–6 mEq/kg) due to osmotic diuresis; serum potassium may be high initially but drops rapidly with insulin therapy.
  • Sodium: Dilutional hyponatremia due to hyperglycemia.
  • Anion Gap: Elevated, indicating high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Renal Function: Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine due to dehydration.

Management

  • Follow ISPAD 2022 Guidelines: Ensure IV fluid resuscitation and appropriate insulin administration in patients with moderate dehydration.

Initial Stabilization

Intravenous Fluids:

  • Start with isotonic saline (0.9%) to correct dehydration and improve circulation.
  • Switch to 0.45% saline if sodium levels are elevated.
  • Add 5% dextrose when blood glucose reaches 200 mg/dL to prevent hypoglycemia.

Insulin Therapy

Intravenous Regular Insulin:

  • Initial bolus of 0.1 units/kg, followed by continuous infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour.
  • Continue until acidosis resolves (pH >7.3, bicarbonate >15 mEq/L, and anion gap normalizes).

Potassium Correction:

  • If potassium is <3.3 mEq/L, delay insulin and administer potassium chloride (KCl).
  • Maintain potassium between 3.5–5.0 mEq/L.

 

Intravenous fluids with long-acting insulin (Option A): Long-acting insulin is not used for acute management of DKA. It is started only after stabilization and when the patient resumes oral intake.

Intravenous fluids (Option B): Although fluid resuscitation is critical, it must be combined with insulin therapy to address acidosis and hyperglycemia.

Intravenous insulin (Option C): Insulin alone cannot correct the severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalances associated with DKA.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Negative feedback

Explanation:

  • The baroreceptor reflex is a mechanism that helps maintain blood pressure homeostasis by regulating heart rate, vascular tone, and cardiac output. It relies on negative feedback to counteract deviations from normal blood pressure levels.

  • Negative feedback mechanism: The body responds to a change by initiating actions that counteract the change, aiming to restore equilibrium.

Examples of negative feedback mechanisms:

System

Stimulus

Response

Effect

Body Temperature

Temperature deviation

Sweating/shivering, vasodilation/constriction

Restores normal temperature

Blood Glucose

High/low blood glucose

Insulin/glucagon release

Normalises blood glucose levels

Thyroid Hormones

High/low thyroid hormones

TSH release adjustment

Maintains hormone balance

Blood Pressure

High/low blood pressure

Heart rate and vessel adjustment

Restores normal blood pressure

Calcium Homeostasis

High/low blood calcium

PTH/calcitonin release

Normalises blood calcium levels

Menstrual Cycle

Hormone level changes

FSH/LH regulation

Regulates menstrual cycle

Respiratory Rate

High CO2 levels

Increased breathing rate

Normalizes CO2 levels

Incorrect Options:

Feedforward (Option A): Incorrect. Feedforward mechanisms predict changes and act in advance to maintain stability, such as anticipatory responses. The baroreceptor reflex, however, responds to changes already occurring in blood pressure.

Positive feedback (Option B): Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies changes, potentially leading to instability. For example, in pathologic conditions like hemorrhagic shock, positive feedback mechanisms may contribute to worsening hypotension, but this is not part of the normal baroreceptor reflex.

Both A & B are correct (Option D): Incorrect. Neither feedforward nor positive feedback applies to the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) specimen of a patient is shown below, along with microscopy. The report shows mononuclear cytosis, elevated proteins, and low sugars. What is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tuberculous meningitis

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario, along with CSF findings of mononuclear cytosis, elevated proteins, low sugars, and the characteristic cobweb-like clot, strongly suggests tuberculous meningitis (TBM).

Features of Tuberculous Meningitis (TBM):

  • Etiology: Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, spreading hematogenously or via rupture of subependymal tubercles into the subarachnoid space.
  • Presentation: Subacute infection with fever, headache, neck stiffness, and cranial nerve palsies (commonly ocular nerves due to basal meningeal involvement).
  • Complications: Hydrocephalus, raised intracranial pressure (ICP), and infarcts.
  • CSF Findings:
    • Lymphocytic predominance.
    • Elevated protein levels.
    • Low glucose levels.
    • Cobweb-like pellicle formation.

Diagnosis:

  • Gold Standard: CSF culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Supportive Tests: Acid-fast bacilli (AFB) stain, PCR for tuberculosis, or CSF ADA levels.

Management:

  • Initiation of antitubercular therapy (ATT).
  • Steroids to reduce inflammation.

 

CSF Findings in Different Types of Meningitis

Parameter

Bacterial Meningitis (Option C)

Viral Meningitis (Aseptic Meningitis) (Option B)

Fungal Meningitis

Tuberculous Meningitis

Appearance

Turbid/cloudy

Clear

Clear/slightly cloudy

Cobweb appearance

Opening Pressure

Elevated

Normal or slightly elevated

Elevated

Elevated

WBC Count

100–10,000/µL (predominantly neutrophils)

10–500/µL (predominantly lymphocytes)

20–500/µL (predominantly lymphocytes)

50–500/µL (predominantly lymphocytes)

Protein

Elevated (>100 mg/dL)

Normal or slightly elevated (50–100 mg/dL)

Elevated (50–200 mg/dL)

Elevated (100–500 mg/dL)

Glucose

Decreased (<40 mg/dL or <40% of serum glucose)

Normal (>40 mg/dL or >50% of serum glucose)

Decreased (<40 mg/dL or <50% of serum glucose)

Decreased (<40 mg/dL or <50% of serum glucose)

 

Chemical meningitis (Option D): This occurs due to the rupture of tumor contents (e.g., from a dermoid cyst or glioma) into the CSF.

  • CSF Findings: Variable inflammatory response, often with elevated proteins but no infective organisms.

questions.text: Which of the following types of cell- to-cell signaling is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paracrine

Explanation:

Cell-to-Cell Signaling

  • Cell-to-cell signaling ensures coordination among cells for proper function and adaptation to environmental changes. This process involves various mechanisms, molecules, and receptors.

Mechanisms of Cell Signaling

Types of Signaling

Type

Mechanism

Examples

Autocrine

Cells release molecules that bind to their own receptors, influencing self-regulation.

Tumor cells promoting growth.

Paracrine

Molecules released into extracellular fluid affect nearby cells.

Local tissue responses.

Endocrine

Hormones travel through the bloodstream to reach distant targets.

Regulation of metabolism via insulin.

Gap Junction

Small molecules and ions pass directly between adjacent cells via gap junctions.

Synchronization in cardiac tissue.

Signal Transduction Pathways

  1. Receptor Activation: Signaling molecules (ligands) bind to receptors, triggering activation.
  2. Transduction: A cascade of intracellular events involves proteins and second messengers (e.g., cAMP, DAG, IP3).
  3. Response: Outcomes include changes in gene expression, enzyme activity, or cell behavior.

Components of Cell Signaling

Component

Description

Signaling Molecules

Include hormones, neurotransmitters, cytokines, and growth factors; classified as hydrophilic (e.g., peptides) or hydrophobic (e.g., steroids).

Receptors

Proteins that bind signaling molecules; key types include:

G-Protein-Coupled (GPCRs)

Activate intracellular G-proteins to elicit responses.

Ion Channel Receptors

Regulate ion flow upon ligand binding.

Enzyme-Linked Receptors

Activate enzymes or possess intrinsic enzymatic activity.

Importance of Cell Signaling

  • Supports development, differentiation, and immune responses.
  • Maintains homeostasis and regulates metabolism.
  • Facilitates tissue repair.
  • Insights into signaling pathways help understand disease mechanisms and therapeutic targets.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of death in a body with a horizontal ligature mark completely encircling the neck and located below the thyroid, with no dribbling of saliva?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ligature strangulation

Explanation

  • The horizontal ligature mark completely encircling the neck below the thyroid, along with the absence of dribbling of saliva, is characteristic of ligature strangulation.
  • In ligature strangulation, the ligature compresses the neck, leading to trauma and bruising of the subcutaneous tissues and muscles underneath the ligature.
    • This bruising is a direct result of the force applied by the ligature, which can cause small blood vessels to rupture, resulting in bleeding into the surrounding tissues.

 

Causes of Death in Ligature Strangulation:

  1. Asphyxia
  2. Cerebral anoxia
  3. Vagal inhibition
  4. Cervical Vertebrae Fracture

 

Postmortem Findings:

1. External Examination:

Finding

Description
Face
  • Congested, swollen, and cyanosed.
  • Tardieu's spots (petechiae) on the forehead, temples, eyelids, and conjunctiva.
  • Prominent eyes with congested conjunctiva, dilated pupils, and possible subconjunctival haemorrhages.
  • Cyanosis of lips, fingernails, and earlobes.
  • Postmortem staining above the ligature.
  • Swollen, dark-coloured, protruding tongue, possibly bitten.
  • Bloodstained frothy fluid and mucus in mouth and nostrils.
Neck
  • Ligature mark ('furrow'): well-defined groove, typically the same width as the ligature, often horizontal.
  • More prominent on the front and sides of the neck.
  • Red base with congested or ecchymosed margins; imprint pattern may be present.
  • Can be indistinct if the ligature is soft; it may appear as a deep groove with a narrow cord ('cheese cutter method').
  • May show an oblique appearance if the victim was dragged post-strangulation.
Other Body Parts
  • Deep, prominent postmortem staining.
  • Involuntary discharge of urine and faecal matter; less common seminal ejaculation.
  • Clenched hands; possible genital turgidity.
  • Possible abrasions, fingernail marks, and contusions on face, and arms, indicating struggle.
  • Horizontal, irregular abrasions on the neck may indicate attempts to remove ligature.

 

 

2. Internal Examination:

  • On dissection- Contusion and haemorrhage- of tissue, muscles of the neck, tonsils and glands.
  • Fracture of the thyroid cartilage is commonly seen.
  • Fracture of the hyoid bone is not very common as it is usually at or below the level of the thyroid.

 

Throttling (Option A): Throttling refers to manual strangulation using hands. Post-mortem findings typically include bruising, nail marks, and finger impressions on the neck. The ligature mark described here rules out throttling.

Gagging (Option C): Gagging involves obstruction of the airway by an object in the mouth, often without external neck findings. This does not match the described findings.

Hanging (Option D): In hanging, the ligature mark is typically oblique, does not completely encircle the neck, and is located above the level of the thyroid cartilage. Dribbling of saliva is a characteristic finding in hanging, which is absent here

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram?

choices.text: Segment la is due to residual urine
Segment Ib is due to Laplace law
Micturition fails to happen in segment II

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Segment Ib is due to Laplace law

Explanation:

  • Segment Ib is due to Laplace law where volume is increased but there is no rise in pressure,

Cystometrogram Phases and Laplace's Law

Phases of Cystometrogram

  • Initial (Filling) Phase:
    • The bladder fills with sterile fluid.
    • Intra-vesical pressure (Pves) rises.
    • Detrusor muscle contracts, causing initial pressure increase without volume change.
    • Divided into three segments:
      • Phase I: Up to 1/3 of max capacity.
      • Phase II: 1/3 to 2/3 of max capacity.
      • Phase III: 2/3 to max capacity.
    • Provides insights into detrusor properties, especially in neurogenic bladders.
  • Emptying Phase:
    • Characterized by rhythmic external urethral sphincter contractions and increased Pves.
    • High-frequency pressure oscillations (HFPO) during active voiding.
  • Rebound Phase:
    • Post-voiding, Pves increases as a rebound effect.
    • Indicates residual pressure changes after voiding.

Application of Laplace's Law

  • Formula:
    P=2T/r
  • Where:
    • P = internal pressure
    • T = wall tension
    • r = radius
  • As the bladder fills, its radius increases, influencing pressure and tension.
  • Helps interpret pressure changes during filling and voiding, especially in detrusor overactivity or compliance issues.

Clinical Relevance

  • Key for diagnosing urological conditions:
    • Overactive bladder (OAB)
    • Bladder outlet obstruction
    • Neurogenic bladder dysfunction
  • Analyzing bladder pressure and compliance during each phase aids in personalized treatment strategies

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried?

choices.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Criminal negligence

Explanation

  • The surgeon’s decision to operate under the influence of alcohol constitutes criminal negligence, as it demonstrates reckless behavior leading to a fatal outcome.
  • This is likely to be prosecuted under Section 304A of the Indian Penal Code (BNS Section 106), which deals with causing death by a negligent act.

 

Civil Negligence Not Amounting to Criminal Negligence (Option B): Civil negligence involves a breach of duty leading to harm . The surgeon’s actions, being willful, surpass the threshold of civil negligence.

Therapeutic Misadventure (Option C): An unintended complication occurred during treatment, which was beyond the doctor's control. This does not apply, as the surgeon acted recklessly by operating while intoxicated.

Dichotomy (Option D): Dichotomy refers to the unethical practice of sharing fees between doctors or professionals and is unrelated to the situation described.

questions.text: What changes do not occur in stage A as compared to stage B when the hypothalamic thermostat in a patient is reset from point A to point C, as depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sweating

Explanation:

  • In Stage A, the hypothalamic set point increases (from Point A to Point C), causing the body to perceive itself as cold, even if the temperature is normal. The body reacts to raise its temperature by:
    • Shivering: Generates heat via muscle activity
    • Vasoconstriction: Minimizes heat loss through skin
    • Epinephrine secretion: Increases metabolic heat production
    • Sweating does NOT occur, because sweating would decrease body temperature, which is counterproductive at this stage

Hypothalamic Temperature Regulation Summary

Phase

Set Point vs Actual Temp

Body’s Perception

Physiological Responses

Stage A

Set point > actual temp

Feels cold

Shivering, vasoconstriction, ↑Epi

Stage B

Set point drops to normal

Feels hot

Sweating, vasodilation

Vasoconstriction (Option B): Incorrect because vasoconstriction does occur in Stage A to conserve heat.

Sweating (Option C): Correct, because sweating does NOT occur in Stage A; it begins in Stage B when the set point normalizes.

Epinephrine secretion (Option D): Incorrect because epinephrine is secreted in Stage A to increase metabolic heat production.

questions.text: In a patient who experienced a stroke 2 days ago, the current symptoms include uncontrollable, forceful, and jerking motions of the limbs on one side. Where is the probable location of the lesion in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Subthalamic nuclei

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of uncontrollable, forceful, and jerking motions of the limbs on one side and a history of stroke suggest the diagnosis of hemiballismus, a movement disorder characterized by involuntary and violent flinging movements of the extremities on one side of the body.

Hypokinetic Diseases

1. Parkinsonism:

  • Cause: Reduced dopamine in the substantia nigra.
  • Symptoms: Akinesia, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity, resting tremor, shuffling gait, stooped posture, reduced facial expression, small handwriting, and mood/cognitive issues.

Hyperkinetic Diseases

1. Hemiballismus:

  • Damage to the subthalamic nucleus, leading to decreased inhibition of the thalamus and excessive movement.

2. Huntington's Disease:

  • Degeneration of the indirect pathway in the striatum, causing involuntary movements similar to hemiballismus.

3. Dystonia:

  • Dysfunction in the direct pathway, resulting in sustained, twisting movements.

The Basal Ganglia:

  • The basal ganglia are a group of subcortical nuclei in the brain involved in regulating movement and coordinating motor activity. Key parts include:
    • Striatum: Consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen. It's the main input center for the basal ganglia, receiving information from the cerebral cortex. (Options C & D ruled out)
    • Globus Pallidus: Divided into the external (GPe) and internal (GPi) segments. It plays a role in the regulation of voluntary movement by processing signals from the striatum.
    • Substantia Nigra: Located in the midbrain and has two parts: the pars compacta (which produces dopamine) and the pars reticulata. It is involved in movement control and has a key role in the dopamine system. (Option B ruled out)
    • Subthalamic Nucleus: Located below the thalamus, it contributes to motor control by influencing the output of the globus pallidus. (Option A)

The basal ganglia use several key neurotransmitters to regulate motor control:

  1. Dopamine: Produced by the substantia nigra, particularly the pars compacta.
  2. GABA (Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid): The primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the basal ganglia. It is released by neurons in the striatum, globus pallidus (both external and internal segments), and substantia nigra (pars reticulata).
  3. Glutamate: The primary excitatory neurotransmitter. It is released by the cerebral cortex to the striatum and by the subthalamic nucleus to the globus pallidus and substantia nigra.
  • The caudate nucleus primarily uses GABA as its neurotransmitter, not acetylcholine.
  • The globus pallidus internus (GPi) exerts an inhibitory influence on the thalamus.
  • The substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr) inhibits the thalamus using GABA, not dopamine.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed to be retro-positive was started on highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Viral load

Explanation:

  • Viral load (HIV RNA levels) is the most reliable parameter for monitoring the efficacy of Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART).
  • It reflects the amount of active virus in the bloodstream and is the primary marker for assessing viral suppression.
  • A tenfold reduction in viral load is typically expected within 1-2 months of HAART initiation, and the goal is to achieve viral load levels of <50 copies/mL within 6 months.

 

CD4+ T Cell Count (Option A): Although an increase in CD4+ count reflects immune recovery, it is less sensitive than the viral load for assessing early response to HAART. CD4+ count is better for staging disease progression or assessing immune status, rather than directly evaluating HAART efficacy.

p24 Antigen (Option C): The p24 antigen is a core protein of the HIV capsid, used primarily in early diagnosis before seroconversion. It is not a marker for ongoing treatment efficacy.

Viral Serotype (Option D): The viral serotype is irrelevant for treatment monitoring, as most cases of HIV are caused by HIV-1.

questions.text: Which organization is responsible for vaccines, child health and nutrition, safe water and sanitation, quality education and skill-building?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - UNICEF:

  • The United Nations Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF) is the primary organization responsible for promoting and protecting the rights of children and ensuring their well-being.
  • It focuses on vaccines, child health, nutrition, safe water and sanitation, and quality education and skill-building as part of its mission to support children's development worldwide.
  • UNICEF works globally to improve the lives of children and women, especially in developing countries, and ensures they have access to essential services.

CARE (option A) is a humanitarian organization focused on fighting global poverty and providing emergency aid. While it works on issues like health and nutrition, its focus is broader and not as specifically centred on child health, vaccines, and education as UNICEF.

UNDP (option B): The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) focuses on sustainable development, poverty reduction, and democratic governance, but does not have the primary responsibility for child health, vaccines, and education.

WHO (option D): The World Health Organization (WHO) is responsible for global health, including setting health standards and coordinating health responses. While it works on vaccines and child health, it is not as directly focused on child welfare, nutrition, water, and education as UNICEF.

questions.text: Many children from a particular community coming to a hospital were detected to have acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control study has to be done to find whether the chemical and ALL are associated, what will be taken as the control?

choices.text: Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease
Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease
Children coming to your OPD, who do not have the disease
All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Children coming to your OPD, who do not have the disease

Children coming to your OPD, who do not have the disease:

  • In a case-control study, the controls are individuals who do not have the disease but are otherwise similar to the cases (in terms of exposure, age, and other factors).
  • Since the study aims to find the association between cytotoxic waste in the water and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the controls should be children who are not affected by ALL but are exposed to similar environmental factors, like the presence of cytotoxic waste, to ensure the groups are comparable.

Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease (option A): These children are exposed to the chemical waste, but since the study is looking at children who do not have the disease, they are not ideal controls. The control group should not be exposed to the risk factor in question in order to establish a clear association.

Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease (option B): This group would have ALL but is not exposed to the chemical waste, making them an inappropriate control. Controls should not have the disease.

All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status (option D): This is referring to all cases of the disease, not controls. In a case-control study, the focus is on comparing cases (children with ALL) to those who do not have the disease, to examine potential risk factors such as exposure to cytotoxic waste.

questions.text: Open vial policy is accepted for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine)

  • The open vial policy is accepted for Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV). IPV can be safely used within 28 days of opening the vial, provided it is stored under appropriate conditions (e.g., in a cold chain) and no contamination has occurred. This policy helps reduce vaccine wastage in settings where demand may be lower, while maintaining the vaccine's efficacy and safety.

BCG (option A): The BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) vaccine does not typically follow the open vial policy. Once opened, the vaccine should be used within a short period, usually within the same day, due to its potential instability and risk of contamination.

Measles (option B): The measles vaccine does not follow the open vial policy in the same manner as IPV. Once opened, it must be used within 6 hours.

JE (option C): The Japanese encephalitis (JE) vaccine does not follow the open vial policy either. Similar to BCG, the JE vaccine requires strict guidelines for handling and storage, and open vials should be discarded after a specific time.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the drug of choice for acute management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sumatriptan

Explanation:

  • The clinical features of unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia are classic signs of an acute migraine attack.
  • Migraine is a common episodic headache disorder, more frequent in females, and often triggered by stimuli such as bright lights, hunger, or stress.

Drug of Choice: Triptans (e.g., Sumatriptan) (5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist)

  • Mechanism of Action: It reduces nociceptive signaling in the trigeminovascular system and causes cranial vasoconstriction, effectively alleviating migraine symptoms.
  • Indication: First-line treatment for acute migraine attacks.
  • Side Effects: Can cause transient myocardial ischemia, coronary vasospasm, and rarely, serotonin syndrome when combined with SSRIs or TCAs.

Migraine Management:

Acute Treatment:

  • First-Line: NSAIDs, Triptans (e.g., Sumatriptan).
  • Alternatives: Gepants (e.g., Rimegepant), Ditans (e.g., Lasmiditan).
  • Supportive measures: Dopamine receptor antagonists (e.g., Domperidone) for associated nausea.

Prophylaxis (for frequent attacks):

  • Flunarizine (Option A): Calcium channel blocker
  • Propranolol (Option C): Non-selective β-blocker
  • Topiramate (Option D): Anticonvulsant
  • Amitriptyline: Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA)

Triggers to Avoid: Bright lights, stress, hunger, sleep deprivation.

questions.text: The patient exhibits a numbed region on the face, depicted in the image provided. Which nerve is most frequently affected in this particular condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Facial nerve

Explanation:

  • Clinical Features in the Image:
    • The image suggests facial swelling with a loss of sensation or muscle weakness, commonly seen in leprosy (Hansen’s disease).
    • The Facial Nerve (CN VII) is commonly involved in lepromatous leprosy, leading to facial palsy and lagophthalmos (inability to close the eye).
  • Facial Nerve Involvement in Leprosy:
    • Mycobacterium leprae infiltrates Schwann cells, causing neuropathy.
    • This leads to weakness of facial muscles, particularly affecting the orbicularis oculi, resulting in lagophthalmos.
    • Loss of motor control can contribute to facial asymmetry and trophic ulcers.

Facial Nerve Involvement in Leprosy

Feature

Facial Nerve (CN VII) Involvement

Function

Motor to facial muscles, taste from anterior 2/3 of tongue

Affected Branches

Zygomatic & Buccal branches

Symptoms in Leprosy

Facial weakness, inability to close eye (lagophthalmos), drooping face

Complications

Corneal ulcers, facial deformity

Abducens nuclei (Option A): Incorrect because CN VI controls lateral eye movement, not facial sensation or motor function.

Optic nerve (Option C): Incorrect because CN II controls vision, not facial movement or sensation.

Trigeminal nerve (Option D): Incorrect because CN V mainly controls sensation, whereas the image suggests a motor deficit affecting facial expressions.

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 16-year-old girl who experiences strong food cravings and engages in excessive eating followed by self-induced vomiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Bulimia nervosa

  • The likely diagnosis for this 16-year-old girl is bulimia nervosa, which is characterised by episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors such as self-induced vomiting, excessive exercise, or laxative use to prevent weight gain.

Features of Bulimia nervosa

Binge Eating Episodes

Recurring episodes of binge eating, occurring at least weekly for the last 3 months.

Compensatory Behaviors

Purging behaviours (self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics), excessive exercise, fasting.

BMI

Often normal or slightly overweight (compared to anorexia nervosa).

Gender prevalence

More common in females than males

Physical Signs
  • Parotid gland hypertrophy (may see increased serum amylase)
  • Enamel erosion (from vomiting)
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome (esophageal tears)
  • These signs appear due to repeated purging.

Electrolyte Disturbances

Commonly, hypokalemia and hypochloremia.

Metabolic Changes

Metabolic alkalosis due to vomiting.

Physical Findings

Dorsal hand calluses from induced vomiting (Russell sign).

Anorexia nervosa (Option A) is characterised by extreme restriction of food intake due to a fear of gaining weight, leading to significant weight loss. Unlike bulimia, individuals with anorexia nervosa typically do not engage in binge eating or purging behaviours.

Atypical depression (Option C) is a subtype of depression that includes symptoms such as increased appetite, hypersomnia, a feeling of being weighed down, and mood reactivity. While eating disturbances can occur in atypical depression, they do not typically involve binge eating, followed by purging, as seen in bulimia nervosa.

Binge eating disorder (Option D) involves episodes of binge eating but without compensatory behaviours to prevent weight gain. Since this patient is inducing vomiting after eating, this would not meet the criteria for a binge eating disorder.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents with sudden-onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray reveals findings consistent with pulmonary edema. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Intravenous nitroglycerin

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario suggests acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema (ACPE).

Precipitating factors:

  • Severe hypertension
  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Chronic heart failure exacerbation
  • Medication non-compliance
  • Excessive salt intake

Symptoms:

  • Sudden severe dyspnea
  • Pink frothy sputum
  • Cyanosis
  • Rales and rhonchi heard on auscultation

Chest X-ray findings:

  • Interstitial edema
  • Alveolar edema in a butterfly pattern
  • Possible cardiomegaly

Management of Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema:

  • IV Nitroglycerin
    • Mechanism: Reduces preload and afterload by causing venodilation, lowering pulmonary venous pressure.
    • Indication: Rapid relief of pulmonary edema symptoms without causing hypotension.
    • Administration: Start with sublingual nitroglycerin; escalate to intravenous if symptoms persist.
  • Oxygen Therapy: Maintain oxygen saturation >92%. Use non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) or intubation if oxygenation fails.
  • Diuretics (e.g., Furosemide): Used to remove excess fluid but only after stabilizing the patient’s hemodynamics.
  • Morphine: Provides venodilation and reduces anxiety, but use is controversial due to the risk of respiratory depression.
  • Positioning: Sitting upright with legs dependent to reduce venous return in patients without hypotension.

 

Intravenous salbutamol (Option A): Salbutamol is a β2-agonist used for acute severe asthma or hyperkalemia, not pulmonary edema.

Nebulization with salbutamol (Option C): Similar to Option A, it is used in asthma management, not for ACPE.

Oxygen and antibiotics (Option D): Oxygen therapy is indicated, but antibiotics are not used in cardiogenic pulmonary edema unless there is an underlying infection like pneumonia.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with multiple anogenital warts. The biopsy of these lesions showed squamous atypia. Which of the following human papillomavirus types are considered high-risk?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HPV 18

Explanation:

  • Clinical Features in the Image:
    • The image shows anogenital warts (condyloma acuminata), which are commonly caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).
    • The presence of squamous atypia on biopsy suggests a risk of progression to high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL) or malignancy.
  • HPV and Oncogenic Potential:
    • Low-risk HPV types (HPV 6 & 11): Cause benign anogenital warts.
    • High-risk HPV types (HPV 16 & 18): Associated with cervical, anal, and anogenital cancers.
    • HPV 18 is one of the most oncogenic strains, particularly linked to cervical adenocarcinoma.

High-Risk HPV and Cancer Association

HPV Type

Risk Level

Associated Conditions

HPV 6, 11

Low-risk

Anogenital warts, respiratory papillomatosis

HPV 16, 18

High-risk

Cervical, anal, oropharyngeal, and penile cancers

HPV 31, 33, 45

High-risk

Cervical and vulvar cancers

 

HPV 2 (Option A): Incorrect because it is associated with common warts (verruca vulgaris), not anogenital warts.

HPV 6 (Option C): Incorrect because it is a low-risk type that causes benign genital warts.

HPV 11 (Option D): Incorrect because it is also low-risk, causing anogenital warts but not linked to cancer.

questions.text: A patient on antidepressants presents with hypotension. An ECG reveals wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Intravenous sodium bicarbonate

Explanation:

The clinical scenario indicates tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity, characterized by:

  • Hypotension
  • Wide QRS complexes
  • Right axis deviation
  • QT prolongation on ECG

TCAs block sodium channels in the myocardium, leading to arrhythmias and conduction delays.

 

Side effects of Tricyclic antidepressants:

Mechanism of side effect

Side effect

H1 receptor blockade

Sedation, weight gain

Anticholinergic action on muscarinic receptors
  • Hyperthermia
  • Dry eyes/mouth
  • Mydriasis (C/I in glaucoma)
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Tachycardia

Increase in serotonin in the brain

Seizure threshold reduction

Alpha 1 adrenergic receptor antagonism

Postural hypotension

Sodium channel block
  • Arrhythmia/QT prolongation
  • Bradycardia in heart block due to overdose

Management of TCA Toxicity:

  • Intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate
    • Mechanism: Reverses the sodium channel blockade by alkalinizing the serum, stabilizing myocardial membranes.
    • Indication: For QRS widening (>100 ms), hypotension, or arrhythmias due to TCA toxicity.
    • Dose: Bolus of 50–100 mEq; repeat as necessary until QRS duration normalizes.
  • Activated Charcoal: If ingestion is recent (within 2 hours), it helps reduce absorption of the drug.

Other Measures for Complications:

  • Seizures: Benzodiazepines are preferred.
  • Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (Torsades de Pointes): Use intravenous magnesium sulfate.

 

Antiarrhythmics (Option A): Class IA, IC, and III antiarrhythmics (e.g., quinidine, flecainide, amiodarone) are contraindicated as they exacerbate sodium channel blockade.

Propranolol (Option C): A beta-blocker, it is not effective in treating TCA-induced arrhythmias or QRS widening. It can worsen hypotension and bradycardia caused by TCA toxicity.

Phenytoin (Option D): An antiepileptic drug, it has no role in TCA toxicity. It can displace TCAs from protein-binding sites, worsening toxicity symptoms.

questions.text: A farmer presents to you with swelling on foot and multiple discharging sinuses in the lower limb. Granules from the discharge were examined under the microscope, shown below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

Explanation:

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Swelling on the foot, multiple discharging sinuses, and granules in discharge are characteristic of mycetoma.
    • Farmers are commonly affected due to trauma with contaminated soil.
  • Microscopic Features in the Image:
    • The granules seen in the image are sulfur granules, which are commonly found in mycetoma.
    • Mycetoma can be caused by both bacteria (Actinomycetoma) and fungi (Eumycetoma).

Mycetoma

Feature

Actinomycetoma (Bacterial)

Eumycetoma (Fungal)

Causative Agents

Actinomyces, Nocardia

Madurella, Exophiala

Granule Color

White, yellow, red

Black, brown

Tissue Involvement

Deep tissue destruction

Deep tissue involvement

Spread

Hematogenous, but not lymphatic

Hematogenous, but not lymphatic

Treatment

Long-term antibiotics

Antifungals, surgery

 

 

 

Undergoes lymphatic spread (Option B): Incorrect because mycetoma spreads via direct extension and hematogenous routes, not through lymphatics.

There is lymphocyte accumulation (Option C): Incorrect because mycetoma is granulomatous, not predominantly lymphocytic.

Involves only superficial tissues (Option D): Incorrect because mycetoma extends deeply into subcutaneous and bone tissue over time.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a woman who is 4 days postpartum and experiencing tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Postpartum blues

  • Postpartum blues (also known as baby blues) is a common condition that affects many women 3-5 days after childbirth.
  • It is characterised by tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia, similar to the symptoms described in this patient.
  • The symptoms are mild and typically resolve within 2 weeks without requiring treatment.

 

Postpartum Blues

Postpartum Depression

(Option A)

Postpartum Psychosis

(Option C)

Occurrence

Affects up to 80% of women after childbirth
  • Affects 10- 15% of women
  • 70% risk of recurrence in next pregnancy
  • Incidence is about 1-2 in 1000 deliveries
  • 50% risk of recurrence in next pregnancy

Timing

Onset 3-5 days postpartum, resolves by days to weeks

Within the first 6 weeks postpartum or after abortion

Symptoms appear within 2-3 weeks postpartum and last 2-3 months

Symptoms

Transient symptoms such as

  • Emotionally labile
  • Insomnia
  • Weepiness
  • Loss of energy
  • Depressed mood
  • Loss of interest or pleasure (anhedonia)
  • Loss of appetite
  • Insomnia
  • Social withdrawal
  • Irritability
  • Suicidal thoughts

Initial symptoms: insomnia, tearfulness, mood lability, fatigue, followed by

  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions

Risk Factors

Not specific; linked to biochemical changes.
  • Young maternal age
  • Antenatal depression
  • Family history of mood disorder
  • Unmarried status
  • Smoking
  • Stress
  • Newborns in intensive care
  • Physical or verbal abuse
  • Serious adverse obstetrical events
  • Nulliparas
  • Obstetrical complications
  • Family history of mood disorder
  • History of psychotic illness

Treatment

Supportive treatment and reassurance.

Antidepressants and psychotherapy.
  • Hospitalization, pharmacological treatment (lithium, antipsychotics, antidepressants), long-term psychiatric care
  • Temporary separation from the infant and nursing supervision may be necessary

Postpartum anxiety (Option D) is excessive worrying that occurs after childbirth, where people may feel consumed with worry and constantly nervous or panicked. It negatively affects breastfeeding, early interactions, infant temperament, sleep, and cognitive development. While anxiety can be a symptom of postpartum blues, it is not typically the primary presenting symptom.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a cauliflower-shaped mass on the foot of a farmer that appeared after a minor injury, with microscopy revealing copper penny bodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chromoblastomycosis

Explanation:

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Cauliflower-shaped mass on the foot
    • Farmer with a history of minor trauma
    • Slow-growing lesion
  • Microscopy Findings:
    • Copper penny bodies (Medlar bodies) → Characteristic of Chromoblastomycosis

Chromoblastomycosis

Feature

Chromoblastomycosis

Causative Organisms

Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora, Phialophora

Risk Factor

Trauma (especially in farmers)

Clinical Appearance

Cauliflower-like verrucous lesion

Microscopy

Copper penny bodies (Medlar bodies/ muriform bodies)

Spread

Slow, localized spread

Treatment

Itraconazole, surgery if severe

 

Blastomycosis (Option B): Incorrect because Blastomycosis presents as pulmonary or skin ulcers, not a cauliflower-like lesion.

Sporotrichosis (Option C): Incorrect because Sporotrichosis follows a lymphatic spread (rose gardener's disease), not a localized verrucous lesion.

Phaeohyphomycosis (Option D): Incorrect because it involves dark-pigmented fungi but does not show copper penny bodies.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sarcoidosis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy, along with leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, strongly points to sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis:

Sarcoidosis is a chronic multisystem inflammatory disorder of unknown cause, characterized by the accumulation of T lymphocytes and mononuclear phagocytes, leading to the formation of non-caseating granulomas in various tissues of the body.

Clinical Presentation

Lungs (90%)

  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Cavitation (Rare)
  • Pleural involvement (1-5% cases) with occasional pleural effusion

Pulmonary Symptoms: Dry cough, dyspnea, chest pain

 

Lymph Nodes (75-90%)

  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (hallmark)
  • Parotid enlargement

 

Extrapulmonary Symptoms:

  • Skin
    • Erythema nodosum (tender red nodules, often on shins)

 

    • Lupus pernio (purple-blue shiny lesions on nose, cheeks, lips, and ears)
  • Eyes: Anterior Uveitis
  • Kidneys: Hypercalcemia with or without hypercalciuria
  • Nervous System: Facial nerve palsy, Peripheral neuropathy
  • Heart: Cor pulmonale (secondary to pulmonary fibrosis)

Constitutional Symptoms: Fever, fatigue, night sweats, weight loss

Syndromes Associated

 
  • Lofgren's syndrome: Features include erythema nodosum (painful red nodules on the shins), hilar lymphadenopathy, and periarticular arthritis.
  • Mikulicz syndrome: Involves bilateral enlargement of the parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands.

Histopathological Features
  • Presence of non-caseating granulomas in affected organs
  • Granulomas are often composed of epithelioid histiocytes and giant cells (Langerhans or foreign body type)

 

Inclusion Bodies in Giant Cells:

  • Schaumann bodies (calcium-protein inclusions)

 

  • Asteroid bodies (stellate-shaped inclusions)

Initial Diagnostic Workup

History and Physical Examination

  • Assess for respiratory symptoms and extrapulmonary signs
  • Check for bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and skin lesions

Chest Imaging

  • Chest X-ray (Stage 1: bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding)

Laboratory Investigations

Serum Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE)

  • Elevated in 60% of cases (non-specific but supportive)

Calcium Levels

  • Hypercalcemia due to increased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D production by macrophages in granulomas

Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL)

  • CD4/CD8 ratio > 3.5 supports sarcoidosis (not diagnostic alone)

Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs)
  • Restrictive Pattern
  • Decreased FVC and TLC
  • Normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio
  • Decreased DLCO (diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide)

Imaging Studies

Chest X-Ray: Staging based on lung involvement

Stage 0

Normal

Stage 1

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with pulmonary infiltrates

Stage 3

Pulmonary infiltrates only

Stage 4

Pulmonary fibrosis

High-Resolution CT (HRCT):

  • Ground-glass opacities
  • Perilymphatic nodules
  • Fibrotic changes

Histopathology

Tissue Biopsy (Gold Standard)

  • Non-caseating granulomas in lung, lymph nodes, or skin
  • Exclusion of other granulomatous diseases such as tuberculosis (caseating granulomas) and fungal infections

Other Diagnostic Tests

Gallium-67 Scintigraphy

  • Panda Sign: Uptake in lacrimal and parotid glands

 

  • Lambda Sign: Uptake in bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes

 

 

Positron Emission Tomography (PET)

  • Identifies active inflammation and organ involvement

Differential Diagnosis
  • Infections: Tuberculosis, fungal infections
  • Autoimmune Disorders: Lupus, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Malignancies: Lymphoma, metastatic carcinoma

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Compatible clinical and radiographic presentation
  • Non-caseating granulomas on histopathology
  • Exclusion of other granulomatous diseases

 

Tuberculosis (TB) (Option B): TB can cause fever, night sweats, and hilar lymphadenopathy but typically presents with cough and hemoptysis, which are not mentioned in this case. Facial nerve palsy is rare in TB unless there is extensive dissemination, which is unusual in early stages.

Lymphoma (Option C): Lymphoma can present with fever, night sweats, and hilar lymphadenopathy. However, it is less likely to cause bilateral facial nerve palsy and ptosis as part of its presentation. Lymphoma would typically involve lymph node enlargement and may present with systemic symptoms, but it is usually not associated with granulomatous inflammation seen in sarcoidosis.

Hypersensitive pneumonitis (Option D): Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis) is caused by an immune response to inhaled antigens and primarily affects the lungs, leading to symptoms like dyspnea, cough, and fever. However, it does not typically cause bilateral facial nerve palsy or hilar lymphadenopathy, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: Irregular pitting of nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is seen in ___________.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Psoriasis

Explanation:

  • Nail Features in Psoriasis:
    • Irregular pitting of nails (small depressions in the nail plate)
    • Subungual hyperkeratosis (thickening under the nail)
    • Onycholysis (nail separation from the bed)
    • Oil drop sign (yellow-brown discoloration)
  • Psoriasis Nail Involvement:
    • Seen in 10-55% of psoriasis cases
    • More common in psoriatic arthritis

Nail Changes in Different Dermatological Conditions

 

Condition

Nail Changes

Psoriasis

Irregular pitting, subungual hyperkeratosis, oil drop sign, onycholysis, splinter hemorrhages

Lichen Planus

Pterygium formation (wing-shaped scar), nail thinning, ridging, longitudinal striations

Atopic Dermatitis

Shiny, brittle nails, exaggerated longitudinal ridging

Alopecia Areata

Regular, geometric pitting, trachyonychia (rough, sandpaper-like nails)

 

Lichen Planus (Option A): Incorrect because it causes longitudinal ridging, pterygium formation, and thinning, but not pitting.

Atopic Dermatitis (Option C): Incorrect because nail changes are uncommon; if present, they show ridging and brittle nails, not pitting.

Alopecia Areata (Option D): Incorrect because it has regular, geometric nail pitting, unlike psoriasis, which is irregular.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Consolidation with air bronchogram

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with fever, breathlessness, cough with expectoration, and the CT scan findings of consolidation with an air bronchogram strongly suggest a pneumonic consolidation due to lobar pneumonia

Clinical manifestations of Lobar pneumonia:

  • Common Symptoms:
    • Fever
    • Cough
    • Sputum production (often mucopurulent)
    • Pleuritic chest pain (Localized pleuritic pain is common, especially in lobar pneumonia)
  • Constitutional Symptoms: Fatigue, headache, myalgia, and arthralgias may occur.
  • Severe pneumonia can lead to:
    • Dyspnea.
    • Confusion, sepsis, and multi-organ failure.
  • Clinical Signs:
    • Tachypnea (increased respiratory rate)
    • Increased vocal fremitus
    • Egophony (E to A changes)
    • Dullness to percussion
  • Auscultation Findings: Presence of crackles or rales, and bronchial breath sounds (tubular type breathing).

Investigation

Findings

Initial Evaluation
  • Clinical suspicion based on patient history and physical examination.

Chest Radiography
  • The most important initial test for pneumonia diagnosis.
  • Shows pulmonary infiltrate; indicates type (lobar, interstitial, unilateral, or bilateral).
  • Cannot reliably differentiate between bacterial and non-bacterial causes.

CT Scan
  • More accurate than a chest X-ray.
  • Focal dense opacification of an entire lobe occurs, with relative sparing of the large airways. Associated findings may include ground-glass opacities in a lobar or segmental pattern, indicating areas of partial involvement or atelectasis.
  • Image shows left upper lung lobe consolidation of heterogenous density, with multiple air bronchograms, and small left pleural effusion

Laboratory Tests
  • Complete Blood Count (CBC):
    • Look for leukocytosis (leftward shift) as a sign of infection.
    • Leukopenia may indicate a poor prognosis.
  • Inflammatory Biomarkers: ESR and acute phase reactants to assess severity.

Sputum Analysis
  • Sputum Gram stain and culture critical for suspected lobar pneumonia.
  • Sputum culture is the most specific diagnostic test for identifying the causative organism.

Influenza Testing
  • Recommended during winter months due to the risk of co-infection with pneumonia.

Patient Stratification
  • Use CURB-65 and the pneumonia severity index to determine hospitalization needs.

Additional Testing
  • Hospitalized patients: sputum culture, blood culture, and/or urine antigen testing before antibiotics.

Invasive Procedures
  • Thoracocentesis, bronchoscopy, pleural biopsy, and pleural fluid culture are rarely performed.
  • Open lung biopsy is the ultimate specific diagnostic test.

 

Mediastinal mass (Option B):

  • A mediastinal mass typically presents with symptoms like chest pain, dyspnea, and cough but not with classic symptoms of pneumonia like fever and cough with expectoration.
  • On CT, a mediastinal mass appears as a localized area of mass effect in one of the mediastinal compartments.

 

Pleural effusion (Option C):

  • Pleural effusion would appear on CT as a fluid-filled space in the pleural cavity and does not cause consolidation with air bronchograms.
  • Breathlessness is common in pleural effusion, but the characteristic CT finding would be a homogenous opacity in the pleural space.

 

Diaphragmatic hernia (Option D): A diaphragmatic hernia would show up on CT as an abnormal position of abdominal organs (such as the stomach or bowel) in the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with hair loss for the past three months. She tested positive for COVID-19 eight months ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Telogen Effluvium

Explanation:

  • History of COVID-19:
    • The patient had COVID-19 eight months ago, a known trigger for telogen effluvium.
    • Telogen effluvium is a stress-induced hair loss condition occurring 2-3 months after a triggering event.
  • Clinical Features of Telogen Effluvium:
    • Diffuse, non-scarring hair loss
    • Increased hair shedding during combing/washing
    • Resolves spontaneously in 6-12 months

 

Telogen Effluvium

Feature

Telogen Effluvium

Trigger

Stress, infection (COVID-19), surgery, postpartum, drugs

Onset

2-3 months after stressor

Hair Loss Pattern

Diffuse thinning, shedding >100 hairs/day

Scalp Examination

Normal, no inflammation or scarring

Prognosis

Self-limiting, resolves in 6-12 months
