Tinea Capitis (Option A): Incorrect because it presents with patchy hair loss, scaling, and inflammation, often with black dot hairs.

Trichotillomania (Option C): Incorrect because it causes irregular patches of broken hair due to self-induced pulling.

Female Pattern Androgenetic Alopecia (Option D): Incorrect because it has a gradual onset with hair thinning in the central scalp, without sudden shedding.

questions.text: A female patient with a body mass index of 30 kg/m2 presents to you with a lesion on the neck, as shown below. Which of the following conditions is the most likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metabolic Syndrome

Explanation:

  • Clinical Presentation:
    • The image shows velvety, hyperpigmented thickening of the skin, likely Acanthosis Nigricans (AN).
    • It is commonly seen in patients with obesity (BMI 30 kg/m²) and insulin resistance.
  • Metabolic Syndrome Association:
    • Acanthosis nigricans is strongly linked to insulin resistance, which is a key component of metabolic syndrome.
    • Metabolic Syndrome = Central obesity + Insulin resistance + Hypertension + Dyslipidemia.

 

Metabolic Syndrome & Acanthosis Nigricans

Feature

Metabolic Syndrome

Key Components

Insulin resistance, obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia

Clinical Signs

Acanthosis nigricans, central obesity, skin tags

Pathophysiology

Chronic hyperinsulinemia stimulates epidermal growth, leading to Acanthosis Nigricans

Associated Risks

Type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease

Management

Lifestyle changes (weight loss, exercise), Metformin

 

Hypothyroidism (Option A): Incorrect because it causes dry skin, myxedema, and weight gain, but not Acanthosis Nigricans.

Addison’s Disease (Option C): Incorrect because it causes generalized hyperpigmentation due to ACTH excess, not localized velvety thickening.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option D): Incorrect because it presents with hypercalcemia, bone pain, and kidney stones, but not Acanthosis Nigricans.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the telomerase theory of ageing:

choices.text: Telomere stability is associated with ageing
Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with ageing
Decreased telomere length is associated with ageing
Increased telomere length is associated with ageing

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Decreased telomere length is associated with ageing

  • Telomerase theory of ageing is based on the idea that telomere length is a biological marker of ageing, i.e., the theory suggests that telomeres shorten as cells divide, which can lead to cellular senescence and this process can contribute to the ageing process and the onset of age-related diseases. (Option D ruled out)
  • Telomerase, also known as the immortality gene, is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase enzyme that adds DNA sequences to the ends of chromosomes, preventing telomere shortening during cell division.
  • However, telomerase activity decreases with age in most somatic cells, contributing to telomeres inevitable shortening over time.
  • When telomeres become too short and reach a critical length, they can no longer effectively protect chromosomes, leading to genomic instability and eventually triggering cell death or senescence.

Telomere stability is associated with ageing (Option A): Telomere stability refers to maintaining the length of telomeres, which are protective caps at the ends of chromosomes. As we age, telomeres shorten rather than remain stable, which is a key factor in cellular ageing, not stability.

Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with ageing (Option B): Abnormal telomerase activation is more commonly associated with cancer (where cells avoid normal ageing and continue to divide) rather than the ageing process itself. In ageing, telomerase activity tends to decline, not increase.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient is undergoing tooth extraction for dental caries. Which of the following does not require prophylaxis against infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atrial septal defect

Explanation:

  • Atrial septal defect (ASD) is a congenital heart defect; however, it is generally not considered a high-risk condition for infective endocarditis unless there are other complicating factors, such as a significant shunt or right-sided heart failure.

Infective Endocarditis (IE)

  • Infective endocarditis (IE) is a bacterial or fungal infection of the endocardial surface of the heart, typically affecting the heart valves.
  • Prophylaxis against infective endocarditis is recommended before certain invasive procedures (like dental extractions) for patients at high risk of developing this condition.

Indications for Prophylaxis in Infective Endocarditis:

High-Risk Patients:

  • Prosthetic heart valves (mechanical/bioprosthetic) (Option D)
  • History of infective endocarditis (Option A)
  • Congenital heart disease (CHD):
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD (Option C)
    • Repaired CHD with prosthetic material (first 6 months)
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with valvulopathy

Procedures Requiring Prophylaxis:

  • Dental: Extractions, periodontal surgery, root canal, dental implants
  • Respiratory: Tonsillectomy, adenoidectomy, bronchoscopy with biopsy
  • GI/GU: Endoscopy with biopsy, colonoscopy, cystoscopy (high-risk patients)

Prophylaxis Regimen:

  • Amoxicillin: 2 grams orally, 30–60 minutes before
  • Alternative (Penicillin allergic):
    • Clindamycin: 600 mg orally
    • Azithromycin: 500 mg orally

Causes of Infective endocarditis

Condition

Most Common Organism

Community-acquired native valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Healthcare-associated native valve endocarditis

Streptococci

Endocarditis in injection drug users (Right side)

Staphylococcus aureus

Endocarditis in injection drug users (Left side)

Staphylococcus aureus

Most common organism causing prosthetic valve endocarditis

Enterococci and Staphylococcus aureus

Most common group of organisms causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery)

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS)

Late prosthetic valve endocarditis (>12 months after surgery)

Streptococci

Acute infective endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Subacute infective endocarditis

Streptococcus viridans

Cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED)-associated endocarditis

Enterococci and Coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS)

Culture-negative endocarditis

HACEK organisms

Coxiella burnetii

Bartonella

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and abdominal pain. There is a history of delayed growth and bone problems causing facial changes. On examination, he had icterus and mild splenomegaly. Electrophoresis is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Beta thalassemia

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation described, with recurrent chest infections, abdominal pain, delayed growth, bone problems, icterus, and mild splenomegaly, points towards a hemoglobinopathy, and the electrophoresis showing high HbA is also consistent with Beta-thalassemia.
  • Thalassemia is a genetic disorder affecting haemoglobin production and causing microcytic, hypochromic anemia.
  • Hemoglobin consists of two alpha (α) and two beta (β) chains, and mutations in the genes responsible for these chains lead to alpha or beta thalassemia, inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • Beta thalassemia is caused by mutations in the HBB gene on chromosome 11, affecting β chain production. The severity depends on whether one or both β genes are mutated:
    • Beta Thalassemia Trait (β-thalassemia minor) (1 mutated gene)
    • Beta Thalassemia Intermedia (2 mutated genes with partial function)
    • Beta Thalassemia Major (β0-thalassemia) (2 mutated genes, with complete absence of β chain production)

Beta Thalassemias

Major (Transfusion-dependent)

Intermedia (Non-transfusion-dependent)

Minor (Trait or Carrier)

Genotype

Homozygous:

  • β⁰/β⁰
  • β⁰/β⁺
  • β⁺/β⁺

Variable:

  • β⁰/β⁺ or β⁺/β⁺ or β⁰/β or β⁺/β

Heterozygous:

  • β⁰/β or β⁺/β

Laboratory Findings

Severe microcytic anemia with target cells (Hb 3–4 g/dL)

Moderate microcytic anemia

Mild microcytic anemia

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis
  • HbA₂ (5% or more);
  • HbF (up to 95%); No HbA
  • HbA₂ (4% or more);
  • HbF (up to 50%)
  • HbA₂ (4% or more);
  • HbF (up to 5%)

HbC disease (Option B) results in mild hemolysis splenomegaly and usually presents with milder symptoms compared to beta-thalassemia. Electrophoresis in HbC disease would reveal elevated levels of HbC, not HbA, and affected individuals generally experience normal growth and development.

Sickle cell disease (Option C) is caused by a mutation in the beta-globin gene, leading to the production of HbS (sickle haemoglobin). The electrophoresis in this condition would show a predominant HbS peak.

Acute coronary disease (Option D) is a cardiovascular condition that primarily affects adults. This condition would present with chest pain, shortness of breath, and EKG changes rather than jaundice, splenomegaly, and bone deformities. The patient described here is a child, making ACS an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of ten tablets of paracetamol. He has developed oliguria, and liver function tests show deranged values. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) N-acetylcysteine

Explanation:

  • The patient’s history of paracetamol ingestion, along with oliguria and deranged liver function tests, is highly suggestive of paracetamol toxicity. The treatment of choice is N-acetylcysteine (NAC).

Acetaminophen (Paracetamol) Toxicity

Leading cause of acute liver failure.

  • Toxic Dose: ≥25g can be fatal.
  • Clinical Presentation: Oliguria, deranged liver function tests.

Mechanism of Toxicity:

  • Metabolism: Acetaminophen is metabolized by cytochrome P450 (CYP2E1) to N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone-imine (NAPQI).
  • Toxicity: In overdose, glutathione stores are depleted, preventing detoxification of NAPQI.

Management:

Antidote: N-acetylcysteine (NAC).

  • Action: Replenishes glutathione stores.
  • Timing: Most effective within 8 hours; partial protection up to 36 hours.

Severe cases: Liver transplantation if hepatic failure persists despite NAC therapy.

questions.text:
A pregnant lady with 34 weeks of gestation presented to the OPD with the following lab reports: LDH- 700 IU/L, Platelets – 75,000/mm3, Serum bilirubin- 1.5mg/dL, SGOT-200 U/L, SGPT-150U/L, and BP -140/96 mm Hg. Her coagulation profile and renal function tests are normal. What is the diagnosis?

LDH- Lactate dehydrogenase

SGOT- Serum glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminase / AST- Aspartate transaminase

SGPT- Serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase / ALT- Alanine transaminase
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HELLP syndrome

Explanation:

  • In this situation, the patient had considerably increased LDH levels and a lower platelet count, which point to hemolysis and thrombocytopenia, respectively. Furthermore, liver damage, a common finding in HELLP syndrome, is indicated by the elevated SGOT and SGPT levels.

HELLP Syndrome:

Rare complication of Preeclampsia, which usually occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy

Features:

  • H- Hemolysis
  • EL- Elevated Liver enzymes
  • LP- Low Platelets

Risk factors:

  • HELLP in prior pregnancy, age >35, multiparous, history of diabetes, kidney disease

Symptoms:

  • RUQ pain, headache, blurred vision, nausea, vomiting, edema

Maternal complications:

  • Blood clotting problems, DIC
  • Kidney failure
  • Liver failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia

Fetal complications:

  • Preterm birth
  • Growth restriction
  • Respiratory distress

Treatment:

  • Majority of patients develop eclampsia- MgSO4 to prevent seizures
  • Antihypertensives to control BP
  • If <34 weeks, Corticosteroids for lung maturity
  • Definitive treatment: Termination of pregnancy

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (Option B) is unlikely because ALT and AST levels are significantly elevated in acute fatty liver, and LDH levels are typically normal. Although platelet count may be low, it does not drop as low as in HELLP syndrome. Additionally, hypertension is not a common feature of this condition.

Viral hepatitis (Option C) is unlikely as there are no specific viral markers or hepatitis-related symptoms, and platelet counts in viral hepatitis typically remain normal or minimally altered.

Intrahepatic cholestasis (Option D) is unlikely because LDH levels are typically normal, while bilirubin levels are higher in cholestasis, which also presents with severe itching—features not observed in this patient. Additionally, cholestasis does not typically present with hypertension.

questions.text: Why do neoplastic cells utilise Warburg metabolism?

choices.text: It decreases glucose utilization by neoplastic cells
It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication
It provides more energy in the form of increased ATP production
It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer immortal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It forms metabolic intermediates which are needed for cell growth and multiplication

  • The Warburg effect is a distinct metabolic feature of cancer cells, where, even in the presence of sufficient oxygen, cancer cells demonstrate a distinctive form of cellular metabolism characterised by high glucose uptake levels (Option A ruled out) and increased glucose conversion to lactose (fermentation) via glycolysis.
  • This shift does not increase ATP production but provides key metabolic intermediates needed for rapid cell growth and division. (Option C ruled out)
  • Otto Warburg was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1931 for this theory.
  • The Warburg effect is the basis of positive emission tomography (PET).
    • Patients are injected with 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG), a non-metabolizable glucose derivative preferentially taken up into tumour cells (due to glucose hunger), which can be detected by PET scan.

It prevents apoptosis and makes the cancer immortal (Option D): While Warburg metabolism can be linked to cellular survival and resistance to certain forms of stress, its primary function is not directly about preventing apoptosis or making the cell immortal. Instead, it helps meet the increased metabolic demands of rapidly proliferating cancer cells.

questions.text: A female patient with a negative urine pregnancy test presents to you with galactorrhea. An MRI was done, which revealed a large pituitary tumor. If the patient is not willing to undergo surgery, which of the following is the best drug for treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bromocriptine

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario is indicative of a prolactinoma—a benign pituitary tumor that results in excessive prolactin production, leading to symptoms such as galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility in women. The negative urine pregnancy test rules out pregnancy as a cause of galactorrhea.
  • In patients who are unwilling to undergo surgery, the first-line treatment is medical management with dopamine agonists, such as Bromocriptine (or cabergoline), which effectively lower prolactin levels and reduce tumor size.

Prolactinoma

A benign pituitary tumor secreting excess prolactin.

Cause

Mostly idiopathic; can be associated with MEN 1 or RET gene mutations.

Classification

Microadenomas: <1 cm, often asymptomatic.

Macroadenomas: >1 cm, may cause visual field defects, headaches, and neurological symptoms.

Symptoms

Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, infertility (women)

Erectile dysfunction, reduced libido (men)

Headaches, visual disturbances (e.g., bitemporal hemianopia, diplopia in large tumors).

Diagnosis

Elevated prolactin levels, MRI for tumor imaging.

Treatment

Dopamine agonists: Bromocriptine, Cabergoline (first-line) to reduce prolactin secretion and tumor size.

Cabergoline: Preferred; fewer side effects.

Surgical: If resistant to or intolerant of dopamine agonists, or with significant complications.

Radiotherapy: For resistant cases.

 

Promethazine (Option B) is an antihistamine used for motion sickness, pruritus, and nausea.

Octreotide (Option C) is a somatostatin analog primarily used for conditions like acromegaly, variceal bleeding, and hepatorenal syndrome.

Clozapine (Option D) is an atypical antipsychotic used in the treatment of refractory schizophrenia and severe mania.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the jugular venous pressure (JVP) finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Absent a wave

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario suggests atrial fibrillation (AF), a common arrhythmia with an irregularly irregular heartbeat, often accompanied by a fast heart rate (e.g., 120 beats/min). The pulse deficit of 20 indicates that not every atrial contraction is passed to the ventricles due to irregular conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node, meaning some atrial beats are not followed by ventricular contractions.

Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke

ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

JVP

Absent a wave

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure.
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail.
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention.
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours; anticoagulation required if AF ≥48 hours.
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.

Thromboprophylaxis

  • Anticoagulation: Required for stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium.
    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion.
    • DOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed.
  • Risk Assessment:
    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2.
    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.
  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke.

 

CHA2DS2-VASc stroke risk scoring system for AF

Points

Parameters

Score

C

Congestive heart failure

1

H

Hypertension history

1

A2

Age (≥75 years)

2

D

Diabetes mellitus

1

S2

Previous stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA)

2

V

Vascular disease

1

A

Age (65-74 years)

1

Sc

Sex category (female)

1

 

Maximum total score

9 points

 

Management option for AF as per CHA2DS2-VASc score

  • 0: need not anticoagulate
  • 1: Give aspirin
  • >=2: Warfarin/Dabigatran/Rivaroxaban

 

Absent p wave (Option A): This is a characteristic ECG finding in atrial fibrillation. The absence of the P wave on ECG signifies that there is no organized atrial contraction, which leads to the irregularly irregular ventricular rhythm.

Cannon a wave (Option C): Cannon a waves occur in atrioventricular (AV) dissociation, where the atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve, leading to a large, prominent a wave.

Raised JVP with normal waveform (Option D): A raised JVP with a normal waveform is typically seen in conditions like congestive heart failure, right ventricular infarction, or superior vena cava obstruction. In atrial fibrillation, the JVP may be raised, but the waveform will not be normal.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents for routine evaluation. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 24 weeks. Ultrasonography revealed decreased amniotic fluid. Which of the following conditions would have led to this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Renal agenesis

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with low fundal height and decreased amniotic fluid, which points to oligohydramnios. The most common cause of oligohydramnios at 26 weeks, especially with a noticeable lag in fundal height, is renal agenesis. In this condition, the absence of kidneys leads to a lack of fetal urine production, which is the main contributor to amniotic fluid in the second and third trimesters.

Criteria

Threshold

Amniotic Fluid Volume

Normal: 500–2000 mL

Oligohydramnios: <500 mL

Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI)

≤ 5 cm

Single Deepest Vertical Pocket (SDVP)

≤ 2 cm

 

Causes of Oligohydramnios and Polyhydramnios

Category

Polyhydramnios

Oligohydramnios

Fetal Anomalies

Anencephaly

Renal agenesis

Esophageal atresia

Posterior urethral valves

Duodenal atresia

Ureteral stricture

Tracheoesophageal fistula

Fetal growth restriction (IUGR)

Twin-Related

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (recipient twin)

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (donor twin)

Maternal Conditions

Diabetes mellitus

Maternal hypertension

Hypothyroidism

Preeclampsia

 

Autoimmune diseases (e.g., SLE) affecting renal perfusion

Placental Factors

Chorioangioma

Placental insufficiency

Placental abruption

Genetic/Metabolic

Bartter syndrome (salt-wasting nephropathy causing fetal polyuria)

_

Growth/Development

Hydrops fetalis

Post-term pregnancy

 

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Opinion B) is characterized by a defect between the trachea and the esophagus. Oligohydramnios is unlikely to result from it.

Cardiac abnormalities (Option C): Some cardiac conditions, such as aortic stenosis or hypoplastic left heart syndrome, might reduce the amount of blood that reaches the placenta and result in oligohydramnios. But typically, this shows up earlier in pregnancy.

Ureteral Stricture (Option D) is a constriction of the ureter, which can lead to hydronephrosis or kidney swelling as a result of a urine backup. This often manifests early in pregnancy, however it can result in oligohydramnios.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with anemia and hemoglobinuria. Investigations reveal increased bilirubin and lactate dehydrogenase. The peripheral smear image is given below. Which of the following is associated with this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Mechanical second heart valve

  • Given the context of anaemia, the other findings, along with the peripheral smear showing fragmented red blood cells such as schistocytes, the most likely diagnosis is microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, which could be seen in conditions like mechanical heart valves or hemolytic uremic syndrome.
  • Mechanical heart valves can cause intravascular hemolysis due to the turbulence of blood flow around the valve, leading to red blood cell fragmentation, hemoglobinuria, increased bilirubin, and elevated LDH.

Schistocytes in Peripheral smear

Splenomegaly (Option A) is commonly associated with chronic hemolytic anaemias. However, in this case, the key features are hemoglobinuria, increased bilirubin, and elevated LDH, which point more toward mechanical hemolysis and typically don't cause splenic enlargement.

Increased HbA2 (Option C) is a hallmark of beta-thalassemia, a genetic disorder of haemoglobin production, where the production of normal beta-globin chains is reduced, leading to an increase in the relative amount of HbA2. However, beta-thalassemia does not cause hemoglobinuria or the other signs of acute hemolysis described in this case.

Goitre (Option D) refers to an enlarged thyroid gland, and it is typically associated with thyroid disorders. The patient’s symptoms and lab results point toward a haematological problem, specifically hemolysis, which would not be linked to a thyroid disorder like goitre.

questions.text: A type 1 diabetic mother is on magnesium sulfate infusion post-cesarean section for preeclampsia. She develops delirium and is drowsy. She has a respiratory rate of 10/min, a random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL, oliguria, and bilaterally absent knee reflex. What is the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Magnesium sulfate toxicity

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with signs suggestive of magnesium sulfate toxicity, including delirium, drowsiness, absent knee reflexes, oliguria, and a low respiratory rate. Magnesium sulfate is commonly used to prevent seizures in eclamptic patients, but excessive levels can lead to toxicity."

 

Magnesium Sulfate Toxicity

  • Monitor magnesium sulfate toxicity by observing deep tendon reflexes, respiratory status, and urine output (primarily excreted by kidneys)
  • Impaired kidney function can lead to toxicity. Loss of patellar reflexes at ~12 mg/dL is an early warning sign.

 

Serum Magnesium Testing:

  • Routine testing is not recommended.
  • Test 4-6 hours after starting infusion to adjust rate (target: 4-7 mEq/L or 4.8-8.4 mg/dL).
  • Elevated serum creatinine (≥1.0 mg/dL) to assess kidney function.
  • Check for toxicity signs (diminished reflexes, breathing issues) to confirm diagnosis and guide treatment. Administer fluids cautiously to avoid overload and pulmonary edema.

 

Adverse Effects of Magnesium Sulfate

Mechanism:

  • Acts as a smooth muscle relaxant.

Serum Magnesium Level

Effect

5–9 mg/dL

Therapeutic range

9 mg/dL

Loss of patellar reflexes

12 mg/dL

Respiratory depression occurs at ~12 mEq/L (14.4 mg/dL) due to muscle paralysis

30 mg/dL

Cardiac arrest

 

Management of Magnesium Toxicity:

Immediate Actions:

  • Administer 10 mL 10% calcium gluconate IV over 3 minutes to reverse mild to moderate respiratory depression.
  • Discontinue magnesium sulfate.

 

Further Steps:

  • Administer furosemide to increase urinary excretion.
  • Severe respiratory depression requires intubation and mechanical ventilation.
  • The effects of IV calcium may be short-lived if steady-state toxicity is present.

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Septate hymen

Explanation:

  • The given image is suggestive of septate hymen, characterized by two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue.
  • The hymen is the membranous remnant of the junction between the sinovaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus, which normally perforates during fetal life to form the vaginal lumen.
  • When this structure fails to perforate completely, it results in different variants of hymen.

Hymen Type

Clinical Presentation

Treatment

Imperforate (Option A)
  • Menarche with cyclic pain, and amenorrhea.
  • Abdominal pain.
  • Cryptomenorrhea: Menstrual blood is produced but not expelled from the body.
  • Hematocolpos: Bulging, bluish membrane at the introitus.
  • Hematometra: Accumulation of menstrual blood in the uterus.
  • Hematosalpinx: Accumulation of blood in the fallopian tubes.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Transverse Vaginal septum -
    • Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts and urogenital sinus.
    • A fibrous band of tissue at various levels (low, mid, or high) that divides the vagina horizontally.
    • Normal external genitalia; vaginal examination reveals a membrane or band within the vagina on palpation.
    • Mx: Surgical resection of the septum.
  • Incision and drainage.
  • Avoid needle aspiration, as this can lead to infection.

Microperforate

Very small opening, which may cause menstrual irregularities or difficulty with tampon use.

Surgical incision followed by excision of the hymen.

Septate

 
  • Band of tissue dividing the vaginal opening
  • Dyspareunia.
  • If one side of a septate vagina is obstructed, it can lead to mucocolpos or hematocolpos.

Excision.

Cribriform (sieve)

Multiple small openings allow for menstrual flow but often cause discomfort or difficulties with intercourse.

 

Annular (Option D)
  • Menstrual irregularities.
  • Difficulty in tampon placement/ intercourse.

 

Naviculare (boatlike)

Semilunar/ Crescentric (Option B)

  • Crescent-shaped opening, with tissue along the lower portion of the vaginal opening, leaving a large central opening.
  • Seen in Childhood/Adolescence.

questions.text: While discharging a patient who underwent a vesicovaginal fistula repair, which of the following would you recommend?

choices.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months
Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year
Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year

Explanation:

After a vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) repair, it is essential to give the body adequate time to heal and ensure the integrity of the surgical repair. The following recommendations are generally advised:

  • Sexual abstinence for 3 months: This allows the surgical site to heal completely and reduces the risk of disrupting the repair during sexual activity.
  • Avoid pregnancy for a year: Pregnancy places significant pressure on the pelvic organs, which could jeopardize the success of the repair and increase the risk of fistula recurrence. A year of abstinence from pregnancy ensures proper healing and reduces the risk of complications during subsequent pregnancies.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET) are true, except?

choices.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis
It is produced in response to bacterial infection
It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Mitochondrial DNA is seen

  • Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are often detected in the blood during sepsis (Option A ruled out), and though mitochondrial DNA might be released in some inflammatory conditions, the main component of NETs is chromatin (nuclear DNA), not mitochondrial DNA.

Neutrophil extracellular traps:

  • They are produced by neutrophils in response to infectious pathogens (mainly bacteria and fungi) and inflammatory mediators (e.g., chemokines, cytokines, complement proteins, and ROS), their presence can be used as a biomarker for sepsis. (Option B ruled out)
  • NET formation starts with ROS-dependent activation of an arginine deaminase that converts arginine to citrulline, leading to chromatin decondensation.
  • NETs are composed of nuclear chromatin and various granule proteins, including antimicrobial peptides and enzymes that help to neutralise and kill pathogens trapped within the NETs. (Option D ruled out)
  • Activated neutrophils release histones into the extracellular space which helps to unwind and release the DNA, allowing it to combine with granule proteins and form the characteristic web-like structure of NETs.
  • NETs do not directly phagocytose or engulf the invading pathogens. Instead, they trap pathogens within their structure, immobilizing them and allowing other immune cells, such as macrophages, to recognize and eliminate them.
  • The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, including histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly lupus, in which individuals react against their DNA and nucleoproteins.

A neutrophil granulocyte (yellow) has ejected a NET (green) to capture bacteria (purple). A red blood cell (orange) is also trapped in the NET.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for inserting the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Trophoblastic disease

Explanation:

The image depicts a copper-containing intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD). An absolute contraindication for its insertion is trophoblastic disease.

Trophoblastic disease (such as hydatidiform mole or choriocarcinoma) involves abnormal growth of the trophoblastic tissue, which can invade the uterine wall. The presence of this disease increases the risk of complications when inserting an IUCD, including:

  • Uterine perforation
  • Misplacement of the device
  • Excessive bleeding

Contraindications for IUCD insertion
  • Trophoblastic disease
  • Distorted uterine cavity (fibroids, uterine anomalies)
  • Ongoing pelvic infection
  • Undiagnosed genital tract bleeding
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Severe dysmenorrhea
  • STIs - current or recurrent
  • Wilson disease (for copper IUCDs)
  • Breast cancer (for hormone-containing IUCDs)

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritis. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed a neutrophil count of 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of abdominal distension, jaundice, pruritus, and a neutrophil count >250/mm³ in ascitic fluid strongly suggests Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP).

Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP)

Description

A severe complication of ascites, characterised by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intra-abdominal source.

Causative organism
  • Escherichia coli (most common) and other gut bacteria.
  • Gram-positive bacteria (Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus, and Enterococcus)

Source of infection

Clinical features
  • Worsening of ascites
  • Fever, nausea, vomiting
  • Increase in abdominal girth
  • Encephalopathy

Diagnosis

Ascitic fluid analysis shows:

  • Turbid appearance

 

  • Neutrophil count >250/μL
  • Culture and gram satins reveal the causative organisms

Management

IV 3rd generation cephalosporins (cefotaxime) for 5 days

Prevention

  • Paracentesis within 12 hours of hospital admission
  • Norfloxacin administration (cirrhotic patients with an episode of SBP)
  • Quinolone antibiotic prophylaxis (recurrent episodes of SBP in variceal bleeding).

 

Malignant Ascites (Option B): Caused by abdominal or extra-abdominal malignancies, with ascitic fluid showing high levels of VEGF or tumor markers and a milky or bloody appearance.

Tubercular Ascites (Option C): Associated with tuberculous peritonitis, with exudative ascitic fluid, high protein levels, and lymphocytic predominance.

Intestinal Obstruction (Option D): Unlikely due to the absence of symptoms like vomiting or cessation of bowel movements.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman is evaluated for primary infertility. Hysterosalpingography was done and reveals the findings shown below. What is the anomaly seen in the image?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Septate uterus

Explanation:

  • The anomaly shown in the hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is indicative of a septate uterus, which is a congenital anomaly caused by the failure of the medial segments of the Müllerian ducts to regress completely. This results in the presence of a fibrous or fibromuscular septum within the uterine cavity.

 

Features of a septate uterus on HSG include:

  • Narrowly spaced and widely diverging horns.
  • Intercornual angle <75° (a key distinguishing feature from other anomalies).
  • A normal external contour of the uterus (as opposed to a bicornuate uterus, which has an indented fundal contour).

Müllerian Uterine Anomaly

Description

Clinical Presentation

Treatment

Septate Uterus

Incomplete resorption of the septum between the Müllerian ducts, resulting in a fibrous septum within the uterine cavity.

Recurrent first-trimester miscarriages, Infertility.

  • DD: Bicornuate uterus has an intercomual angle >105 degrees during hysterosalpingography.

Hysteroscopic metroplasty to remove the septum.

Bicornuate Uterus (Option C)

Incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts, leading to a heart-shaped uterus with two cavities.

Higher incidence of infertility, endometriosis, and dysmenorrhea.

  • Requires 3D USG/ MRI to differentiate from Septate Uterus

Metroplasty in severe cases. Often managed conservatively.

Didelphys Uterus (Option B)

Complete non-fusion of the Müllerian ducts, two separate uteri, and often two cervices.

Preterm labor, Menstrual irregularities.

Managed conservatively, Metroplasty if symptomatic.

Unicornuate Uterus - Noncommunicating

(Option D)

Partial development of one Müllerian duct, resulting in a single-horned uterus.

Cyclic pelvic pain may be misdiagnosed as an adnexal mass.

Ectopic pregnancy, Preterm labor

Prophylactic cerclage placement or progesterone supplementation to prevent preterm birth.

Arcuate Uterus

Mild indentation at the top of the uterine cavity due to minor incomplete resorption of the septum.

Generally asymptomatic and normal reproductive outcomes.

Reassurance and conservative management.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with no other comorbid conditions develops preeclampsia. She enquires about the cause of her condition. The doctor explains that it is due to the failure of the invasion of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Spiral artery by extravillous trophoblasts

Explanation:

  • Preeclampsia is caused by the failure of the invasion of extravillous trophoblasts into the spiral arteries, leading to incomplete remodeling of these vessels.

 

Normal Physiology of Spiral Artery Remodeling:

  • The spiral arteries supply blood to the endometrium.
  • During pregnancy, extravillous trophoblasts (particularly endovascular trophoblasts) invade the walls of the spiral arteries in two waves:
    1. First wave (10–12 weeks): Invades up to the decidual segments of the spiral arteries.
    2. Second wave (16–18 weeks): Invades up to the myometrial segments of the spiral arteries.
  • This remodeling replaces the endothelial lining and the muscular wall with trophoblastic tissue, transforming the arteries into a low-resistance, high-flow system required for optimal placental perfusion.

 

Pathophysiology in Preeclampsia:

  • Failure of the second wave of trophoblastic invasion results in inadequate remodeling of the spiral arteries.
  • This leads to high resistance and reduced blood flow to the placenta, causing placental ischemia and the release of antiangiogenic factors into the maternal circulation.
  • These factors contribute to systemic endothelial dysfunction, hypertension, and organ damage characteristic of preeclampsia.

 

Feature

Normal Pregnancy

Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension (PIH)

Placentation
  • Extravillous trophoblasts invade the spiral arteries of the uterus around week 20.
  • This invasion widens the spiral arteries.
  • The widening enhances blood flow to the placenta.
  • This is known as secondary placentation.
  • Incomplete invasion of the spiral arteries by extravillous trophoblasts.
  • Persistent narrow vessels with reduced blood flow and placental ischemia.

Immune Response

T-helper 2 cells dominate, promoting humoral immunity and tolerance of the fetal antigens.
  • A shift towards T-helper 1 cell activity.
  • Increasing the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, γ-interferon, IL-2).
  • Contributing to endothelial dysfunction.

Endothelial Function

Maintains normal vascular tone and permeability, regulating blood flow and preventing inappropriate clotting.

Endothelial cells become dysfunctional, leading to vasoconstriction, increased permeability (edema), and activation of the coagulation cascade.

Angiogenic Balance
  • Pro-angiogenic factors (VEGF, PlGF, TGF-β) promote blood vessel growth.
  • Anti-angiogenic factors (sFlt-1, sEng) inhibit blood vessel growth.
  • A balance between these factors is essential for proper placental development and function.
  • Imbalance occurs with elevated production of anti-angiogenic factors (sFlt-1, sEng).
  • Reduced levels of pro-angiogenic factors are observed.
  • sFlt-1 binds to and deactivates VEGF and PlGF.
  • sEng inhibits TGF-β signaling.
  • This imbalance leads to endothelial dysfunction and impaired angiogenesis

Blood Pressure

Blood pressure remains within the normal range due to the vasodilatory effects of pregnancy hormones
  • Hypertension occurs after 20 weeks of pregnancy, characterized by blood pressure over 140/90 mmHg.
  • It results from vasoconstriction, endothelial dysfunction, and heightened sensitivity to vasopressors.

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G2P1 comes to the clinic at 14 weeks of gestation for her antenatal checkup. A uterine artery Doppler was suggested by the doctor. What would it detect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Early-onset preeclampsia

Explanation:

  • A uterine artery Doppler is a non-invasive test used in early pregnancy to assess uteroplacental blood flow. It helps predict complications associated with impaired placentation, including early-onset preeclampsia and fetal growth restriction.

 

Mechanism:

  • In early pregnancy, trophoblastic invasion of maternal uterine vessels reduces vascular resistance, ensuring adequate blood flow to the developing placenta.
  • Failure of this process results in high resistance in uterine arteries, which can be detected by Doppler studies.

 

Features Suggestive of Abnormal Uterine Doppler:

  • Diastolic notch: Indicates increased resistance to blood flow.
  • Elevated resistance index in the second trimester: Associated with a sixfold increase in the risk of preeclampsia.

 

Implications:

  • Early-onset preeclampsia is strongly associated with impaired trophoblastic invasion. It is often detected by abnormal uterine artery Doppler findings.

 

Additional Screening Tests for Preeclampsia:

  1. Mean arterial pressure (MAP) ≥90 mmHg in the second trimester.
  2. Umbilical artery Doppler: Absence of end-diastolic flow frequencies may indicate placental insufficiency.
  3. Biochemical markers: Placental growth factor (PIGF) and soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFLT-1) ratio.
  4. Roll-over test: Now rarely used but historically indicated the risk of gestational hypertension.

 

Late-onset preeclampsia (Option B) is typically associated with maternal metabolic and cardiovascular factors rather than abnormal uterine Doppler findings.

While uterine artery Doppler abnormalities are also seen in fetal growth restriction (Option C), this test is not the primary one used in early pregnancy.

Placenta accreta (Option D) involves abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall and is diagnosed using ultrasonography or MRI, not Doppler studies.

questions.text: A patient underwent a cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Malakoplakia

  • The patient's cystoscopy findings of yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone and the histopathological finding of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are characteristic of malakoplakia.
  • It is a rare inflammatory condition often seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with chronic immunosuppression following organ transplants.

Malakoplakia

Common Pathogen

Escherichia coli (most common), other Gram-negative bacteria

Histopathology

Von Hansemann cells (large, foamy histiocytes) with Michaelis-Gutmann bodies (PAS-positive inclusions).

Characteristic Inclusions

Michaelis-Gutmann bodies (basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions)

Staining

Positive staining with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS), von Kossa, and Perl’s stains

Associated Conditions

Immunocompromised states, such as organ transplantation, HIV, diabetes, malignancy

Organ Involvement

Predominantly genitourinary tract, but can affect multiple organ systems

Treatment

Antibiotics (fluoroquinolones, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), possible surgical excision

Prognosis

Requires treatment; may lead to complications if untreated; variable course with potential relapses.

Interstitial cystitis (Option A) is a chronic condition characterised by bladder pain, urgency, and frequency, often without any specific histopathological features like Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. The cystoscopy shows hunters’ ulcers or small bladder capacity but does not have yellow-white plaques.

Polypoid cystitis (Option C) condition involves benign inflammatory polyps, usually caused by chronic irritation or infection, but it does not include Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

Acute cystitis (Option D) is a common urinary tract infection that presents with dysuria, frequency, and urgency. It does not cause the formation of yellow-white plaques or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Obstructive jaundice

Explanation:

  • The laboratory findings of elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) with normal liver enzyme levels (AST, ALT) strongly suggest obstructive jaundice.

Feature

Prehepatic Jaundice

(Option D)

Hepatic Jaundice

(Option C)

Posthepatic (Obstructive) Jaundice

Etiology
  • Hemolysis (e.g., hemolytic anemia, malaria) (Option B)
  • Sickle cell disease
  • G6PD deficiency
  • Liver diseases (e.g., viral hepatitis, cirrhosis, alcoholic liver disease)
  • Liver tumors
  • Drug-induced liver injury
  • Bile duct obstruction (e.g., gallstones, pancreatic cancer, cholangiocarcinoma, strictures, tumors)

Mechanism
  • Increased breakdown of red blood cells
  • Excessive bilirubin production
  • Impaired bilirubin conjugation and excretion due to liver dysfunction
  • Blocked bile flow
  • Accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in bloodstream

Clinical Features
  • Yellowing of skin and sclera
  • Anemia
  • Fatigue
  • Splenomegaly
  • Yellowing of skin and sclera
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Pruritus
  • Yellowing of skin and sclera
  • Pale stools
  • Dark urine
  • Pruritus
  • Hepatomegaly

Bilirubin

Elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin

Elevated unconjugated and conjugated (direct) bilirubin

Elevated conjugated (direct) bilirubin

Liver Enzyme Values
  • AST, ALT: Normal or slightly elevated
  • ALP: Normal
  • GGT: Normal
  • AST, ALT: Markedly elevated
  • ALP: Elevated
  • GGT: Elevated
  • AST, ALT: Mildly elevated
  • ALP: Markedly elevated
  • GGT: Elevated

Prothrombin time (PT)

Normal Prolonged PT

Prolonged PT

Prolonged PT

Urine

Normal or slightly dark urine due to excess urobilinogen

Dark urine (due to increased conjugated bilirubin)
  • Dark urine (due to conjugated bilirubin)
  • Pale stools (due to reduced bile excretion)

Hemolytic jaundice (Option B) results from excessive breakdown of red blood cells. It typically leads to an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, while alkaline phosphatase and liver enzymes remain normal because there is no bile duct obstruction or hepatocellular damage.

questions.text: While conducting a delivery, you perform the maneuver shown below. Following this, there is incomplete separation of the placenta and massive hemorrhage. What is your next step in management?

choices.text: Start oxytocin infusion and wait for spontaneous delivery of the placenta
Arrange for blood and use Crede's method for placental delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Manual removal of placenta

Explanation:

  • The maneuver depicted is the Brandt-Andrews maneuver, which is used for controlled cord traction during delivery of the placenta. In this case, incomplete separation of the placenta has occurred, leading to primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to retained placental tissue. Immediate manual removal of the placenta is indicated to control the hemorrhage.

 

Diagnosis of Retained Placenta

  • Defined as the failure to deliver the placenta within 30 minutes after the birth of the baby.
  • Causes:
    1. Simple Adherent Placenta: Normal implantation, but failure to separate.
    2. Lower Uterine Segment Constriction: Trapping of the placenta in the lower uterine segment.
    3. Morbidly Adherent Placenta: Abnormal placental adherence, including:
      • Placenta accreta (superficial invasion).
      • Placenta increta (invasion into myometrium).
      • Placenta percreta (invasion through the myometrium and into adjacent structures).

 

Immediate Action in Case of Hemorrhage

  1. Perform manual removal of the placenta.
  2. Inspect for retained fragments and ensure bleeding is controlled.

 

Role of Medications

 

Oxytocin infusion:

  • Useful in managing atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Ineffective in cases of retained placenta due to mechanical causes.

 

Supportive Measures

  • Blood transfusion and volume resuscitation for severe hemorrhage.

 

Types of PPH:

  • Primary PPH: Within 24 hours of delivery
    • Most common cause: Atonic PPH
  • Secondary PPH: After 24 hours of delivery to 12 weeks
    • Most common cause: Retained bits of placenta

 

Causes of Primary PPH

Cause

Description

Factors increasing risk

Uterine Atony (Most common)

The inability of the uterus to contract effectively after delivery leads to a soft and boggy uterus and continuous bleeding from the placental site.
  • Grand multiparity
  • Overdistension of the uterus: Multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, large baby Malnutrition, and anemia
  • Antepartum hemorrhage: Placenta previa and placental abruption
  • Prolonged labour
  • Anesthesia
  • Oxytocin use
  • Uterine malformations
  • Other factors: Obesity, h/o PPH, advanced maternal age (over 40 years), tocolytics and magnesium sulfate

Retained Tissue

Prevents proper uterine contraction, causing primary PPH with continued bleeding and incomplete contraction.

Although more commonly associated with secondary PPH, retained placental fragments can also be a cause of primary PPH.

Trauma to the genital tract

Cervical, vaginal, or perineal tears are a significant cause of primary PPH. This type of bleeding occurs despite a well-contracted uterus.
  • Assisted deliveries
  • Rapid labor
  • Large babies

 

Thrombin (Coagulopathy)

Involves disorders of blood clotting, which are a less common cause of PPH. They can be acquired or congenital.
  • Placental abruption
  • Jaundice in pregnancy
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Intrauterine device (IUD)

questions.text: Which of the following measures is associated with an increased life span?

choices.text: Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Decreasing calorie intake by 30%

  • Among the given options, caloric restriction has the most well-documented association with increased lifespan.
  • Caloric restriction has increased lifespan across various species, including nonhuman primates and humans.
  • This is linked to two key neurohormonal circuits regulating metabolism:

Insulin and IGF-1 Signaling

IGF-1, produced in response to growth hormone, mimics insulin signalling, promoting an anabolic state, cell growth, and replication.

Sirtuins
  • These are NAD-dependent deacetylases that help adapt to stressors like food deprivation and DNA damage.
  • They promote longevity by regulating genes that reduce metabolic activity, apoptosis, and oxidative damage.
  • Sirtuins also improve insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism.
  • Caloric restriction reduces IGF-1 signalling, which may reduce cellular damage while simultaneously increasing sirtuins, particularly sirtuin-6, to promote DNA repair and metabolic adaptation.
  • Hence, caloric restriction, particularly a reduction in calories by about 20-30%, can reduce IGF-1 signalling and increase sirtuin activity, which together is thought to extend lifespan. 

Regular moderate exercise for 30 min (Option A) is associated with numerous health benefits, like improved cardiovascular health, better metabolic function, and reduced risk of chronic diseases. While it may increase health span, it is not as directly proven to increase lifespan compared to caloric restriction.

Decrease stress (Option B): Chronic stress is associated with a range of negative health effects, all of which can reduce lifespan. Stress management techniques can help improve health and increase longevity, but this relationship is more indirect and variable.

Pharmacological intervention with proton pump inhibitors (Option D): PPIs are used to reduce stomach acid and treat conditions like GERD and peptic ulcers. While they are effective for symptom relief, they are not associated with increased lifespan.

questions.text: A woman presents with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lupus nephritis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation, including fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue, hematuria, RBC casts, and proteinuria, is consistent with Lupus Nephritis, a common renal complication of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).

Lupus Nephritis

Pathophysiology: Immune complex deposition in glomeruli involving anti-dsDNA and other antibodies.

Clinical Features:

  • Proteinuria (may reach nephrotic range).
  • Hematuria with RBC casts.
  • Systemic symptoms of SLE: fever, arthralgia, oral/nasal ulcers, fatigue, and photosensitivity.
  • May progress to hypertension or end-stage renal disease if untreated.

Diagnosis:

  • Urine findings: RBC casts, proteinuria.
  • Serology: Positive ANA, anti-dsDNA, and anti-Sm antibodies.
  • Renal biopsy: Helps classify lupus nephritis into six histological classes.

Management:

  • Immunosuppressants: Corticosteroids, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate mofetil.
  • Hydroxychloroquine is used to manage SLE and is safe during pregnancy.

 

Acute Interstitial Nephritis (Option A): Presents with oliguria, fever, rash, eosinophilia; urine shows WBC casts and granular casts, not RBC casts; common causes include NSAIDs, infections, or drugs.

Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (Option B): Common in children aged 2–14; occurs after streptococcal skin or pharyngeal infection; presents with hematuria, edema, hypertension, RBC casts, but lacks systemic features like arthralgia and ulcers.

IgA Nephropathy (Option D): Follows upper respiratory infections; characterized by recurrent hematuria with mesangial IgA deposition; does not include systemic symptoms such as fever, ulcers, or arthralgia.

questions.text: A female patient collapses soon after delivery. There is profuse bleeding and features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Amniotic fluid embolism

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of profuse bleeding, collapse, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) soon after delivery is strongly suggestive of amniotic fluid embolism (AFE).

 

Amniotic Fluid Embolism

Category

Details

Pathophysiology
  • Amniotic fluid or fetal debris enters the maternal circulation, triggering a systemic inflammatory response.
  • Leads to cardiorespiratory collapse and coagulopathy (DIC).

Presentation
  • Sudden onset of hypotension or cardiac arrest.
  • Respiratory distress and gasping for air.
  • Profuse bleeding due to coagulopathy/DIC.
  • Potential seizures or altered consciousness.

Timing

Most cases occur during labor, immediately postpartum, or within 30 minutes of delivery.

Clinical Triad
  • Hemodynamic collapse.
  • Respiratory compromise.
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

 

While Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) (Option B) can cause collapse due to hypovolemia, it does not typically present with the abrupt onset of DIC.

Peripartum cardiomyopathy (Option C) is a type of heart failure that can develop in the last month of pregnancy or in the months after delivery. While it can cause cardiovascular collapse, it is not typically associated with profuse bleeding or DIC.

Rupture of the uterus (Option D) can cause severe bleeding and potentially lead to DIC, but it is not a common cause of PPH

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, and the cervix is dilated with the head at station 0 with molding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipitotransverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient?

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lower segment cesarean section

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of the deep transverse arrest. A lower segment cesarean section is carried out for the management of this patient.
  • In deep transverse arrest, the sagittal suture is placed in the transverse bispinous diameter. There is no descent of the head for at least ½–1 hour after full dilatation of the cervix. The mode of delivery is based on the fetal condition and pelvic assessment.
    • Caput succedaneum indicates the static position of the head for a prolonged duration.
    • Molding grade 2+ (overlapping parietal bones separable easily) and caput suggest cephalopelvic disproportion, necessitating cesarean delivery.
  • If the pelvis is adequate, ventouse application or manual rotation with forceps can be tried.

 

Midpelvic forceps (Option A) or vacuum-assisted delivery (Option B) is not indicated since the fetal head is at station 0, and the caput is only 2+. These instruments are typically used in cases of fetal distress, malpresentation, or prolonged second stage of labor.

Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor (Option C): Waiting for spontaneous labor to progress for an hour might not be the best option in this case. The baby's head is already at station 0 for the past two hours, and the cervix may not dilate further without assistance. Prolonging labor in such a situation could increase the risk of fetal distress or maternal complications.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. She has been in labor for 3 hours. Which of the following will determine if she is in active labor?

choices.text: Fetal head 5/5 palpable on abdominal examination
Two contractions lasting for 10 seconds in 10 minutes
More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) More than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement

Explanation:

  • This patient is in active labor if there is more than 5 cm cervical dilatation with complete effacement.

 

Stages of Labor

Stage

Definition

Features

Contractions

First Stage

Onset of labor to full cervical dilatation (10 cm).

 

  • Latent Phase: Early cervical changes with slower progress.
  • Active Phase: Faster cervical dilatation (≥5 cm) with regular contractions.
  • Cervical dilatation and effacement occur.
  • Intermittent painful uterine contractions.
  • "Show" (blood-stained mucus) is common.
  • Active labor starts at cervical dilatation ≥5 cm with regular contractions.

Latent Phase: Irregular and mild.

Active Phase: Regular; 3–5 min apart, lasting ~45 seconds.

Second Stage

From complete cervical dilatation (10 cm) to fetal delivery.
  • Begins after complete cervical dilation.
  • Ends with the delivery of the baby.

Strong and frequent; 2–3 minutes apart.

Third Stage

From fetal delivery to placental expulsion.
  • Placental separation and expulsion occur.
  • Average duration: 5–15 minutes.

Mild uterine contractions to aid placental expulsion.

Fourth Stage

Observation for at least 1 hour after placental expulsion.
  • Monitoring for postpartum hemorrhage and uterine contraction.

Uterine contractions continue, aiding hemostasis.

 

Fetal head 5/5 palpable (Option A): Indicates the fetal head is floating above the pelvic brim, meaning active labor has not begun.

Two contractions lasting 10 seconds in 10 minutes (Option B): This is insufficient for diagnosing active labor. Contractions during active labor are more frequent and longer in duration.

Rupture of membranes (Option D): While this may indicate the onset of labor, it does not confirm active labor.

questions.text: Please identify the area in the image below that appears blue in color:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Midpelvis

Explanation:

The midpelvis is the region of the pelvis highlighted in blue in the given image. It is defined by the following boundaries:

 

Upper Boundary

  • Plane of Greatest Pelvic Dimensions
    • This is the most spacious pelvic plane.
    • It extends from:
      • The middle of the posterior surface of the symphysis pubis
      • To the junction of the second and third sacral vertebrae.

 

Lower Boundary

  • Midpelvic Plane (Plane of Least Pelvic Dimensions)
    • This plane forms a wedge posteriorly and coincides with the narrowest dimensions of the pelvis.
    • It extends from:
      • The lower margin of the symphysis pubis
      • To the tip of the sacrum, at the level of the ischial spines or the junction of S4 and S5.

 

 

The obstetric outlet (Option A) is the space bounded by the lower border of the symphysis pubis anteriorly, ischial tuberosities laterally, and the tip of the coccyx posteriorly.

 

The anatomical outlet (Option B) is bordered by the pubic arch, ischial tuberosities, sacrotuberous ligaments, and the tip of the coccyx.

 

The pelvic inlet (Option C) is the uppermost plane of the pelvis, bounded by the sacral promontory, arcuate line, iliopectineal line, and the upper margin of the symphysis pubis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a post-mortem finding seen in the lung after the death of a patient from COVID-19 after a week?

choices.text: Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Thick layer of fibrin

  • A thick layer of fibrin is a common post-mortem finding in COVID-19 patients after a week, especially in those with severe disease.
  • Fibrin deposition occurs as part of the coagulopathy and inflammatory response in the lungs, leading to the formation of hyaline membranes and organized fibrin in the alveoli.

Fresh and old intra-alveolar haemorrhage (Option A): These can occur in COVID-19, especially in the acute phase; it is typically seen in earlier stages of the disease, not necessarily after a week. After a week, haemorrhage may be less prominent, and fibrin deposition would be a more characteristic finding.

Perivascular cuffing (Option C) refers to the accumulation of lymphocytes around blood vessels, commonly seen in viral infections, usually in the early stages. By the later week, this feature may still be present but is not as defining as fibrin deposition after a week of death in COVID-19.

Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance (Option D) can develop with long-standing lung disease or after multiple episodes of severe illness. However, this is a chronic finding rather than an acute post-mortem feature. Pulmonary artery hypertrophy is a very rare complication after COVID-19 and would not commonly be a primary finding after one week of death from COVID-19.

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue and a history of piles. Routine complete blood count analysis showed a haemoglobin of 9 g/dL, an MCV of 60 fL, and an RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear is given below. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Serum ferritin levels

  • The patient's presentation, with a history of piles and a peripheral smear showing anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, and target cells, along with the microcytic nature of the anemia, strongly suggests iron deficiency anemia (IDA) due to chronic blood loss.
  • Serum ferritin is a key marker for diagnosing IDA.
  • In IDA, ferritin levels decrease as iron stores are depleted. Levels below 30 ng/mL are indicative of depleted iron stores.

Investigations for IDA

Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL) indicates depleted iron stores.

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low levels are seen in iron deficiency anemia.

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)

Increased TIBC reflects the increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores.

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased RDW is often seen in iron deficiency anemia

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test

HbA2 levels (Option A) are useful for diagnosing thalassemia. Although target cells can also be seen in thalassemia, the clinical history of piles and the absence of symptoms indicative of thalassemia suggest iron deficiency anemia is the more likely diagnosis

Serum folate levels (Option C): Folate deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia. The MCV here is low, making folate levels less relevant.

Serum homocysteine levels (Option D): This would be more relevant for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, which typically causes macrocytic anemia, not microcytic anemia.

questions.text: What will be the level of the uterus on postpartum day 2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Two finger breadths below umbilicus

Explanation:

  • On the second day postpartum, the uterus lies at two finger breadths below the umbilicus.

Time Following Delivery

Features

Weight

Immediately After Delivery
  • Uterus corresponds to 20 weeks of gestation.
  • Fundus lies just below the umbilicus.
  • Lochia rubra (bright red discharge).

1000 g

48 Hours Post-Delivery
  • Myometrial involution starts.
  • Fundal height decreases by 1 finger breadth (1 cm) per day.
  • Uterus lies at two finger breadths below the umbilicus.
  • Lochia rubra continues.

_

1 Week Post-Delivery
  • Rapid involution.
  • Fundus lies midway between the umbilicus and symphysis pubis.
  • Lochia serosa (pinkish-brown discharge).

500 g

2 Weeks Post-Delivery
  • Uterus becomes a pelvic organ.
  • Fundus no longer palpable.
  • Lochia serosa persists but decreases in amount.

300 g

4 Weeks Post-Delivery
  • Clinically, involution is complete.
  • Lochia alba (whitish-yellow discharge).

100 g

6-8 Weeks Post-Delivery
  • Uterus returns to normal (pre-pregnant) size.
  • Sonographically, involution is complete at 8 weeks.
  • Lochia typically ends.

60 g

 

  • The process of uterine involution is due to a decrease in the size of the uterine muscle fibers. It is clinically assessed by measuring the fundal height in relation to the umbilicus and symphysis pubis.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Which of the following will you recommend?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Additional 300 kcal in 2nd trimester

Explanation:

During pregnancy, the nutritional requirements of the mother increase to support fetal growth and development. Here's the breakdown of energy needs during pregnancy:

  • First trimester: Energy requirements are generally the same as for non-pregnant women.
  • Second trimester: Energy intake should increase by 340 kcal per day, though 300 kcal is commonly recommended, according to ICMR guidelines.
  • Third trimester: Energy intake increases further by 452 kcal per day, with a recommended 300 kcal intake, according to ICMR.

 

Therefore, the recommended increase in caloric intake for a pregnant woman at 12 weeks (in the second trimester) is 300 kcal per day.

Recommended Dietary Allowances For Energy And Protein For Indians

 

Category

EAR - Energy (Kcal/D)

RDA - Protein (g/D)

Man

Sedentary work

2110

54

Moderate work

2710

54

Heavy work

3470

54

Woman

Sedentary work

1660

46

Moderate work

2130

46

Heavy work

2720

46

Pregnancy (2nd trimester)

+340

+9.5

Pregnancy (3rd trimester)

+452

+22

Lactation (0-6 months)

+600

530

Lactation (6-12 months)

+520

Infant

0-6 months
