questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is a massive splenomegaly. A peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils. Which of the following translocations is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - t(9;22)

  • The clinical presentation of dragging abdominal pain, massive splenomegaly, and peripheral smear findings is suggestive of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).
  • The hallmark of CML is the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the t(9;22) translocation.

CML

Genetics

Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22))

Origin

Myeloid lineage

Etiopathogenesis
  • BCR-ABL fusion gene due to t(9;22) causes increased tyrosine kinase activity.
  • Radiation exposure.

Clinical features
  • Occurs in adults.
  • Often presents with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort.
  • It can progress to a blast crisis with features of acute leukemia.

Diagnosis
  • Bone marrow aspirate to confirm diagnosis
  • Peripheral smear: shows many mature neutrophils, some metamyelocytes, and myelocytes.
  • On FISH - the presence of BCR ABL fusion gene product can be seen.

Management

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as Imatinib.

t(8;21) (Option B) translocation results in the RUNX1-RUNX1T1 fusion gene, which is commonly seen in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

t(15;17) (Option C) translocation results in the PML-RARA fusion gene, which is also characteristic of AML.

t(8;14) (Option D) translocation involves the MYC gene on the chromosome, which is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text: A 40-year-old G2P1 woman with 18 weeks of amenorrhea comes with a dilated cervix. The cervical length is 15 mm. In spite of explaining the risks, she insisted on cerclage. Which of the following is a contraindication for cervical cerclage?

choices.text: Prolapse of membranes into the vagina

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ruptured membranes

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of mid-trimester cervical dilatation and a short cervix suggests cervical incompetence, which can lead to preterm birth or miscarriage.
  • Cervical cerclage is a procedure used to strengthen the cervix and prevent premature delivery in cases of cervical insufficiency. However, certain conditions serve as contraindications for performing a cerclage, including:
    1. Intrauterine infection
    2. Ruptured Membranes
    3. Presence of vaginal bleeding
    4. Severe uterine irritability
    5. Cervical dilation > 4cm.
    6. Fetal death

 

  • Cervical incompetence is associated with multiple risk factors, including prior preterm birth, congenital uterine anomalies, and certain medical procedures like dilatation and curettage or vaginal operative deliveries.
  • Investigations for cervical incompetence include:
    • Transvaginal ultrasound: Shows funneling of the internal os >1 cm and cervical length <25 mm.
    • Per speculum examination: Reveals cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes.

 

Types of cerclage: Shirodkar and McDonald

Removal of stitch: 37 weeks or earlier if labour pain starts

Time of Cerclage done:

  1. Prophylactic cerclage is done at 14 weeks of gestation
  2. Emergency cerclage can be done when the cervix is dilated, and the membranes are bulging.

 

Prolapse of membranes into the vagina (Option B) is an indication for cerclage, as it suggests cervical insufficiency, and cerclage can help to prevent further damage and maintain the pregnancy.

Fetal fibronectin positive (Option C): While fetal fibronectin is a marker for impending preterm labor, it is not a contraindication for cerclage. In fact, prophylactic cerclage can be indicated in women with a positive fibronectin test if ultrasound confirms cervical incompetence.

While advanced maternal age (Option D) may increase the risk for preterm birth or other pregnancy complications, it is not a contraindication for cervical cerclage.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency room in the early stage of labor with adequate uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, a gynecoid pelvis is felt, the membranes are ruptured, and the vertex is felt in the right occipito-posterior position. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Normal vaginal delivery

Explanation:

The clinical scenario describes a primigravida with a right occipito-posterior (ROP) position, which is the most common malposition. In the ROP position, the fetal occiput is positioned posteriorly over the sacrum or the sacroiliac joint. Although it is associated with the risk of delayed engagement, prolonged labor, and potential cesarean delivery in some cases, it can still be managed through normal vaginal delivery under the following conditions:

  • The pelvic shape is gynecoid, which is favorable for vaginal delivery.
  • Adequate uterine contractions are present, indicating good labor progress.
  • There are no signs of fetal distress or other complications.

 

In the majority of cases, ROP presentation in a woman with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions results in normal labor progression. Most ROP positions spontaneously rotate to the anterior position during labor, allowing for a vaginal delivery.

Management would involve monitoring the labor closely, as spontaneous rotation can occur, leading to a normal vaginal delivery.

 

Vacuum-assisted delivery (Option A) is typically used for difficult deliveries due to malposition or malpresentation, but in this case, normal vaginal delivery can be anticipated, and the need for vacuum assistance is not yet indicated.

A cesarean section (Option B) would be considered if there are complications such as arrest of labor, fetal distress, or inadequate uterine contractions, but these are not present in this scenario.

Forceps delivery (Option D) may be used in certain malpositions during the second stage of labor if there is fetal distress or failure of spontaneous delivery.

questions.text: A pregnant patient with a history of a classical cesarean section due to fetal growth retardation in the previous pregnancy presents to you. She is currently at 35 weeks of gestation with breech presentation. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Advice ultrasound and visit after 2 weeks
Internal podalic version followed by vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cesarean section at 37 weeks

Explanation:

  • In this case, the patient has a history of classical cesarean section (longitudinal uterine incision) significantly increases the risk of uterine rupture in subsequent pregnancies, making VBAC (vaginal birth after cesarean) contraindicated. The risk is further heightened in cases of breech presentation.
  • Given these risks, cesarean delivery is the safest mode of delivery for a breech fetus in patients with a prior classical cesarean section. It is typically scheduled at 37 weeks to minimize preterm complications while ensuring fetal maturity for optimal outcomes.

Vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC)

  • Described as vaginal delivery in a woman who has given birth via cesarean section in a former pregnancy.
  • Patients desiring VBAC delivery undergo a trial of labor (TOL), also called the trial of labor after cesarean section (TOLAC).

Selection Criteria of Cases for TOLAC (ACOG)
  • One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar.
  • Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section.
  • Pelvis adequate for the fetus.
  • Continued labor monitoring possible.
  • Availability of resources (anesthesia, blood transfusion and theatre) for an emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes of the decision.
  • Informed consent of the woman.

 

Contraindications for TOLAC (indications for Cesarean Delivery)
  • Previous classical or inverted T-shaped uterine incision, myomectomy scar
  • Previously >2 LSCS
  • Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD.
  • Presence of other complications in pregnancy: Obstetric (pre-eclampsia, malpresentation, placenta previa) or medical.
  • Resources limited for emergency cesarean delivery or patient refusal for TOLAC.
  • History of prior uterine rupture

 

Advice ultrasound and visit after 2 weeks (Option B): An ultrasound at this stage will not change the decision about mode of delivery. The decision to proceed with cesarean section is based on the history of classical cesarean, not just fetal position.

Internal podalic version followed by vaginal delivery (Option C): Internal podalic version is typically used in twin pregnancies with transverse lie for the second baby. It is not indicated for a singleton breech pregnancy and is not appropriate in this case.

External cephalic version at 36 weeks (Option D): It is a procedure used to turn a breech fetus into a head-down position through abdominal manipulation. However, it is contraindicated in cases of previous cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in managing a diabetic patient who has a visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye and further investigations reveal preretinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Pan-retinal photocoagulation

  • The findings described in the patient—a visual acuity of 6/9, preretinal hemorrhages, and neovascularization at the optic disc—are consistent with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), a severe form of diabetic retinopathy.
  • In proliferative diabetic retinopathy, abnormal neovascularization (growth of new, fragile blood vessels) occurs in response to retinal ischemia. These new blood vessels are prone to leakage, causing preretinal hemorrhages and potentially leading to tractional retinal detachment.
  • Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the first-line treatment for proliferative diabetic retinopathy. It involves the application of laser burns to the retina to ablate areas of ischemia, thereby reducing the stimulus for neovascularization. The goal is to prevent further progression, bleeding, and potential vision loss.

 

Abbreviated Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) classification of diabetic retinopathy

Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR):

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

Mild NPDR

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

 

Severe NPDR

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants

Review in 4 months

 

Very severe NPDR

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR):

Mild-moderate PDR

New vessels on the disc (NVD) or new vessels elsewhere (NVE), but extent insufficient to meet the high-risk criteria

Treatment is considered according to the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and the patient's circumstances such as reliability of attendance for review. If not treated, review in up to 2 months

High-risk PDR

  • NVD greater than ⅓ disc area
  • Any NVD with vitreous hemorrhage
  • NVE greater than ½ disc area with vitreous hemorrhage

Treatment should be performed immediately when possible and certainly on the same day if symptomatic presentation with a good retinal view

Advanced diabetic eye disease

Is characterized by tractional retinal detachment. Significant persistent vitreous hemorrhage and neovascular glaucoma.

Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR):

  • Panretinal Photocoagulation (PRP):
    • PRP of ischemic area reduces metabolic demand and prevents the release of vasoproliferative factors by conversion of hypoxic areas into anoxic areas and creates inert scars from leaking vascular anomalies.
    • Laser used: Argon, frequency-doubled YAG or diode laser
    • In PRP, the inferior quadrant of the retina is first coagulated.
    • Untreated Areas: A circular area with a radius of 2.5 DD around the fovea is left untouched during treatment.
    • Each treatment requires 2000-3000 burns, administered over two to four sessions.

 

Anti-VEGF Therapy:

  • Bevacizumab, ranibizumab or aflibercept are used to control neovascularization.
  • Vitreoretinal Surgery: Advanced cases with tractional retinal detachment or unresolved vitreous hemorrhage require vitrectomy.

Focal laser photocoagulation (Option A): This is typically used for treating macular edema or localized areas of retinal leakage, not for the widespread ischemic retina seen in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Grid laser photocoagulation (Option C): This is also used to treat macular edema but is not the treatment of choice for proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Scleral buckling (Option D): This procedure is used for retinal detachment, often caused by traction from proliferative diabetic retinopathy, but it's not the initial treatment for PDR. Pan-retinal photocoagulation is used before considering surgery in the event of a detachment.

questions.text: An 11-year-old child with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis presents with fever and arthralgia. There is no past history of rheumatic heart disease or carditis. How often is 600,000 IU of benzathine penicillin recommended for prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease?

choices.text: Once in three weeks for 5 years or till the age of 18, whichever is longer
Once in three weeks for 10 years or till the age of 25, whichever is longer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Once in three weeks for 5 years or till the age of 18, whichever is longer

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario describes acute rheumatic fever (ARF) in a child, which follows a group A streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis infection. Secondary prophylaxis is essential to prevent recurrent episodes of ARF, which increases the risk of developing rheumatic heart disease (RHD).

Secondary prophylaxis for Rheumatic Fever:

Dose and Frequency:

  • Patients weighing <27 kg: 600,000 IU benzathine penicillin every 3 weeks.
  • Patients ≥27 kg: 1.2 million IU benzathine penicillin every 3 weeks.

Condition

Recommended Duration

Without Carditis

5 years after the last attack or until 18 years of age, whichever is longer

With Carditis but No Residual Valvular Disease

10 years or until 21–25 years of age, whichever is longer

With Persistent Valvular Disease

At least 10 years or until 40 years of age; lifelong prophylaxis may be required

 

Revised Jones Criteria for the diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Criteria

Moderate- and High-risk Populations

Carditis

Clinical or subclinical

Polyarthritis only

Polyarthritis, polyarthralgia, or monoarthritis

Yes

Yes

Yes

Yes

Yes

Carditis

Clinical or subclinical

Not applicable

≥38.5°C

Increased ASLO/anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture or positive rapid strep test

Diagnosis of Initial ARF

2 Major criteria or 1 Major + 2 Minor criteria

Diagnosis of Recurrent ARF

2 Major criteria or 1 Major + 2 Minor or 3 Minor criteria

questions.text: A man on diuretics presents with weakness. An ECG shows flat T waves and prominent U waves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypokalemia

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and ECG findings strongly suggest hypokalemia, a condition defined as a serum potassium level <3.5 mEq/L.

Symptoms:

  • Muscle weakness, cramps, or paralysis.
  • Fatigue and lethargy.
  • Constipation or ileus (due to smooth muscle dysfunction).
  • Severe cases may lead to cardiac arrhythmias.

Causes of Hypokalemia:

  • Diuretic Use (Loop and Thiazide Diuretics): Increased renal excretion of potassium.
  • Metabolic Alkalosis: Intracellular shift of potassium due to increased extracellular pH.
  • Excessive β-agonist Activity: Intracellular potassium shift (e.g., in asthma treatment with salbutamol).
  • Gastrointestinal Losses: Vomiting or diarrhea leading to potassium depletion.
  • Other Causes:
    • Insulin administration (drives potassium into cells).
    • Magnesium deficiency (worsens renal potassium loss).
    • Hyperaldosteronism (increased potassium excretion).

ECG Changes in Hypokalemia:

  • Flattened T waves.
  • Prominent U waves.
  • ST depression.
  • Prolonged QT interval.

Severe cases: Risk of ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

Management:

Potassium Replacement:

  • Oral potassium chloride for mild cases.
  • Intravenous potassium for severe or symptomatic cases (administer cautiously to avoid hyperkalemia).

 

Correct Underlying Cause

Hypocalcemia (Option A):

  • Presents with muscle cramps, tetany, or paresthesias.
  • ECG: Prolonged QT interval but no prominent U waves.

Hypomagnesemia (Option B):

  • Causes muscle weakness and arrhythmias.
  • ECG: Torsades de Pointes (polymorphic ventricular tachycardia).

Hyperkalemia (Option C):

  • Presents with muscle weakness or paralysis.
  • ECG: Tall, peaked T waves, shortened QT interval, and widened QRS complex.

questions.text: A primigravida at 22 weeks of gestation presents with profuse vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure and glucose levels are within normal limits. Placental implantation at which of the following sites can cause this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Internal os

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario is indicative of placenta previa, a condition characterized by placental implantation in the lower uterine segment, partially or completely covering the internal os. This condition often presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester.

 

Types of placenta previa:

Types

Definitions

I

Low lying

The placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment but does not reach the internal os.

II

Marginal

The edge of the placenta is at the margin of the internal os.

III

Incomplete/ partial central

The placenta partially covers the internal os of the cervix.

IV

Central/complete

The placenta completely covers the internal os of the cervix.

 

  • Types I and II can be anterior or posterior.
  • Types I and II are minor degrees, and types III and IV are major degrees of placenta previa.

 

Revised Classification:

Types

Definitions

True Placenta previa

The placenta covers the internal os

Low lying placenta

The placenta lies within 2cm of internal is but does not cover it

 

Characteristics of placenta previa include:

  • Profuse vaginal bleeding without pain.
  • Bleeding typically occurs in the second half of pregnancy.
  • Bleeding often resolves spontaneously but can recur.

 

The management depends on gestational age, fetal status, maternal stability, and degree of placental coverage. In many cases, planned cesarean delivery is required.

Implantation in the fallopian tube (Option B) is characteristic of an ectopic pregnancy, which typically presents with first-trimester vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and often hemodynamic instability due to tubal rupture.

Ovarian (Option C) implantation is an extremely rare form of ectopic pregnancy that also presents in the first trimester with signs of rupture and hemodynamic compromise, not painless bleeding in the second trimester.

Abdominal (Option D) pregnancy is a rare form of ectopic pregnancy where implantation occurs within the peritoneal cavity. It often presents with vague abdominal pain, abnormal bleeding, or gastrointestinal symptoms and is diagnosed later in pregnancy.

questions.text:
A male patient presents to the emergency department with the following arterial blood gas (ABG) values:


	pH: 7.2
	pCO2: 81 mmHg
	HCO3: 40 mEq/L


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Respiratory acidosis

Explanation:

The arterial blood gas values point to respiratory acidosis, a condition characterized by:

  • Decreased pH (<7.35): Indicates acidosis.
  • Increased pCO2 (>45 mmHg): Suggests a respiratory cause for the acidosis.
  • Elevated HCO3: Indicates partial metabolic compensation.

Interpretation of ABG:

  1. Primary disorder: A high pCO2 and low pH confirm a primary respiratory acidosis.
  2. Compensation: The elevated HCO3 suggests renal compensation, which occurs as the kidneys retain bicarbonate to buffer the acidosis.

Causes of Respiratory Acidosis:

Acute Causes:

  • Severe asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbations.
  • Airway obstruction (e.g., foreign body, anaphylaxis).
  • Neuromuscular disorders (e.g., Guillain-Barré syndrome).
  • Central respiratory depression (e.g., from opioids or sedatives).

Chronic Causes:

  • COPD or other chronic lung diseases.
  • Obesity hypoventilation syndrome.
  • Sleep apnea.

ABG Analysis

Parameter

Metabolic Acidosis

(Option B)

Metabolic Alkalosis

(Option D)

Respiratory Acidosis

Respiratory Alkalosis

(Option A)

Primary Disturbance

↓ HCO₃⁻ (Bicarbonate)

↑ HCO₃⁻ (Bicarbonate)

↑ PaCO₂ (Hypoventilation)

↓ PaCO₂ (Hyperventilation)

ABG Parameters

pH

↓ (Acidemia)

↑ (Alkalemia)

↓ (Acidemia)

↑ (Alkalemia)

HCO₃⁻ (Bicarbonate)

↓

↑

Normal or ↑

Normal or ↓

Normal or ↓

Normal or ↑

↑

↓

Compensation Mechanism

Respiratory: Hyperventilation (↓ PaCO₂)

Respiratory: Hypoventilation (↑ PaCO₂)

Renal: ↑ HCO₃⁻ reabsorption, ↑ H⁺ excretion

Renal: ↓ HCO₃⁻ reabsorption, ↓ H⁺ excretion

Compensation Status

Compensated

Normal pH, ↓ HCO₃⁻, ↓ PaCO₂

Normal pH, ↑ HCO₃⁻, ↑ PaCO₂

Normal pH, ↑ PaCO₂, ↑ HCO₃⁻

Normal pH, ↓ PaCO₂, ↓ HCO₃⁻

Decompensated

↓ pH, ↓ HCO₃⁻, inadequate ↓ PaCO₂

↑ pH, ↑ HCO₃⁻, inadequate ↑ PaCO₂

↓ pH, ↑ PaCO₂, inadequate ↑ HCO₃⁻

↑ pH, ↓ PaCO₂, inadequate ↓ HCO₃⁻

Common Causes

↑ Anion Gap:

  • DKA, Lactic acidosis

 

Normal Anion Gap:

  • Diarrhea, Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA)
  • Vomiting
  • Diuretics
  • Antacid overuse
  • COPD
  • Respiratory depression
  • Airway obstruction
  • Anxiety
  • Pain
  • Fever
  • High altitude

Clinical Features
  • Kussmaul breathing
  • Confusion
  • Hypotension
  • Muscle cramps
  • Tetany
  • Hypokalemia
  • Headache
  • Confusion
  • Dyspnea
  • Dizziness
  • Numbness
  • Tetany

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Parathyroid adenoma

  • Explanation: Parathyroid adenomas are typically associated with MEN 2A and MEN 1, not MEN 2B.
  • MEN 2B (also known as MEN 3) is a rare inherited condition caused by gain-of-function mutations in the RET proto-oncogene at chromosomal locus 10q11.2.

Features of MEN 2B

  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): (Most common) often aggressive and presenting early.
  • Pheochromocytoma: Frequently bilateral, causing palpitations, sweating, and headaches.
  • Mucosal Neuromas: Present as bumpy, enlarged lips, tongue, and eyelids. (Option C ruled out)
  • Marfanoid Habitus: Features include tall stature, long limbs, arachnodactyly, and joint hypermobility. (Option D ruled out)
  • Megacolon: Results from intestinal autonomic ganglion dysfunction, often associated with diverticula. (Option A ruled out)
  • Medullated corneal nerve fibers and delayed puberty.

MEN 1 (Wermer Syndrome)

MEN 2A (Sipple Syndrome)

MEN 2B (MEN 3)

MEN 4

Gene: MEN1

Gene: RET

Gene: RET

Gene: CDKN1B
  • Pituitary Adenomas
  • Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors
  • Primary Hyperparathyroidism
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma
  • Phaeochromocytoma

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease presents to you with chest pain and palpitations. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following can be used in the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intravenous amiodarone

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and ECG findings suggest ventricular tachycardia (VT) in a patient with coronary artery disease.

ECG Findings:

  • Wide QRS complexes (>120 ms).
  • Absence of P waves or atrioventricular dissociation.
  • Ventricular rate >100 bpm.

Symptoms: Palpitations, chest pain, syncope, and dyspnea.

Management

  • Hemodynamically Stable VT:

Drug of Choice: Intravenous amiodarone.

Mechanism: Class III antiarrhythmic, prolongs action potential duration and refractory period.

  • Hemodynamically Unstable VT: Immediate Electrical Cardioversion.
  • Torsades de Pointes (Polymorphic VT): Treat with intravenous magnesium sulfate.

Resuscitation Steps for Shockable & Non-Shockable Conditions

Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Ventricular Fibrillation

Asystole

Ventricular Tachycardia

Pulseless Electrical Activity

 

Shockable Conditions

Non-Shockable Conditions

Immediate Recognition

Identify Shockable Rhythm: Recognize VF or pulseless VT.

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓

Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓

Defibrillation

After 2 minutes of CPR, deliver a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

If no change, administer a second shock immediately.

↓

Continue CPR

Resume CPR for 2 Minutes

Place an intravenous or intraosseous line for drug administration.

↓

Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Given IV/IO after 2 minutes of CPR to enhance coronary perfusion pressure.

↓

Advanced Airway Management

Secure Airway: Perform endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation.

↓

Further Defibrillation

Third Shock: If VF or pulseless VT persists, deliver a third non-synchronized shock.

Continue CPR for 2 More Minutes: Follow with additional CPR.

↓

Administer Antiarrhythmic Medication

Amiodarone 300 mg IV: Administer for shock-refractory VT to stabilize heart rhythm.

↓

Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Immediate Recognition

Identify Non-Shockable Rhythm: Recognize asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA).

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓
Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓
Establish intravenous or intraosseous line for medication administration.

↓
Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Administer IV/IO after the first 2 minutes of CPR.

↓

Identify Rhythm

  • Non-Shockable Rhythm: Continue CPR and administer epinephrine every 3-5 minutes.

Goal: To increase the likelihood of developing a shockable rhythm, such as ventricular fibrillation (VF), which is necessary for effective defibrillation.

  • Shockable Rhythm: Administer a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

↓
Advanced Airway Management

Airway: Secure the airway with endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation for adequate oxygenation.

↓
Continue CPR

Resume chest compressions for 2 minutes.

↓
Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

Primary Focus: Address reversible causes, especially hypothermia.

↓
Repeat CPR and Epinephrine

Cycle: Continue repeating CPR and epinephrine administration every 3-5 minutes.

 

 

Oral Metoprolol (Option A): Selective β1-antagonist used in angina, hypertension, and chronic heart failure; not indicated for acute ventricular tachycardia management, especially when rapid control is needed.

Oral Amiodarone (Option B): Used for chronic treatment of VT, atrial fibrillation, and ventricular fibrillation; delayed onset makes it unsuitable for acute management.

Intravenous Metoprolol (Option D): Used in acute myocardial infarction to reduce heart rate and myocardial oxygen demand; not a first-line treatment for ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A female patient presents with six weeks of amenorrhea, associated with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her blood pressure is normal. Investigations reveal beta-hCG of 1400 mIU/mL. An ultrasound shows a trilaminar endometrium with normal adnexa. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Repeat beta-hCG after 48 hours

Explanation:

This clinical scenario is consistent with pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), as the ultrasound does not confirm an intrauterine or ectopic pregnancy. The primary concerns include:

  1. Ectopic pregnancy
  2. Threatened abortion
  3. Early pregnancy loss

 

  • The next best step is to perform a serial beta-hCG measurement after 48 hours to evaluate the pattern of increase or decrease.
  • A beta-hCG cut-off of ≥1500 mIU/mL is referred to as the discriminatory zone, above which an intrauterine gestational sac should typically be visible on transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS).

 

Condition

Serial beta-hCG Measurement

Normal Intrauterine Pregnancy

Rising beta-hCG (doubling every 1.4–2 days)

Ectopic Pregnancy

Plateauing or declining beta-hCG

Threatened Abortion

Variable beta-hCG changes

Early Pregnancy Loss

Declining beta-hCG

 

Repeat ultrasound after 3 days (Option B): While ultrasound may be useful later, beta-hCG measurements are more reliable at this stage to identify trends and determine the need for further imaging or interventions.

Measurement of progesterone levels (Option C) is less reliable for diagnosing ectopic pregnancy or viability. Levels <5 ng/mL suggest nonviability but do not confirm the location of the pregnancy.

Laparoscopy (Option D) is definitive for diagnosing and treating ectopic pregnancy but is invasive and reserved for cases with confirmed ectopic pregnancy or hemodynamic instability.

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis shows resistance to which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Isoniazid and rifampicin

Explanation:

  • Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most potent first-line anti-TB drugs.

Drug-Sensitive Tuberculosis (DSTB)

Tuberculosis that is susceptible to the first-line anti-TB drugs, such as isoniazid and rifampin.

Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis (DR-TB)

TB caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains that are resistant to at least one first-line anti-TB drug.

Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis (MDR-TB)

TB caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains that are resistant to at least isoniazid and rifampin, the two most potent first-line anti-TB drugs.

Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis (XDR-TB)

A more severe form of MDR-TB resistant to isoniazid, rifampin, fluoroquinolones, and at least one of the second-line injectable drugs (e.g., amikacin, kanamycin, or capreomycin).

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever, jaundice, and malaise. Based on the serology reports provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?

Serology Reports:


	HBsAg: Positive
	Anti-HBc: Positive
	Anti-HCV: Negative
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute hepatitis B

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of fever, jaundice, and malaise, along with the provided serology results, points to acute hepatitis B.

  • HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): The presence of HBsAg indicates active hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, which is crucial in diagnosing acute or chronic hepatitis B.
  • Anti-HBc (IgM anti-Hepatitis B core antibody): The presence of IgM anti-HBc suggests acute infection with hepatitis B. IgM antibodies appear during the initial phase of HBV infection and are markers of recent exposure.
  • Anti-HCV: Negative in this case, which excludes hepatitis C, ruling out acute or chronic hepatitis C. (Option D ruled out)

Acute hepatitis D (Option A): Hepatitis D requires co-infection with hepatitis B to exist. It is not the correct answer here because anti-HBc (core antibody) is positive, but no other markers for hepatitis D (like HDV RNA) are provided.

Chronic hepatitis B (Option C): Chronic hepatitis B would show HBsAg positive for more than 6 months, which is not suggested by the given clinical scenario or serology. Additionally, anti-HBc would typically be IgG (indicating a past infection or chronicity) rather than IgM.

questions.text: In the image, what are the associated complications observed in a 35-year-old woman who has been diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Scleromalacia perforans

  • The diagnosis in this scenario is scleromalacia perforans.
  • It is usually associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and presents with scleral thinning appearing bluish and without signs of inflammation.
  • The underlying cause of scleral thinning is probably ischemia because of vessel damage (type III hypersensitivity).

Scleromalacia Perforans:

  • Most common in elderly females

Pathophysiology:

  • Associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis
  • Melting of the sclera is due to obliteration of arterial supply causing ischemia
  • Vessel damage is mediated by type III hypersensitivity (Option A)

Clinical manifestations:

  • Painless scleral thinning
  • Underlying dark uveal tissue is visible
  • Rarely perforation of the globe

Scleromalacia perforans

Treatment:

  • No specific therapy
  • Protection of the eye from trauma is very crucial
  • Plenty of topical lubrication
  • Oral NSAIDs
  • Oral steroids
  • Immunomodulatory agents
  • Surgery-scleral patch grafting

Ciliary staphyloma (Option B): This condition involves outpouching of the eye wall near the ciliary body, typically associated with trauma or inflammatory conditions other than rheumatoid arthritis, but it is not a direct complication of RA.

Coloboma (Option C): A coloboma is a congenital defect in the eye, where part of the eye structure (such as the iris or retina) is missing. It is not associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Malignant melanoma (Option D): This is a type of eye cancer that arises from pigment-producing cells. It is unrelated to rheumatoid arthritis and is not an autoimmune complication.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Pseudoexfoliation syndrome:

  • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is a condition where an abnormal protein material (pseudoexfoliative material) accumulates in the anterior segment of the eye, especially on the lens capsule, pupillary margin, and the corneal endothelium.
  • This condition can cause the formation of a characteristic white, flaky material around the lens and pupil, which is the hallmark of pseudoexfoliation syndrome. It can lead to increased risk of glaucoma (due to blocked drainage of fluid), cataracts, and other complications.
  • This can lead to phacodonesis (lens wobbling).

Ocular manifestation of Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome (XFS) is characterized by the accumulation of fibrillar, proteinaceous material on various ocular structures, including

the lens, iris, and trabecular meshwork.

  • This material can be seen as flaky white deposits on the anterior lens capsule and pupillary margin, often with a distinct clear zone at the center of the lens.
  • It causes secondary open-angle glaucoma, known as pseudoexfoliative glaucoma.
  • The excessive material and pigment clog the trabecular meshwork, increasing intraocular pressure (IOP) and causing damage to the optic nerve, which leads to glaucoma.
  • It also predisposes patients to complications during cataract surgery due to weakened zonules, resulting in lens instability or phacodonesis.

Features of Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome:

  • White flaky deposits on the anterior lens capsule and iris
  • Increased trabecular meshwork pigmentation
  • Elevated IOP, leading to secondary glaucoma
  • Zonular instability and risk of lens dislocation during cataract surgery
  • Mutations in the LOXL1 gene have been strongly associated with PXF, although not all individuals with these mutations develop the disease.
  • More prevalent in elderly patients.

Intraocular foreign body (Option A): This typically causes localized symptoms such as pain, vision changes, or infection. An image of an intraocular foreign body would typically show the object within the eye, which is not characteristic of the findings in pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

Ocular trauma (Option C): Ocular trauma may lead to various findings such as bruising, swelling, or damage to the structures of the eye. It is not characterized by the deposition of material on the lens and anterior segment like in pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

Vossius ring (Option D): This is a pigmented ring on the cornea that results from trauma (usually from a blow to the eye). It is a permanent imprint of the iris pigment on the corneal endothelium and is not related to the findings of white, flaky material seen in pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lactating female with an 18-month-old child presents with a history of irregular, heavy bleeding and seeks contraceptive advice. Which contraceptive is the most appropriate choice for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mala N

Explanation:

  • Among the given options, the contraceptive of choice for this lactating woman with heavy, irregular bleeding is Mala N, a combined oral contraceptive (COC) containing 30 mcg of ethinylestradiol (EE2) and 0.15 mg of levonorgestrel.
  • Mala N is an appropriate choice for contraception due to the following reasons:
    • Suppresses ovulation by inhibiting pituitary hormones FSH and LH.
    • Controls irregular bleeding patterns such as polymenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia.
    • Safe to use as the woman is well beyond the puerperal period (first 6 weeks postpartum) and the child is partially weaned (complementary feeds are introduced at 6 months).
  • Mala N is available free of cost in Family Planning Clinics in India.
  • The tablets should be taken beginning on the first day of the menstrual cycle and continued for 21 days. A new cycle of tablets should start 7 days after finishing the previous one. It is recommended to take the tablet at the same time each day, ideally after a meal.

Progestasert (Option A) is a hormone-containing intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) that works by forming a thick cervical mucus plug to block sperm entry. However, it may exacerbate heavy bleeding, making it unsuitable in this scenario.

Copper-T 380A (Option B) is a non-hormonal IUCD, highly effective for contraception. However, it may worsen menorrhagia and contribute to anemia, making it unsuitable for this patient.

Norethisterone enanthate - depot injection (Option D): This progestin-only injectable contraceptive is safe for lactating women. However, it is associated with side effects like menstrual irregularities and osteopenia, making it less ideal for a patient already experiencing irregular, heavy bleeding.

questions.text: What will be observed in a patient diagnosed with sympathetic ophthalmitis, and a history of penetrating eye injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Panuveitis

  • The patient is likely experiencing sympathetic ophthalmia, a condition characterized by bilateral granulomatous panuveitis following trauma to one eye. The pathogenesis involves a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (T-cell mediated) to tyrosinase peptide antigens or melanocytes, leading to non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation in both eyes.

Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO)

Definition
  • Bilateral, granulomatous, panuveitis occurring after penetrating trauma where uveal prolapse may have been a feature of the trauma

Etiology and pathogenesis
  • Trauma to one eye (exciting eye) — 2 weeks to 3 months — Uveitis in the uninjured eye (sympathizing eye).
  • T-cell mediated autoimmune hypersensitivity reaction to Retinal S antigen.
  • Maximum risk upon injury to the ciliary body.

Histopathology
  • Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the choroid.
  • Scattered aggregates of epithelioid cells are seen, many of which contain fine granules of melanin.
  • Dalen–Fuchs nodules - granulomas located between Bruch membrane and the RPE (also seen in VKH syndrome)

Clinical features
  • The exciting eye is frequently red and irritable.
  • The sympathizing eye develops irritation, blurred vision, photophobia and loss of accommodation causing difficulty in near vision (first symptom)
  • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, which may be mild or severe and is usually granulomatous

Investigations
  • Fundus exam: Dalen–Fuchs nodules, Exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis and optic disc swelling.
  • As inflammation settles, residual chorioretinal scarring may confer a ‘sunset glow’ appearance similar to VKH.
  • B-scan ultrasonography: Choroidal thickening and retinal detachment

Treatment
  • Enucleation of a severely injured eye within 10 to 14 days of the injury is effective in preventing or reducing the severity of SO
  • Steroids are the basis of initial treatment. Intravenous methylprednisolone followed by high-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months and gradually tapered according to response. Supplementary topical steroids and cycloplegics may be given

Causes of Panuveitis:

MCP: Multifocal Choroiditis and Panuveitis, BSRC: Birdshot Retinochoroidopathy, ABD: Acute Bilateral Diffuse Uveal Retinitis, VKH: Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada Disease, SFU: Sarcoid-Associated Fuchs Uveitis, TB: Tuberculosis, HSV: Herpes Simplex Virus, VZV: Varicella-Zoster Virus, ARN: Acute Retinal Necrosis

Acute anterior uveitis (Option A): While acute anterior uveitis can occur in sympathetic ophthalmitis, it is not the most characteristic feature. Inflammatory involvement is not limited to just the anterior uvea in sympathetic ophthalmitis, as it typically progresses to involve all layers (hence panuveitis).

Pars planitis (Option B) is a type of intermediate uveitis that primarily affects the pars plana of the eye, but it is not typically associated with sympathetic ophthalmitis. It is a distinct form of uveitis, not related to penetrating trauma or autoimmune responses following injury.

Chronic anterior uveitis (Option D): This is not the typical presentation in sympathetic ophthalmitis. While inflammation can persist, it is more commonly panuveitis (involving both anterior and posterior segments), rather than isolated chronic anterior uveitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done, and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario and biopsy findings are consistent with Sertoli cell-only syndrome. This condition typically presents in males between 20 and 40 years of age with primary infertility. The testicular biopsy in Sertoli cell-only syndrome reveals seminiferous tubules populated exclusively by Sertoli cells, with a thickened tubular basement membrane and the absence of germ cells. This histological pattern is diagnostic of the condition.

 

Pathophysiology of Sertoli cell-only syndrome:

  • Sertoli cells line the seminiferous tubules and support spermatogenesis. They respond to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and testosterone, which are necessary for sperm production.
  • In Sertoli cell-only syndrome, there are no germ cells in the seminiferous tubules, leading to very low or absent spermatogenesis.
  • As a result, FSH levels rise due to the lack of feedback inhibition from spermatozoa, while testosterone and LH levels remain normal since Leydig cells are unaffected.
  • Normal physical examination, with no sexual abnormalities, is characteristic.
  • Diagnosis is made via biopsy, and patients may require assisted reproductive technologies for fertility.

 

Testicular atrophy (Option B) is characterized by the thickening of the basement membrane of the seminiferous tubules, hyalinization, and absence of germ cells. It may be due to cryptorchidism, atherosclerosis, cachexia, or the end stage of orchitis. Testicular atrophy typically presents with a reduced testicular size and decreased testosterone levels.

Benign testicular neoplasm (Option C) includes Sertoli cell tumors and Leydig cell tumors. Sertoli cell tumors would not present with the complete absence of germ cells seen in Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Leydig cell tumors, unlike Sertoli cells, are characterized by the presence of Reinke crystals.

Orchitis (Option D) refers to inflammation of the testes, typically caused by bacterial or viral infections. It is characterized by the inflammatory infiltration of neutrophils and may progress to abscess formation. The biopsy in orchitis would show inflammatory cells, which is not seen in Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. Which drugs are used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

Explanation:

  • For a patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation who is unwilling to continue the pregnancy, the combination of misoprostol and mifepristone is the recommended medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) regimen.

 

Stepwise Approach for MTP:

  1. Mifepristone (200mg): Administered orally on day 1. Mifepristone is a progesterone antagonist, which leads to the detachment of the pregnancy from the uterine lining, causing fetal death.
  2. Misoprostol (800 mcg): Administered 24-48 hours later through vaginal, sublingual, or buccal routes. Misoprostol induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy.

 

Confirmation: Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 after the procedure to ensure the termination is complete.

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act

  • The original act was passed in 1971 and amended in 2021.

 

Indications:

  • Maternal Risk
  • Fetal Risk: Spina bifida, Down syndrome.
  • Eugenic Conditions: Risks to both mother and fetus.
  • Humanitarian Cause: Pregnancy resulting from rape.
  • Contraceptive Failure.

 

Qualifications:

  • MBBS, MD/DNB/DGO
  • MBBS who has trained in gynaecology for 6 months
  • MBBS who has performed 25 MTPs under supervision
  • ASHA and AYUSH cannot perform MTP.

 

Additions of 2021 amendment:

  • Abortions allowed up to 20-24 weeks.
  • <20 weeks - Single doctor’s decision; 20-24 weeks - 2 doctors.
  • Extension of abortion rights to single, unmarried females.
  • Inclusion of marital rape under the MTP Act.
  • Abortions >24 weeks in cases of significant fetal anomalies with no gestational upper limit, are to be decided by a state medical board (gynecologist, pediatrician, radiologist).

 

Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks)

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)

20-24 weeks

  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy

 

Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone (Option A):
Medroxyprogesterone is not used for MTP. It is a progestin used for contraception and to manage menstrual irregularities, but it has no role in the medical termination of pregnancy.

Mifepristone and Methotrexate (Option C):
Methotrexate can be used for medical abortion in certain cases, but it is not a first-line option for early pregnancies. Methotrexate works by inhibiting DNA synthesis and cell division, but mifepristone is the more commonly used and effective drug in combination with misoprostol.

Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone (Option D):
As mentioned above, Medroxyprogesterone has no role in medical abortion. The correct regimen involves mifepristone and misoprostol.

questions.text: What does this image indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Keratoconus:

  • The image most likely represents keratoconus, characterized by the thinning and cone-shaped bulging of the cornea, leading to visual distortion and irregular astigmatism.

Keratoconus

  • Definition: Progressive, non-inflammatory bilateral ectatic corneal condition affecting the axial part.
  • Pathology: Involves progressive thinning and ectasia of the cornea due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharides and collagen.

Clinical Features

  • Symptoms:
    • Defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism, uncorrectable by glasses.
    • Blurred and distorted vision, glare, halos around lights.
    • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation.
    • Visual loss mainly from irregular astigmatism and myopia; secondary loss due to corneal scarring.

Examination Findings

  • Corneal Thinning & Bulging: The Cornea thins near the centre and bulges forward, with the cone apex slightly below the corneal centre.
  • Specific Signs:
    • Distorted Window Reflex: Visual irregularity on corneal reflection.
    • Placido Disc Irregularity: Circles appear irregular.
    • Slit-Lamp Examination:
      • Thinning and ectasia of the central cornea.
      • Opacity at the apex, Fleischer Ring: Brownish ring around the cone, possibly due to haemosiderin in the epithelium.
      • Folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes.
      • Vogt Striae: Fine, parallel striae at the apex, best seen with a slit lamp, disappearing with external pressure (vs Haab striae: They are curvilinear breaks in Descemet's membrane, resulting acutely from stretching of the cornea in primary congenital glaucoma).

Oil droplet reflex

  • Retinoscopy: Yawning reflex (scissor reflex) with high oblique/irregular astigmatism.
  • Distant Direct Ophthalmoscopy: Annular dark shadow (oil droplet reflex) separating central and peripheral cornea. A ring of shadow concentric with the margin in the red reflex, resembling an oil droplet.
  • Ophthalmoscope Findings: Irregular Astigmatism: Progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism in later stages, poorly corrected by glasses.
  • Munson's Sign: Localized bulging of the lower lid when looking down (seen in late stages).
  • Keratometer Findings: Malformed, malaligned, and malfocused mires.
  • Corneal Topography: The most sensitive method for early detection (Forme Fruste Keratoconus) shows the shape of the corneal surface.

Vogt's limbal girdle (Option B): This refers to a white or grayish band at the corneal margin, but it is not associated with corneal thinning or bulging, as seen in keratoconus.

Keratoglobus (Option C): This is a rare condition where the cornea is uniformly thin and globular in shape, but it is not associated with the same irregular astigmatism and conical shape as keratoconus.

Corneal dystrophy (Option D): This is a group of inherited disorders that cause abnormal deposits in the cornea, but the presentation is different from keratoconus. It does not typically involve the corneal thinning and cone shape seen in keratoconus.

questions.text: Identify the image modality given below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) PET CT

Explanation:

  • It is a type of imaging that combines positron emission tomography (PET) and computed tomography (CT) into a single machine.
  • PET scans measure metabolic activity in the body by detecting the distribution of a radioactive tracer. A PET scan is specifically designed to show metabolic changes in the body, particularly by tracking the uptake of radioactive tracers like F-18 fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG).
  • while CT scans provide detailed images of the anatomy.

Feature

PET

SPECT (Option A ruled out)

Cost

Very expensive

Less expensive

Radioactive Tracers

Uses positron-emitting radioisotope (tracer): F-18 fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG)

Uses gamma-emitting radioisotopes (tracers): technetium-99m, iodine-123, iodine-131

Detector Design

Ring of multiple detectors

 

Usually one large crystal-based detector

Image Quality

Better contrast and spatial resolution

Poor contrast and spatial resolution

Functionality

Shows metabolic changes

Doesn't show metabolic changes

Sensitivity

More sensitive

Less sensitive; fewer events detected.

Imaging

 

Sestamibi scan (Option C): It is a type of nuclear medicine scan that is used to image the heart, parathyroid gland, and breast. It uses the radiotracer technetium-99m sestamibi and a gamma camera to produce images.

Full body MDCT (Option D): MDCT stands for multi-detector computed tomography, which is a type of CT that uses multiple rows of detectors to produce detailed 3D images of the body. It is commonly used to detect cancers, injuries, and other abnormalities in the body.

questions.text: After a road traffic accident, a patient arrives at the emergency department. Upon examination, the patient is awake and alert, with a blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute, and a pulse rate of 120 bpm. An X-ray is provided for evaluation. What would be the subsequent course of action in terms of treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Chest tube insertion

Explanation:

  • The given X-ray shows a right-side pneumothorax and requires immediate intervention. The appropriate next step in management would be inserting a chest tube to decompress the pneumothorax and restore normal lung function.

 

Comparison of Normal and Pneumothorax Lungs:

Parameter

Normal Lung

Pneumothorax Lung

Inspiration

Black

Black

Expiration

White

Black

 

Radiographic appearance of pneumothorax:

  • Pneumothorax appears as a radiolucent area (black).
  • Pneumothorax pushes the adjacent lung towards the hilum.
  • A sharp radiopaque line separates the pneumothorax from the lung parenchyma.
  • A closed pneumothorax is easily detectable in an expiratory X-ray, as there is a decrease in lung volume. However, the volume of the pneumothorax is not affected by respiration.
  • Approach:
    • Small pleural air is detected by a lateral decubitus radiograph with the non-dependant abnormal side. It is contraindicated for the patient to be positioned with the normal side down and the abnormal side up, as air in the pneumothorax will rise to the non-dependent areas of the thoracic cavity.
    • A horizontal beam “shoot-through” lateral radiograph detects anterior pneumothorax in a supine patient.

Tension pneumothorax

Loculated pneumothorax

  • Significant contralateral deviation of the mediastinum
  • Collapsed lung
  • Depression of ipsilateral hemidiaphragm
  • Ovoid air collection
  • Close to the chest wall
  • Pleural adhesions are seen as line shadows

 

Note: Chest X-rays are useful, but a CT scan is considered the most sensitive investigation/ investigation of choice for pneumothorax.

questions.text: A 1-day-old neonate has not passed urine since birth. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Continue breast feeding and observe

  • If a healthy neonate has not urinated within 24 hours, the initial step is to continue breastfeeding and observe.


First Urine in Newborns:

  • The first urination typically occurs within 12-24 hours after birth.
  • In the first 2 days, urine is concentrated and may contain urates, causing orange or pink stains on diapers.
  • Urine retention or lack of urination beyond the first 24 hours requires medical evaluation.
  • Delay in passage of urine is seen in:
    • Posterior urethral valves (PUV)
    • Urethral atresia
    • Ureterocele
    • Urogenital sinus anomaly in females
    • Spina bifida

Meconium:

  • The first bowel movement is meconium, a sticky greenish-black substance.
  • Meconium should ideally be passed within 48 hours after birth.
  • Delayed passage of meconium could indicate intestinal blockage or other birth defects.
  • Delay in passage of first stool (Meconium) is seen in:
    • Meconium plug syndrome
    • Hirschsprung disease
    • Imperforate anus
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Sepsis

Admit to NICU (Option B): Admission to the NICU is warranted only if the neonate continues to not pass urine beyond 24 hours or develops other concerning symptoms such as dehydration or systemic illness.

Start artificial feeding (Option C): Artificial feeding is indicated only if breastfeeding is insufficient or not possible, such as in cases where the mother cannot breastfeed or the neonate has difficulty latching or feeding effectively.

Start intravenous fluids (Option D): IV fluids are necessary only if the neonate shows signs of dehydration or if there is a suspicion of an underlying medical condition requiring immediate intervention.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Saphenous nerve

Explanation:

  • The saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve that provides sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the leg and foot.
  • It is the largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and runs alongside the great saphenous vein in the medial leg.
  • During surgery for varicose veins (often involving the great saphenous vein), the saphenous nerve is at risk of being injured because of its close proximity to the vein.

Superficial peroneal nerve (Option B):

  • Provides sensory innervation to the anterolateral lower leg and most of the dorsum of the foot, excluding the web space between the first and second toes.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy. Investigations reveal hyperuricemia, raised creatinine levels, and hyperkalemia. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Hydration

  • The child with abdominal pain, vomiting, oliguria, and periorbital puffiness following chemotherapy, along with hyperuricemia, raised creatinine levels, and hyperkalemia, is suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. The next best step in management is hydration.

Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS):

  • A clinical condition caused by extensive tumor cell lysis and characterized by metabolic disturbances, such as hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperuricemia, which can lead to end-organ damage.
  • This syndrome is most commonly observed in patients with hematologic malignancies.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Abdominal Symptoms: Abdominal pain and distension.
    • Urinary Symptoms: Dysuria, oliguria, flank pain, and hematuria.
    • Symptoms of Hypocalcemia:
      • Anorexia
      • Vomiting
      • Muscle cramps and spasms
      • Seizures
      • Tetany
      • Altered mental status
  • Timing: TLS typically occurs 12-48 hours after initiating chemotherapy but can occur spontaneously in tumors with the high burden (e.g., Burkitt lymphoma, lymphoblastic lymphoma, high WBC leukemia).
  • Rare Tumors: TLS is infrequently reported in Hodgkin lymphoma, neuroblastoma, or hepatoblastoma.
  • Pre-Therapy Evaluation: Measure serum uric acid, electrolytes, calcium, phosphorus, and creatinine. Ensure adequate hydration.
  • Prevention:
    • Allopurinol (xanthine oxidase inhibitor) to prevent uric acid accumulation. (Option C)
    • Rasburicase (uric acid-degrading enzyme) in high-risk patients or those with established TLS to decrease the accumulation of uric acid. (Option D)

Probenecid (Option B) inhibits organic anion transporters to reduce uric acid reabsorption, promoting excretion. However, it is contraindicated in TLS as it increases the risk of uric acid crystal formation and kidney stones due to increased uric acid levels.

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the left lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Intussusception

  • The clinical scenario of abdominal pain, a palpable mass in the left lumbar region, and the characteristic claw sign on barium enema suggests Intussusception.

Intussusception:

  • It refers to the telescoping of a proximal segment of the intestine (intussusceptum) into a distal segment (intussuscipiens).
  • Most common cause of intestinal obstruction in 5 months to 6 years of age.
  • It may be ileocolic (most common), colocolic or ileoileal.

Clinical features:

  • The classic triad of abdominal pain, red currant jelly stools (blood and mucus) and palpable mass are observed.
  • Barium enema shows a ‘Coiled Spring Sign or Claw Sign’. 

Management:

  • Spontaneous resolution occurs in a few patients.
  • Hydrostatic reduction under Fluoroscopic or USG guidance.
  • Surgical reduction may be required if the child has refractory shock, suspected intestinal perforation or necrosis, or in case of multiple recurrences or peritonitis.


Sigmoid volvulus (Option B) presents with abdominal pain, bloating, constipation, and inability to pass gas. Imaging typically shows the ‘coffee bean’ sign or omega sign on X-ray, not the claw sign seen in intussusception.

Duodenal atresia (Option C) presents with bilious or non-bilious vomiting immediately after birth, without abdominal distension. Imaging shows the double bubble sign (gas in the stomach and proximal duodenum), not the claw sign or any barium study findings typical of intussusception.

Intestinal obstruction (Option D) presents with abdominal pain, distension, and constipation. X-ray findings include multiple air-fluid levels, and barium studies are contraindicated in acute obstruction, unlike the findings specific to intussusception.

questions.text: Identify the given structure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pancreatic islet cells

Explanation:

  • Pancreatic islet cells are clusters of endocrine cells within the pancreas that secrete hormones such as insulin and glucagon.
  • Pancreatic islet cells are also known as islets of Langerhans. Each islet comprises a few distinctive sorts of cells, including alpha, beta, delta, and PP cells that work together to direct blood glucose levels.
  • The islet cells are organized in a round or unpredictably molded cluster and are encompassed by a thin layer of connective tissue.

 

Lymph node (Option A):

Glomerulus (Option B):

 

Spleen (Option C):

Correct Answer: D) White fibrocartilage

  • White fibrocartilage is found in zones of the body where strength and support are required, such as the intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, and menisci of the knee.
