questions.text: An 8-day-old newborn was found to have thyroid-stimulating hormone levels of more than 100 mIU/L. Which of the following will be the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Radiotracer uptake with technetium:

  • Radiotracer uptake with technetium is the next best step to evaluate thyroid size, location, and function, helping differentiate between thyroid dysgenesis, dyshormonogenesis, or ectopic thyroid.

Congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation, which results from a deficient production of thyroid hormone.
  • More common among girls
  • The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism is thyroid dysgenesis.

Etiology of congenital hypothyroidism:

1. Primary hypothyroidism:

  • Thyroid dysgenesis
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
  • Iodine deficiency (endemic goiter)
  • Defect in thyroid hormone transporter- Mutation in MCT8 (monocarboxylate transporter 8) gene
  • Maternal antibodies- TRBAb (thyrotropin receptor-blocking antibody)
  • Maternal medications- Iodides, amiodarone, propylthiouracil, methimazole, radioiodine

2. Central (hypopituitary) hypothyroidism:

  • TSH deficiency- mutation in TSH beta subunit gene
  • TRH deficiency- mutation in the TRH gene
  • TRH unresponsiveness- mutation in TRH receptor gene
  • Multiple congenital pituitary hormone deficiencies

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiological jaundice - early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation - not responsive to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • A dull-looking face with macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells
  • Hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes
  • Macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment

Diagnosis:

Primary hypothyroidism:

  • T4 level: low
  • TSH usually>100mIU/L

 

  • Central hypothyroidism: Low TSH, T3, and T4 levels

Radionuclide scanning (technetium-99m or iodine-123) or ultrasonography helps assess thyroid size and location to differentiate thyroid dysgenesis, dyshormonogenesis, or transient abnormalities in congenital hypothyroidism.

X-ray findings in congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis at birth
  • Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis
  • Deformity or breaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebrae
  • X-ray image of skull- large fontanelle and wide sutures

Screening:

  • Universal newborn screening for congenital hypothyroidism
  • At birth, with umbilical cord blood
  • Heel prick: dried blood spots, sample collected beyond 48 hrs or 48-72hrs
  • Should not be done in first 1-2 days, to avoid TSH surge
  • Most sensitive approach- check for T4 and TSH both

American Society of Hematology (ASH) first strategy:

  • Initial TSH screening using dried blood spot
  • If TSH >20mIU/L, recheck
  • Obtain a venous blood sample to check T4 and TSH levels if TSH remains elevated.

Treatment

  • Oral levothyroxine (early morning with empty stomach for older children and for newborns it is to be given at a fixed time)
  • The dose is higher in the earlier age group, and as the babies grow, the dose reduces.
  • Newborn: 10-15 mg/kg/day
  • Children: 2-4 mg/kg/day

Urine iodine excretion (Option A) is primarily used for epidemiological studies and surveillance to classify iodine deficiency in populations, as recommended by the WHO. It measures iodine intake but is not specific for diagnosing congenital hypothyroidism in individual cases.

Serum thyroid receptor antibody (Option B) is helpful in diagnosing transient congenital hypothyroidism caused by transplacental passage of TSH receptor-blocking antibodies, particularly in neonates of mothers with autoimmune hypothyroidism.

The perchlorate secretion test (Option D) is used to diagnose thyroid peroxidase deficiency by assessing iodide organification defects. It is not the initial test of choice for congenital hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression in developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

  • The infant's presentation of jerking movements (infantile spasms), developmental regression, and hypsarrhythmia on EEG is characteristic of West syndrome. Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in this condition.

West Syndrome

Age group

Typically occurs between 2 and 12 months of age.

Genetics

ARX Gene Mutations: In males, linked to ambiguous genitalia and cortical migration abnormalities.

Types
  • Cryptogenic (Unknown Etiology): Normal development before onset.
  • Symptomatic: Associated with developmental delays due to perinatal issues, brain malformations, metabolic disorders, or other causes.

Clinical Features
  • Infantile Epileptic Spasms: Clusters of spasms occurring mainly during drowsiness or upon waking.
  • Developmental Regression
  • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG: A chaotic, high-voltage background with multifocal spikes.

Management

First-Line Treatment: Hormonal therapy, primarily ACTH (80 mg/mL)

  • Dosage: 150 units/m² daily (75 units/m² twice daily) for 2 weeks, then taper gradually.
  • Monitoring: EEGs at 1, 2, and 4 weeks to assess response.
  • Early intervention is crucial, as a delay beyond 3 weeks can worsen the prognosis.

Alternative Treatments
  • Oral Prednisolone: Lower-cost alternative (Less effective)
  • Vigabatrin: Used as a first-line agent in West syndrome associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) or second-line if hormonal therapy fails. Side effects include retinal toxicity.
  • Ketogenic Diet: Considered a third-line therapy.
  • Other Medications: Valproate, benzodiazepines (nitrazepam, clonazepam), topiramate, lamotrigine, zonisamide, pyridoxine, and IVIG. These drugs can help reduce seizure frequency and severity but are not uniformly effective and may be used alongside ACTH or vigabatrin in cases with incomplete response.

Side Effects and Precautions
  • Side Effects of Hormonal Therapy: Hypertension, electrolyte imbalance, infections, hyperglycemia, and gastric ulcers.
  • Vaccination: Live vaccines are contraindicated, and other vaccines may be ineffective during and shortly after hormonal therapy.

Phenytoin (Option A) is primarily used for focal seizures and status epilepticus. Ineffective for infantile spasms or the underlying EEG abnormality (hypsarrhythmia) seen in West syndrome.

Levetiracetam (Option C) is effective for focal seizures and status epilepticus, but not proven beneficial for infantile spasms.

Phenobarbitone (Option D) is commonly used as an antiepileptic in neonatal seizures and as an enzyme inducer in Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II. Less effective than ACTH for managing infantile spasms.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step?

choices.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics
Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

  • In this scenario, where an infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea, the next best step is to perform a dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR to assess whether the infant has acquired HIV.

Maternal Antibodies: Infants born to HIV-positive mothers will test positive for HIV antibodies due to passive transfer from the mother. These antibodies typically disappear in uninfected infants by 6-18 months, but some may persist up to 24 months.

Diagnosis of HIV in Infants:

 

< 24 Months
  • Antibody Tests: Not reliable for definitive diagnosis due to maternal antibody presence.
  • IgA & IgM Tests: Not clinically useful d/t poor sensitivity and specificity.
  • Viral Diagnostic Tests:
    • HIV DNA PCR: Highly sensitive and specific by two weeks of age.
    • HIV RNA PCR: Similar to DNA PCR.

> 24 Months

IgG Antibody Tests: Reliable if repeatedly positive, confirmed with HIV PCR.

Testing Protocols
  • Rapid HIV Tests are useful for immediate diagnosis in newborns, but positive results must be confirmed with a second test or PCR.
  • For breastfed infants, test 12 weeks after breastfeeding ends to detect any potential infection acquired through lactation.
  • High-Risk Infants: Initial viral testing within the first 12-24 hours, followed by additional tests at 2-3 weeks, 4-8 weeks, and 4-6 months if needed.

Definitive Diagnosis

For nonbreastfed infants, HIV infection can be excluded with

  • Two negative virologic tests at ≥1 month and ≥4 months
  • Two negative antibody tests at ≥6 months.

Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics (Option A): While testing for giardia and administering antibiotics may be appropriate in cases of infectious diarrhea, it would not address the primary concern of diagnosing HIV in a newborn born to an HIV-positive mother. The HIV diagnosis should be confirmed first before addressing secondary infections.

Antibody test for HIV (Option C) is not recommended for infants under 18 months, as they may still have maternal antibodies circulating, which can interfere with the test's accuracy, making it unsuitable for diagnosing HIV in a newborn.

Aerobic culture (Option D) is typically used to detect bacterial infections, but it would not help in diagnosing the underlying cause of diarrhea in this scenario, where HIV-related issues are the primary concern.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has difficulty walking and getting up from a squatting position. A muscle biopsy was done and is shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: It is a mitochondrial storage disorder
Early treatment has an excellent prognosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Death occurs in 3rd decade:

  • The clinical scenario and muscle biopsy showing fatty replacement of muscle fibers suggest Duchenne muscular dystrophy. This condition typically leads to progressive muscle weakness, with death occurring in the late teens or early 20s (third decade).

Features

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)

Inheritance Pattern

X-linked recessive

Type of Mutation

Frameshift mutations leading to a disrupted reading frame

Dystrophin Protein
  • Dystrophin deficient
  • Truncated and unstable (< 3% of normal)

Age of Onset

Before 5 years

Clinical Severity

Severe, early onset, rapid progression

Early Symptoms

Hip girdle weakness, delayed walking, Gowers’ sign, lordotic posture, frequent falls

Ambulation Loss

Typically between 10-14 years

Progression Rate

Rapid

Muscle Involvement

Proximal muscle weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy

Cardiac Involvement

Common, usually worsens after loss of ambulation

Cognitive Impairment

Common (20-30% with IQ < 70), possible autism-like behavior, epilepsy

Respiratory Involvement

Common, leading to frequent pulmonary infections, sleep apnea, and respiratory failure

Initial Genetic Evaluation
  • Primary Testing: Deletion/duplication analysis of the dystrophin gene using dosage analysis.
  • Next-generation sequencing (NGS) if initial testing is negative.

Muscle Biopsy
  • Indications: Used when genetic tests are inconclusive, especially if serum CK levels are elevated.
  • Findings: Endomysial connective tissue proliferation, degenerating/regenerating myofibers, hypercontracted fibers, dystrophin abnormalities.

Steroid Therapy
  • Purpose: Slows muscle strength decline, prolongs ambulation, and may benefit scoliosis progression.
  • Dosing: Prednisone (0.75 mg/kg/day) or deflazacort (0.9 mg/kg/day); various dosing protocols available.

Life Expectancy

Late teens to 20s


Previous history of viral prodrome (Option B): A viral prodrome, which includes symptoms like fever or malaise before a viral infection, is not typically associated with Duchenne muscular dystrophy or mitochondrial disorders.

It is a mitochondrial storage disorder (Option C): Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene, not by the accumulation of abnormal substances in mitochondria, making it distinct from mitochondrial storage disorders.

Early treatment has an excellent prognosis (Option D): While early intervention can slow the progression of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the condition typically has a poor long-term prognosis, with death occurring in the late teens to early 20s due to respiratory or cardiac complications.

questions.text:
Which of the following children are considered at-risk babies?


	Baby with a birth weight of 2.5 kg
	Baby on artificial feeding
	Baby of working mother/single parent
	Baby with weight <85% of expected weight
	Birth order of 3 or more
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 2, 3

  • Among the options, babies on artificial feeding and babies of working mothers/single parents are considered at-risk babies.

At-Risk Infants:

  • Identifying and providing special care to "at-risk" infants is crucial to reduce perinatal, neonatal, and infant mortality.
  • Criteria for Identification:
    • Birth weight <2.5 kg (1)
    • Twins
    • Birth order 5 or more (5)
    • Artificial feeding (2)
    • Weight below 70% of expected weight (4)
    • Failure to gain weight over three successive months
    • Children with protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) or diarrhea.
    • Working mother or single parent (3)
  • These criteria help in prioritizing infants who require intensive care and monitoring.

questions.text: Identify the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bladder exstrophy

  • The above image is suggestive of Bladder exstrophy.

Bladder exstrophy:

Etiology
  • Disruption in normal development during pregnancy.
  • Exact triggers remain unclear.

Pathology & Pathophysiology
  • Improper development of the cloacal membrane.
  • Early rupture leads to epispadias (incomplete urethral formation).
  • Later rupture results in bladder exstrophy.

Types
  • Spectrum from simple epispadias to more complex forms of bladder exstrophy.

Clinical Features

Males:

  • Shortened penis due to pubic bone separation (diastasis of the pubic symphysis).
  • Widely spaced crura (internal, spongy columns within the penis).
  • Underdeveloped corporeal tissue (erectile tissue).

Females:

  • Shortened and narrowed vagina, often positioned more anteriorly.
  • Bifid clitoris (split into two parts).

Complications
  • Urinary function issues.
  • Increased risk of infections.
  • Risk factor for Adenocarcinoma.

Surgical Treatment
  • Cover the bladder with a wet sterile plastic wrap and plan for surgery.

Surgical repair, in multiple stages.

  • Steps Include:
  • Closing the bladder and placing it back inside the body.
  • Reconstructing the urethra.
  • Repairing the abdominal wall defect.
  • Addressing genital abnormalities to ensure normal function and appearance.

 

Omphalocele (Option B)

Gastroschisis (Option D)

Herniation of bowel contents that fails to return back

 

Evisceration of bowel contents through a defect in the anterior abdominal wall just lateral to the umbilicus

 

Defect through central umbilicus

Defect through right of umbilicus

Three-layer membrane covering present (peritoneum, Wharton's jelly & amnion)

Membrane cover absent

Associated with aneuploidies, genetic syndromes (eg. Beckwith -Wiedemann) and other congenital anomalies
  • Associated anomalies rare.
  • Gut malrotation/bowel atresia may be seen.

Poor prognosis in long term due to associated anomalies

Better prognosis in long term

 Persistent vitellointestinal duct (Option C) occurs when the vitelline duct remains patent over its entire length, leading to direct communication between the umbilicus and the intestines. This results in fecal discharge from the umbilicus.

questions.text: A previously healthy child presented with acute-onset dyspnea. A chest X-ray shows unilateral hyperinflation of the lung. What is true for this patient?

choices.text: Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body
In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation
The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body:

  • The above scenario of acute-onset dyspnea and X-ray showing hyperinflation of the lung in a previously healthy child is suggestive of foreign body aspiration. In this case, auscultation would reveal a focal area of decreased air entry, which is characteristic of obstruction caused by a foreign body.

Lower Airway Foreign Body Aspiration:

Prevalence

  • Choking is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children, especially those under 4 years old.
  • Most victims are older infants and toddlers.

Common Objects
  • Food items: Nuts, seeds, hard candy, gum, bones, raw fruits and vegetables.
  • Inorganic objects: Coins, latex balloons, pins, jewelry, magnets, pen caps and toys.

Location

Bronchus > Trachea > Larynx

Types

Partial obstruction:

  • This causes a ball valve effect that leads to localized hyperinflation of the affected lung area (a bronchial foreign body blocks the exit of air from the obstructed lung during expiration). (Option C)
  • Overlying the chest wall shows hyperresonance, diminished vocal resonance and poor air entry.

Complete Obstruction:

  • Cause distal atelectasis and suppuration of surrounding parenchyma of lungs result in bronchiectasis.

Clinical Manifestation
  • Initial Event: Coughing, choking, gagging, potential airway obstruction. Some children may expel the foreign body during this stage.
  • Asymptomatic Interval: Immediate symptoms subside; foreign body remains lodged. Can be misleading and lead to delayed diagnosis.
  • Complications: Fever, cough, hemoptysis, pneumonia, atelectasis.

Diagnosis

  • Positive history is crucial.
  • Plain Films: Recommended first; may miss radiolucent objects (80-96%).
  • Expiratory Films: Reveal secondary findings like air trapping, asymmetric hyperinflation.
  • CT Scan: High sensitivity and specificity but involves radiation.
  • Bronchoscopy: Should be performed if suspicion remains despite negative or inconclusive imaging.

Treatment

  • Prompt endoscopic removal with a rigid bronchoscope. (Option B)
  • Appropriate antibiotics are given for secondary infection.

The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Option D): Laryngotracheobronchitis, commonly caused by the parainfluenza virus, presents with symptoms such as barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever, and is associated with a "steeple sign" on X-ray. However, unilateral hyperinflation of the lung is not characteristic of laryngotracheobronchitis, which typically shows subglottic narrowing, making this diagnosis less likely in this case.

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limb. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glucocorticoids

Explanation: The clinical scenario of arthralgia, abdominal pain, palpable purpura over the lower limbs, and a history of a preceding upper respiratory tract infection is suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used for the treatment of HSP.
 

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP):

Etiology
  • Exact cause unknown.
  • Immune-mediated vasculitis, often following an upper respiratory infection.
  • Genetic predisposition, with HLA-B34 and DRB1 observed in some cases.
  • Most common in males.

Pathology and Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation of small blood vessels affecting skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys.
  • Triggered by immune system response to infections.
  • Leakage of fluid and blood cells into tissues.
  • Immune complex deposition, particularly IgA, in affected vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Palpable Purpura: Raised, purplish-red rash, mainly on legs and buttocks.
  • Joint Involvement: Joint swelling, commonly in knees and ankles.
  • Abdominal Pain: Often severe, may include vomiting, diarrhea, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception.
  • Renal Involvement: Less common, presents as Chronic renal failure.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

Palpable purpura plus at least one of:

  1. Diffuse abdominal pain
  2. Arthritis or arthralgia
  3. Biopsy-proven IgA deposition
  4. Renal involvement

 

Laboratory involvement:

  • Elevated ESR or CRP indicating inflammation.
  • Platelet Counts are normal.

Complications
  • Intussusception.
  • Chronic Renal Failure due to Long-term kidney damage, in severe cases.
  • Neurological Complications: Rare; may include seizures, headaches, or peripheral neuropathy.

Treatment
  • Mild Cases: Rest, hydration, and pain relievers.
  • Moderate to Severe Cases: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) to reduce inflammation.
  • Severe or Resistant Cases: Additional immunosuppressive medications may be required.

Prognosis
  • Full recovery in most cases.
  • Variable based on renal involvement.


Azathioprine (Option A) is used as an immunosuppressive agent, generally for autoimmune diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus, not for HSP unless there is severe renal involvement.

Methotrexate (Option B) is often used in the treatment of autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, but not a first-line treatment for HSP.

Cyclosporine (Option C) is used in organ transplant immunosuppression or autoimmune diseases and may be considered for nephrotic syndrome in certain cases, but is not a first-line therapy for HSP.

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with edema and anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease is made. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Good response to steroids

  • The correct statement about minimal change disease is a good response to steroids.

Feature

Minimal Change Disease (MCD)

Clinical Presentation

Nephrotic syndrome: Edema, heavy selective proteinuria, but normal renal function (Option D ruled out)

Age

Appears between 2 to 6 years of age (Option C ruled out)

Proteinuria

Heavy (3+ to 4+) on dipstick

Hematuria

Rare, microscopic hematuria may occur

Urinary Casts

Hyaline and granular casts

Serum Albumin

Low (<1 g/dL)

Blood Urea and Creatinine

Normal unless hypovolemia or acute kidney injury

Serum Complement C3

Normal

Cholesterol

Hypercholesterolemia (may cause milky plasma)

ASO/Anti-DNase B Titers

Not elevated

Light Microscopy

Glomeruli appears normal

Electron Microscopy

Diffuse effacement of podocytes. (Option A ruled out)

Treatment

Corticosteroid

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and weight loss. On examination, the height and weight are lesser than expected. Laboratory investigations were positive for class II HLA-DQ2. Which of the following will you advise the child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Gluten-free diet

  • The clinical scenario of diarrhea, weight loss, growth failure, and positive class II HLA-DQ2 points towards a diagnosis of celiac disease. The next step is to advise a gluten-free diet to manage the condition.

Celiac disease or Gluten-sensitive enteropathy:

  • T-cell mediated autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten, associated with HLADQ2 and HLADQ8.
  • High-risk groups: Type 1 diabetes mellitus, Down syndrome, selective IgA deficiency, autoimmune thyroid disease, Turner syndrome, Williams syndrome, Addison’s disease, autoimmune liver disease and first-degree relatives of patients with celiac disease.
  • Clinical manifestations:
    • Diarrhoea, growth failure, and anemia.
    • Temporal association with the introduction of wheat products during weaning.
    • Abdominal distension, vomiting, anorexia, aphthous stomatitis, and bloating.
    • Rickets, osteoporosis, short stature, muscular atrophy, peripheral neuropathy, and irritability might be seen in some cases.
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis can be seen.
  • Diagnosis: ESPGHAN (European Society for Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology & Nutrition) guidelines 2020 suggest that in all suspected cases (symptomatic, asymptomatic, and at-risk group), the first test should be total serum IgA and IgA tTG (tissue transglutaminase IgA).

Serology
  • Anti-tTG (Tissue Transglutaminase)
  • Anti EMA (Endomysial antibody)
  • Anti-DGP (Deamidated gliadin peptide)

Upper GI endoscopy

The endoscopy may be normal or show the absence of folds or scalloped duodenal folds.

Histopathology
  • Villous atrophy/Flat villi
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Intraepithelial lymphocyte infiltration.

 

 

  • Treatment: Gluten-free diet (avoid wheat, rye, barley and oats)

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness (IMNCI), thischild will be classified as having:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Severe dehydration

  • The child’s history of loose stools with increased frequency for 4 days, drowsiness, inability to feed, and slow skin recoil with skin pinch suggests severe dehydration according to the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines.

Assessment of Dehydration in Children:

  1. Clinical Symptoms: Look for dry mucous membranes, sunken fontanelle (in infants), and irritability.
  2. Skin Turgor: Evaluate skin recoil; delayed recoil indicates dehydration.
  3. Capillary Refill Time: Assess capillary refill time; prolonged refill suggests dehydration.
  4. Urine Output: Monitor for decreased wet diapers or reduced frequency of urination.
  5. Vital Signs: Check for abnormal vital signs, such as elevated heart rate or low blood pressure.
  6. Mental Status and Behavior: Assess for changes in mental status, such as lethargy or confusion, which can indicate the severity of dehydration.

IMNCI Classification of Dehydration in children:

Sign/Symptom

No/Mild Dehydration

(Option A)

Some Dehydration (Option B)

Severe Dehydration

Mental status

Alert

Irritable/restless

Lethargic/unconscious

Thirst

Normal

Increased

Unable to drink

Eyes

Normal

Slightly sunken

Very sunken

Tears

Present

Decreased

Absent

Mouth

Moist

Dry

Parched

Skin turgor

Normal (Immediate skin recoil)

Slow recoil (2-3sec)

Very slow recoil (>3sec)

Capillary refill

Normal (<2sec)

Prolonged (2-3sec)

Prolonged (>3sec)

Urine output

Normal

Decreased

Minimal

questions.text: Please identify the manoeuvre being executed in the image provided.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option A) Head tilt, chin lift

Explanation:

  • The given manoeuvre is Head tilt and chin lift.

Head Tilt Chin Lift Maneuver:

  • The head is tilted back while lifting the chin upwards to prevent the tongue from obstructing the airway.
  • Used to open the airway in an unconscious patient without suspected spinal injury.

Jaw Thrust Maneuver: (Option B ruled out)

  • The lower jaw is lifted forward by placing fingers behind the angle of the mandible, moving the tongue forward and clearing the airway without moving the neck.
  • Used to open the airway in patients with suspected cervical spine injury.

 

Head extension (Optio C): It involves tilting the head backward but without lifting the chin. It is not as effective as the head tilt, chin lift for airway opening and is generally not recommended alone as a maneuver for maintaining a patent airway.

In-line manual stabilization (Option D): This technique is used to stabilize the cervical spine in patients with suspected spinal trauma, especially during airway management or intubation. The rescuer holds the patient’s head in a neutral position to prevent any cervical movement, which could worsen a spinal injury.
